content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
 Gameplay Stalker CoP is an open-world RPG survival shooter with 3 large areas Zaton, Yanov and Pripyat, very atmospheric with plenty of side quests that reward exploration.The beginning of the game is tricky with hardly any equipment or money, there's no tutorials or any kind of help so you need to find your own way to survive, isn't an easy gameThe A-life will not give up until you ran out of ammo or eventually die, some will trow objects at you     Screenshot  and even telekinetically steal your weapon, things appear randomly in the sky or mutants with camouflage   Screenshot   etc. Human opponents put up a tough fight, they kinda cheat in fog weather or at night even without nightvision scopes equipped, (but mods like Misery fixes that) so playind like CoD will get you killed.Still includes the emissions and anomalies (detectors needed for finding artifacts  Screenshot  ) and more customization of armor/weapons. Graphics it features the X-Ray 1.6 engine supports dx11 elements like real time tessellation, shadows, wet surfaces, volumetric smoke and others like SSAO DOF... so in other words it looks good, models and textures are a little outdated but shadows and sun rays are amazing (i recommend to use mods like AtmosFear3 specially designed for sky textures and weather behavior ). Screenshot  Sound The background noise of the zone is enchanting. In the distance, the reactor is booming as before, animals roaring in the west, shootout in the East, everything draws exactly the image of the restricted area as you are used to it. Multiplayer has Deathmatch and CTF style competitive matches with its multiplayer mode. Mind you, this doesn't exactly represent the highlight of the experience. If you want to get the best out of this game, stick with the main campaign, for what it's worth.  Story Call of Pripyat - takes place shortly after the events in Shadow of Chernobyl. Having discovered the open path to the center of The Zone, the government decides to take control of it via "Operation Fairway", in which they plan to thoroughly investigate the territory before dispatching the main military force.Despite these preparations, the military operation fails, with all five helicopters crashing. In order to determine the cause of the crashes, the Ukraine Security Service sends an ex STALKER agent, Major Degtyarev, into The ZoneAfter discovering that the crashes were caused by strong electrical currents, Degtyarev makes his way to an evacuation point located in Pripyat. Along the way, depending on the choices the player makes, he may meet a number of different characters that can become his allies. Eventually, after arriving in Pripyat, Degtyarev's party finds themselves surrounded by the military survivors, who take them to their base. Once there, they work together with the military commander of the helicopter group in surviving and escaping The Zone. They are met by Strelok, the protagonist of the first game, who offers his full cooperation including the reasons why the operation failed in the first place.Degtyarev then helps to re-establish contact with headquarters and, together with Strelok, organize a desperate evacuation out of The Zone. There are multiple different endings available depending on the player's success, whether or not some of the characters survive the evacuation and how the lives of other stalkers Degtyarev met throughout the game turn out. In the ideal scenario, Degtyarev becomes head of the Security Service in The Zone, and Strelok gives all the materials he found in The Zone to the government, prompting the creation of the "Scientific Institute for the Research of the Chernobyl Anomalous Area", with Strelok taking up the position of chief scientific consultant. Bugs/Glitches It has soooo many and it will crash or make one or two missions almost unplayable. i recomend to mod the game (some will make it worse lol). MODs MISERY: (for hardcore difficulty) its full concept modification that touches every game aspect including textures, sfx, music, weapons, AI, items, weather, economy and 3 playable USS characters classes to choose from: Assaulter, Recon and Sniper.Each comes with unique attributes like endurance, speed, health, stamina, weapon specializations, starting gear...AtmosFear: like i said before it tweaks and expands the vanilla weather system to be more realistic and various.Call of Pripyat Reloaded: it's like misery but for better and easier gameplay.http://www.moddb.com/games/stalker-call-of-pripyat/mods?sort=rating-descOverall 8.5/10It's easily in my top 5 Exploring the hazardous lands and scavenging through abandoned buildings with aggressive wildlife never gets old.This is a true PC game ( not ported, bad optimized or locked at 30fps and weird controls. not that junk we see today)If you liked the others stalkers this is a must or this type of game i recommend Metro series.sorry about errors/bad spelling, english isn't my main language

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												I really hated this game.I bought it, downloaded it, launched it, and found myself plunged instantaneously into the Zone. I was alone. There was no tutorial, no introductory cutscene, no explanation, not even a basic explanation of how the game worked. I walked forward, and looked around. I was instantly shocked at the low FOV and uncomfortably "floaty" mouse control. This was not what I was used to - my most played FPS is Team Fortress 2, closely followed by Fallout 3. S.T.A.L.K.E.R. was something else - something new. I was excited. I continued walking and came across three people with guns walking in the other direction. "STOP WAVING THAT THING ABOUT" one of them bellowed, while sticking his assault rifle up my nose. I pressed "e" (because by now I'd explored the options menu and rebound some keys) to speak to him. What was going on? That was a question that I'd ask myself a lot while playing this game. This guy told me absolutely nothing of interest, except that there was a base of some description a little further down the hill. By now I'd figured out what some of the HUD was for, and how to open my inventory. I then went to Skadovsk (although I didn't know what it was called then) and got yelled at to put my gun away again. So I opened my inventory and moved my rifle from its slot into my backpack. I would be doing this for a while until I discovered that I could just press "3" to holster my weapon. I then walked into the ship.I didn't know what the hell I was doing. Where was I? What am I doing here? What do I do now? So I spoke to someone who told me there was a strange glow in the distance that he wanted me to check out. Fair enough, I thought. So I went where the map pointed me and found a ship. I walked onto the ship - and died instantly for (seemingly) no reason. (In actual fact I'd hit an anomaly, I just had no idea what anomalies were or what I was doing.)  Having not saved at any point, I started the game again. When I got to Skadovsk for the second time, I couldn't find the guy I'd previously talked to, so I talked to Sultan instead. He wanted me to help kill some people. Once again, I thought "fair enough" and went with him. At midnight I boarded a boat and once again struggled to see what the ♥♥♥♥ was happening in the darkness. I think I killed someone. And I got some money. So then, being a Fallout veteran and this being an open world game, I decided to go exploring. I went about 100 metres and the game crashed. One thought ran through my mind: "♥♥♥♥ this". I quit the game and didn't come back for at least a month. I ♥♥♥♥ing hated this game. What I piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ I thought. I couldn't understand the 95% positive review score. This was after about 1 hour's play time. Eventually I was bored and I decided to boot the game again. After switching my lighting renderer from DX10 to DX11 (as the internet told me to) the game didn't crash (although it does crash a lot when trying to enter the "load game" screen). I then tried again. I got to Skadovsk. I talked to Sultan. I did the mission. I learned how to quicksave. From there, I continued (on the easiest difficulty because I'm a casual scrublord).I then discovered why this game has so many positive reviews. Although the graphics are somewhat dated, the gameplay and atmosphere are second to none. I warmed to the game within another hour. Did some side missions, figured out where I was and what I was doing. I learned what anomalies are. I learned how to collect artifacts. And, ultimately, I learned that Google is my best friend. From this I can see that at least 90% of the negative reviews are either performance issues (there is admittedly a good deal of stuttering in this game) or they are people who, like me, just haven't given the game a chance. I see people in the negative reviews saying how awful the game is with 1.6 hours on record. And I know why. This game tells you absolutely nothing. You know a sum total of jack♥♥♥♥♥♥ Why am I dying instantly for no reason? "♥♥♥♥ you, figure it out!" Why do my bullets not work? "♥♥♥♥ you, git gud." What do these numbers and icons mean? "♥♥♥♥ you, use google!" This is a good thing when you've got into the game because it enhances the atmosphere and is more immersive. The downside is it scares away new players who are frustrated by how bad they are at the game. To people who are looking at buying this game: I say buy it and don't give up on it in the first hour. Google things you don't know and teach yourself about the game - this is hardcore FPS survival horror and it does not hold your hand. In actual fact, it amputates your hand, kicks you into the ground and spits on your face. And that's without the Misery mod! If you are strong enough to get past that, it is one of the most atmospheric and immersive games I've ever played. The gunplay is amazing, it feels realistic, and you truly feel like this could be happening and you could be there experiencing it. If you like FPS survival horror, look no further than the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series.I love this game.N.B. After going into Pripyat, I went to the Kindergarten to do that mission where you destroy the interference transmitter. It was 1 A.M. and I had my flashlight on as I entered the psy-field. Blew up the door, went inside and the first thing I saw illuminated by my flashlight was the creepiest ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ lion I've ever seen. It scared the absolute living♥♥♥♥♥♥out of me - more than any horror game has ever done. АНУ ЧИКЙ БРИКЙ В ДАМКЕ

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												I spotted the derelict ship, known by the local STALKER's  as Skadovsk, in the distance. A wave of hope passed over me. The Zone was cruel, unforgiving, and merciless. With the sky growing darker every second, the tension and anxiety building up, I made the final sprint to the Skadovsk. It was difficult to see at this point, with only the silhouettes of dead trees and abandoned machinery to guide my way. My flashlight had ran out of battery, along with my PDA. Navigation was close to impossible. I could feel the Zone closing in, with the sounds of the unnatural creatures this unholy place has birthed echoing in the darkness. I may have a weapon - however, it was badly damaged, and my single magazine of ammunition wouldn't do me much good, as my gun was unreliable and often jammed or malfunctioned. No prayer could change the fact that I was a walking meal for these creatures. Creatures, whose shimmering eyes you could see in the distance with no visible body, speeding across your vision. Whatever unnatural cloaking the Zone has given them, they could attack from any direction. I wasn't going to let them get that chance. The Skadvosk was near, now. I'm getting exhausted. I'm hungry. I'm thirsty. I had used my last bandage after getting shot by a bandit, if I wanted to survive, I had to get inside. Just as I approached the gaping hole in the hull of the ship, those piercing yellow eyes appeared in a cluster of dead grass. The eyes that followed me, watching me, waiting for me to slip up before it attacks. It was all I could see, the rest of the world was encompassed in a miserable darkness that could strike fear into a fearless man. Just as I had stepped inside the broken hull, sprinting with my last burst of stamina to the sealed door, ear-piercing shots were heard above me, along with the heart warming Russian insults being directed at the creature that was just hunting me. Stepping in the ship, closing the door behind me, I quickly unloaded my haul to Beard, the bartender and trader. The weight lifted from my shoulders, I purchased some Bread and Vodka with my newly acquired Rubles, and sat around the table, listening to my fellow STALKER's tell the tales of their own Misery.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												This game makes you want to buy a ticket to Ukraine and tour Pripyat.  It takes the core concepts of the original game and pushes them in a direction that allows you to have a little more fun while exploring the brutal representation of a real-life scarred patch of earth.The first game had a lot of elements of wanting to go somewhere, but the high radiation levels or heavy enemy resistance prevented it.  CoP opens up the world around you a little more and gives you some more room to do your own thing.There are little touches that help crank up the entertainment level as well.  One of my favorites is the randomly occuring "blowouts" that will almost always (without the appropriate inventory items) kill you if you can't find cover in time.  Some of the greatest moments in this game exist when in the middle of a vicious firefight, or at the final moments of a task that has you hurt and running low on supplies, and then a blowout starts rolling in.Get ready to feel like a badass.  Get ready to have moments where you're running for your life.  Get ready to drain hours of your life exploring the wastes.  Pripyat is calling.

content:
Posted: April 13
 Ahem, 'a nu cheeki breeki iv damke' That is all. Alrighty, to a more descriptive review.S.T.A.L.K.E.R is basically Ukrainian Fallout. Except it told Fallout to go ♥♥♥♥ itself and made itself incredibly challenging in comparison to Fallout which is as easy as pie. Because of this, S.T.A.L.K.E.R earned itself a seat in the 'Games that have 1/4 the recognition it deserved' category, most of the attention quite literally coming from people who saw the memes of this game online and thought to themselves 'SLAV! CHEEKI BREKI MEME 4 LIFE, IDI NAHUI BLAYT' and play it for themselves only to realise how good the S.T.A.L.K.E.R games are. Which is a real shame because it's constantly overshadowed by other games set primarily in the Russian Post-Nuclear Apocalypse (Metro 2033, etc) despite being a great game. If it weren't for memes, S.T.A.L.K.E.R would of been long forgotten in the eyes of the world and for once, I can thank memes for preserving such an amazing game.So, COP plays a lot like your typical Fallout game in some sense. Except no V.A.T.S, no convenient/easy fast travel, has emissions/blowouts, and has (at least in my opinion) a much more enticing world with a better atmosphere. There's a bunch more but it's take too long to go over them. COP has a combat-system incredibly similar to Arma, peaking out of cover with Q & E, aiming down sights and shooting at a bunch of enemies in a nice open-world setting. You're also unbelievably fragile in the harder difficulties which forces you into that 'play safe' mentality, not just to run out in the open and attempt to hipfire everybody to death. This makes combat rewarding and fun at the same time. Due to the open-worldness of COP, you always need to keep track of where you are headed and making sure you're fighting in the right areas.Fast-travelling in this game can be a ♥♥♥♥♥ for a few reasons. You always have to pay money to fast-travelThe only consistent fast-travel is between the 3 explorable regionsNPCs you approach won't always take you where you want to goOnly specific NPCs are able to fast-travel you to places, which you have to befriend by doing a variety of questsAnd because of all these, it actually feels so much more rewarding to just walk/run everywhere. Because it doesn't take awfully long to get anyway, the map is incredibly deceptive at first until you learn that you can probably run from one side of the map to the other in 10 minutes. Fast-travelling does come with its perks though, being able to narrowly avoid emissions and the ability to do quick artifact runs to make money in-game. The Stalker Games also have this thing that games like Fallout lack, 'Emissions' (also known as Blowouts). Basically a nuclear storm that occurs often every 2-3 days. Most of the time (if you're like me), you'll sleep through these Emissions while waiting for certain quests or for certain items to arrive from NPCs. However, when you aren't asleep and you're caught in an Emission, holy♥♥♥♥♥♥they can be so much fun. Screen shakes, audio becomes somewhat deafening. You have to put aside anything you're doing and find cover as soon as possible and wait there until the emissions ends. While this can be inconvenient, it keeps you on your toes, making sure you don't get yourself caught out in the open and be forced to run into a den of enemies in a giant ravine. These emissions add to how tense the atmosphere in the Zone (the area you're in) is.Stalker's atmosphere is also fantastic. Unbelievably fantastic. Enemies jump at you from left and right, most of them being a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to kill like the Controllers & Chimeras. Every fight with those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s could go south quickly and recounting to how the combat is in this game, it makes things so much more tense. Chimeras literally leap at you and tear your face off, meaning if you're in an enclosed space, you're screwed. Vice-versa for Controllers, always keeping their distance and forcing you out of stamina & forcing you to put your weapon away due to their psionic abilities (like mind-control crap). It's also an incredibly grim game to an extent, showing just how hopeless the place can be. Having allies in battle die at the drop of a dime, sometimes even before the mission starts. I had an experience where right before we were going to raid a container yard and save a guy, literally the entire squad died from a large pack of dogs and I had to do the entire mission by myself. While yes, this can seem unfair having all your comrades die before anything happens, keep in mind that something like that would probably happen if these games were 'Real life'.Anyway, round of applause to S.T.A.L.K.E.R: COP, had me binge the game because of how fun it was. Deserves much more attention then what it has right now. May the memes live on and continue to attract people to this game like wasps to a lantern. Also, ♥♥♥♥ing god-tier ending music, had be reflecting on my choices and made me want to replay to fix up everything I missed due to how depressing everything was

content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												Zaton, Misery.Walking. Watching the sun slowly rise, it could've been a scene from a thousand years ago- with no cars, no lights, no noise but the animals and wind through the trees.Human interference seemed so minute, I barely noticed the subtle gunfire in the background, the cracked and blistered road I walked across.Then suddenly-CRACK.Something small and fast whizzes past my head like a bee.No time to check.I hold shift and book it.There's a van nearby. Maybe two metres, maybe four.I make a line straight for it.CRACK.I hear the bullet thump into the road. A plume of dust floats past the van i'm hiding behind.I pull my gun out from it's holster.It's a 357 magnum revolver. Condition is terrible, and rust visibly coats the gun like fungus on a tree.Three shots. Better make them count.Pull the hammer back, ready to fire.I hold it steady, creeping my way to the edge of the van.I peak out the side. Slowly. Carefully. Don't make it obvious.Binoculars out.In front of me is a hill. Tall and green, with a thick layer of grass and foliage covering the top like mould.Something flashes in my eyes. Movement. I track it like a sniper.The grass is moving, alive like some unknown mutated creature of the zone.I look closer.Whoever it is, his outift blends in well with the greenery. He evidently hasn't noticed me yet, and he's moving down the hill no doubt for a better view.On his back is a long gun. Maybe a rifle, maybe a shotgun. It's metallic sheen stands out like a sore thumb amongst the natural hues surrounding it.I check my gun again. Yeah. Definitely just three shots.I wait.He reaches the edge of the hill. Cautious. Careful.Starts running.Not close enough yet.As soon as he goes past the van, that's when I'll start moving.From over his shoulder he reveals his gun to be a shotgun. The long barrelled 'over-under' type.It'd be deadly if I give him the chance to use it.His aproach is swift, not wanting to be caught out in the open road, completely disregarding the van I could be hiding behind.Now.I slowly creep to the back of the van.Small, miniscule steps mark my way as I go, gun aimed with an intense trigger finger.It finally centres over his head.I stand up.Calmly walk out into the road. Gun still trained on his head.I wait until he notices something. The subtle echo of footsteps, or just good situational awareness, he eventually hazards a look behind him."ANNU CHEEKI BREEKI IVV DAMKE," I scream in real life, as I hit mouse1.The gun jerks back as a plume of smoke appears at the front end of the barrel, and my vision goes hazy at the edges for a moment.Then it happens again. Then again. What? What the hell is happening? The same sounds, the same bullet sound, over and over again until - "X-ray engine has stopped working. Windows is trying to find a solution to the problem,"10/10 Would have the game crash on me again.

A Paladin's Review: S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Call of Pripyat. A Polished Yet Stark Post Apocalyptic World.Genre: FPS RPG Post-Apocalyptic Horror Open World.Developed and Published by: GSC Game WorldPlatform: Windows Only. Business Model: Base Game. Copy Purchased by Myself Read the full & unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]Overall Gameplay ThoughtsIf Shadow of Chernobyl was the wild west of the STALKER universe, Call of Pripyat is the "civilized" entry into the series. My immediate impression of the game is that it's much more polished, with refined mechanics and a much more stable world to explore. Its clear that the developers didn't want another buggy Shadow of Chernobyl again. However, there were trade-offs with this approach. Unlike the creepy and danger-around-every-corner feeling that SoC gives you, CoP comes off as a more stark and alien. As if this wasn't Earth anymore. The "living world" that was present in SoC is much more subdued and scaled back in CoP and some mechanics were removed to my disappointment. Despite my disappointments, they didn't overshadow the sheer fun surviving in the Zone. After all, what could possibly be more enjoyable than listening to glorious Russian accents, finding strange anomalies and surviving the mutants of the Exclusion Zone. Combat ThoughtsThe game is more complete, better balanced and more variety of weapons no doubt thanks to its focused development cycle. You can also modify your suits and weapons this time around was also a nice change, allowing for a much more RPG-like experience. My favorite gun had to be the railgun you picked up in the later part of the game, the sound from firing it was just too cool. Overall, weapons feel very well balanced and have their own pros, cons and punch to each weapon. Ammo is still pretty limited but there are more merchants to buy from so it's not terribly difficult to keep a good supply on hand. Everything is suitably deadly, requiring you to keep on your toes the entire time. Exploration ThoughtsExploration in this game is better and more rewarding. There are plenty of interesting areas to look around, people to meet and creepy as heck underground structures to freak out in. I noticed more of the exploration took place out in the zone more than in underground facilities unlike SoC which had several notable X Labs to explore. That being said, there's still a creepy lab or two to get creeped out in. Atmosphere and the WorldIf there is something to be disappointed about, its the reduction of mechanics from the previous entry. Gone is how epic the A-Life engine felt when creatures roamed the lands and danger was around every possible corner. That sense of risk evaporated. In SoC, you could come across battles going on or the aftermath. Also gone are the risks to the NPCs, the zone changing around you on a regular basis with every emission. Any important quest giver won't be killed this time around which I felt was a damn shame. Gone is that sense of continual change that SoC had. In SoC, factions fought each other over land and constant conflicts. When certain events, those factions took advantage of the craze to get into all-out warfare. The Zone feels static now, not as unpredictable as it used to be. It stays put for the majority of the main story. Instead, it goes for more mechanical purity and straightforward experience. I can't blame them for going that route and I'm certainly not going to complain about it being a lot less buggy than CoP. However, I do wish they had taken the A-Life engine to a whole new level rather than step back. PC Settings & ModdingCoP is largely clean of bugs in its vanilla state so modding isn't as required as it was in SoC though there is some. The expected PC settings are mostly here though you have to do some modding to open up Field of View options, V-sync and borderless windowed mode. You can find more about that on PCGamingWiki[pcgamingwiki.com]. In game you have a selection of resolution options, quality options, full screen on/off and sliders for gamma, contrast and brightness. Advanced options include vision distance, object detail, texture detail, anisotropic filtering, antialiasing, grass detail density, lighting distance, and shadow quality sliders. In fact, there's almost nothing you can't tweak and change in the advanced graphics options. Everything from SSAO modes to volumetric light to NPC flashlights, there's a crazy amount of choices to optimize your experience. CoP is the best optimized game of the lot too so your computer shouldn't have too much trouble running it. There's only two audio sliders this time around for SFX and music which is a bit limited. Key rebinding and secondary keys are also supported. Final ThoughtsThe S.T.A.L.K.E.R. remains one of the most memorable series I've had the chance to play. The journey has been exciting, terrifying and challenging all at the same time. Call of Pripyat is the least buggy and better overall game of the series. But, I feel it loses that sense of risk that Shadow of Chernobyl took, instead going for a more standard open world experience. It's still incredibly compelling compared to most open worlds though. I still want to return to the Zone again and tackle it again. Which is pretty rare for me to want to do with most open world games. What can I say, it's a unique series. Its tragic that the development studio closed its doors. While GSC has been rumored to return, I'm doubtful that we will see another STALKER game again. I definitely recommend this game if you're into the FPS, RPG and post-Apocalyptic type titles such as these. Despite all of its flaws and quirks, the experience is well worth taking head-on.Read this review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]A Paladin's Review: S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl

content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												An absolutely amazing game with an incredibly oppressive and bleak atmosphere. Following the Chernobyl catastrophe, there was another explosion in the Chernobyl exclusion zone, an explosion that left the surrounding environment altered in ways that defy scienfitic explanation. The area is now filled to the brim with deadly physics defying anomalies, countless pockets of radiation and incredibly lethal mutants. The area is simply referred to as "The Zone". Those that explore the zone, in search of valuable artifacts spawned from the mysterious anomalies, are called Stalkers. You are one of them. Or rather, you pose as one. You are in fact a Ukranian army major, covertly entering the zone to investigate a lost helicopter squadron sent in to conduct reconnaissance in the zone. To accomplish your mission, you need to make allies with other stalkers and with their aid make your way towards the city of Pripyat and find out what exactly happened to the helicopters and their crews. Of course, there's also hostile humans to contend with, ranging from bandits, brain fried zombies (Still capable of using their guns) and foreign mercenaries. You also have some degree of choice in which faction to align yourself with and every side mission you complete (Or don't) have an impact on the epilogue endings of the game. It is very much worth it to complete every side mission, for that reason but also because a lot of the best moments in the game happen during them. The game is very survival focused, with a large emphasis on resource and inventory management. It also has a hunger mechanic, which adds flavor without in any way becoming overbearing. There's a real time passage of time (At a factor of 1 minute per 3 seconds or so), various weather conditions and there's also recurring "Emissions", which are essentially storms that turn the entire world red and fry your brain unless you take cover inside a solid structure. There's quite a lot of weapons and armors to acquire and many ways to upgrade them to improve your survivability. You can also equip artifacts to boost various attributes, like improved healing rate, increased endurance or resistance against radiation. I personally find that the equipment progression curve is a bit uneven, with the player finding equipment early on that's good to stick with nearly all the way to the end game. The feeling of being outmatched and outgunned, which was prevalent for a large part of the first two games, is much rarer in this installment. That's not to say that the game is easy, because it certainly isn't. Later in the game, you very much want to stick to the biggest guns you've got and bring as much armor piercing ammunition as you can. But it lacks the initial desperation, trying to scrounge for decent gear, which made the beginning of the first two games so frustrating, but also exciting. This also has the effect of making pistols somewhat useless, which is a shame, because there is quite a few of them. But, as far as the story is concerned, it makes sense to not have terrible equipment from the outset. This is still the best installment in the series, due to it's gameplay refinements and focus on a handful of large open areas rather than multiple smaller maps. I do however think the environment design of the first game is superior, but it's entirely possible that that is simply nostalgia speaking. I just felt that each area in the first game introduced something new, while the 3 large areas of Call of Prypyat feel a bit more sparse and predictable. I do miss the beginners area of the Cordon (Rookie Village, Railway Bridge), the claustrophobic streets. alleys and railways of the Wild Territory (Exploring this in a thunderstorm is amazing), the absolutely terrifying Bloodsucker village and the city of Pripyat itself (And the locations you find there).Really, what I'm saying is play all of them.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												The sequel to Shadow of Chernobyl, Call of Pripyat does an excellent job of adding to the previous game's mechanics and making it a smoother experience.  Issues from Shadow of Chernobyl such as item repair are now included without needing mods and other aspects are changed such as artifact hunting and a degree of neutrality with other factions (such as mercenaries and bandits).  The game is perhaps more open world than SoC and the side quests are much more intuitive.   Most importantly, the game retains much of its original atmosphere and you'll continue to explore the decaying wastelands of the Exclusion Zone.With that said, the game does have some weaknesses.  While it retains that atmosphere that made SoC great, it also (disappointingly) leaves you cut off from much of its namesake town of Pripyat.  Regions you once explored in SoC such as the hotel, government building and the park with its iconic Ferris wheel are now only seen in the distance behind fences.  The buildings you explore instead seem sparser and more linear.  Likewise, human opponents are pretty thin in the game and most of your fighting will be against mutants.  Sure, you CAN just start shooting people on sight but the different factions and uncertain nature of SoC felt much more exhilarating to me and winning against 'human' opponents just felt more gratifying than shooting umpteen mutant dogs and pigs.  Finally, the ending felt rushed to me and less epic than the original breech into the forbidden CNPP.Even with all that, Call of Pripyat still felt like a worthy successor to Shadow of Chernobyl.  I would definitely recommend that someone new to the series play SoC first but Call of Pripyat will be a satisfying way to remain in the mysterious world of the Exclusion Zone a while longer.  Call of Pripyat played well 'vanilla' without requiring mods (which is more than you can say for the buggy SoC) but there are multiple well crafted mods to dramatically change the world and keep things interesting for a long time to come.  Shadow of Chernobyl was a tough act to follow and Call of Pripyat made it most of the way there; a recommended purchase in my book.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
												A typical day as a STALKER:I wake up as day breaks on an old ship we STALKERs use as a makeshift base.  I check my gear for the day; one pump-action shotgun for the mutants, and a rifle in case one of my own decides he wants my gear.  I make sure I have enough food for the day, drugs in case some form of radiation decides to run rampant through my body, a few medkits and bandages, and my artifact detector.  I decide its a perfect day for artifact hunting.  As I step out the ship, I hear gun shots to the north, my intended direction.  F*** that, I'll go somewhere else.  On my way to the first anomaly, I suddenly hear shrieks and the sound of ruffled bushes.  As I turn toward that direction, a snork leaps its way toward me, claws ready to dig straight through my throat.  Luckily I had my shotgun out, and I was quicker than him.  As my slugs blow off his face, another one follows, but I make short work of him too.  Unharmed and feeling confident, I continue to the anomaly.  Before I'm even halfway there, a fight breaks out between a group of stalkers and bandits.  I lay in wait, hoping the two groups wipe each other out.  Suddenly the bandits have an overwhelming advantage.  Then I'm spotted.  My rifle fires into the head of the first two, but I'm not so lucky with the third.  His bullets clip my side.  I quickly bandage them up to stop the bleeding, pop out of cover and fire, exploding his head.  I use my medkit to heal everything up, and a few minutes later I'm back on track.Or so i thought.  Out stomps a god damn psuedogiant, as large as a frickin SUV.  As I'm running, I see a group of stalkers and head in there direction.  They see the situation, and begin to fire into the giant, as do I.  But it's not enough.  The thing destroys these three stalkers, but while he was distracted, I managaed to lay a few grenades under him, and finish him off with the shotgun.  It's nearing night, and stalkers know thats when more of these mutants come out, and not just the ones I've seen.  I'm frightened I'll run into a buror, or a controller.  Not to mention the horde of wild dogs hungry enough to sink their teeth into any form of flesh.  I'm make my way back to the old ship. What was I out here for again?

												Okay you little casual, listen here and listen here good.S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is not your average 'Pew pew shooter'.  You need to realize this right here, right now.S.T.A.L.K.E.R. will ♥♥♥♥ you up. If you think playing Dark Souls or ArmA  prepares you for this game then I'm sorry for you.In S.T.A.L.K.E.R. you will be thrown into The Zone (some people call it Hell and they have their reasons)  and you will be given an objective. Simple as that.  No tutorial, not any big baby hand-holding cutscene and no magic armor that defends you from everything. You are literally one of the most useless things walking around in The Zone and of course the NPCs will treat you like one.  They will try to steal from you, kill you and even ask you if you want to die fast or slowly.  'Make your choice'.What can you do to avoid that? Nothing. It will happen sooner or later because as I said you are the most useless thing in the game.  You will die at least 5 times within the first hour and if you are a dirty casual, you will abandon the game.If you want to master this game though, you will continue playing and every time the game beats you up like you were a bag of trash.So here are two tips from  an experienced player such as myself:Tip #1 Take your ♥♥♥♥ing time, idiot.    You do not kill everything you see, because you can't.  You have a better chance waiting for your "friendly" NPCs to kill each other and then go loot their bodies because that's all you can do at the start of the game.   You are pathetic.So after you get some nice loot, go sell it in Skadovsk. You do not know what Skadovsk is? Then open the ♥♥♥♥ing wiki and see for yourself. That's how you will play this game from now on. You will learn things from the damn wiki because it's the only place that explains things. Tip #2Do not go outside during night. I did once, and to this date I still wake up in the middle of the night from the nightmares.  Don't go outside during night, ♥♥♥♥nut.Overall score:10/10. And if someone gives it lower than 10,  he is a rookie and Vodka is too strong for him.

Posted: October 7, 2014
												Frankly, I loved this game ... as is probably apparent by the "hours on record".  I've always liked the weapon physics in the Stalker series.  Its a bit tougher to be accurate whether ADS or from the hip.  And some of the creature noises just make my hair follicles bristle.  Some creepy stuff, but not so intensely as to be truly horrific (imo).  Stupid snorks!  I felt engaged in the story, driven to "save" (for instance) all my squad when going through the tunnels to Pripyat.  Losing one of them was unacceptable.  Trading with the good guy, "Beard" instead of "Owl" whenever possible ... and always dissing "Sultan's" team of bandits.I'd really recommend playing the game a second time 'round with a different weapon setup.  Get clever with saves so as to purchase the special weaps and armour from "Nimble" that you'd favour.Then play again on the "Misery" mod.  Despite having played CoP at least 4 times through --yes I've lost count-- trying "Misery" mod was enjoyable because of the difficulty.I wonder where the dev team is now ... ?  I thought they were working on another post-apocalyptic adventure for me! ... a loyal supporter of the franchise.  :D

content:
Posted: January 5
												Before I get into the details, I'll have you know that I've only played this with Misery Mod... a massive overhaul mod tweaking the game to be harsher with bartering, adding dynamic weather, more weapons, the need to eat and sleep, the removal of food healing and adding real time eating and bandaging of which both take around 5 - 10 seconds, new mutants and not to mention this locks the game difficulty to the hardest setting.Do not expect the following:1. Regenerating health2. Bullet sponges (except for chimeras, which are the STALKER equivalent to deathclaws, and they almost always 1 shot you)3. Cinematic cutscenes4. A levelling up system5. Being a pack mule (you CAN carry up to 3x the "weight limit" shown, but you will also lose stamina quicker and get hungry quicker)Now the reason I recommend this is quite simple.... Never before have I played a game that contains all the following at once....1. The player characte being in need of sleep so badly that their head would shake while yawning, trying to line up a shot, all the while with hazey vision...2. Situations with 2-4 bandits with basic rifles being a threat to the player character even in newly purchased grade 3-4 armor (there are 5 grades of armor, 5 being the highest)3. 												I cannot recommend this game enough, as it's one of the few open world games that captures a truly "living" world. That is, a living world that can, and will, probably kill you. Alot. But more importantly, especially with the MISERY mod, the Zone feels like the type of place that will go on with or without you. You aren't some superpowered hero, you're an underfunded schmuck with scavenged gear and a job to do. Given the setting of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series, it shouldn't be any other way.Verdict: Definitely give it a shot. And then install MISERY, and give it another 4 or 5.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												I love the STALKER games; they have an interesting setting and story, post-apocalyptic feel, interesting open areas to explore, lots of unscripted yet interesting encounters, horror elements, authentic industrial environments, and refreshingly unforgiving FPS gameplay.Call of Pripyat is definitely the least buggy and most polished of the series. Extremely compelling, fun to explore, and just plain awesome. Also, many of the game's locations are very close to real-life locations in the zone, and they look impressively authentic when you compare photos to screenshots (which I absolutely love).There are less side quests, but they are individually larger, more interesting, and better thought out than all the mini-side-quests in STALKER: SoC. The interface is also much improved from previous STALKERs, highlighting matching ammo when you mouse over a gun, for example. There aren't as many stashes, but the stashes in CoP can be found without knowing where they are beforehand. Artifact rarity is handled the best in CoP, compared to SoC (too plentiful and easy to get) and Clear Sky (nearly impossible to get). Emissions and equipment upgrades are the best in the series here, as well.The story of CoP is very loose, to let you do whatever you want in whatever order you want, though it's not nearly as good as the story of the original SoC. The game's ending is similar in style to that of Fallout, where it shows you short clips about people and places in the game, telling you what happens to them afterwards. I felt like it was an epic and satisfying end to the trilogy. Ironically, though, the Pripyat area of the game was the worst in terms of well-thought-out-edness in story, dialogue, and missions/quests. Pripyat is, on the other hand, really awesome because the entire area is closely moddled after the Eastern section of real-life Pripyat, with the only major difference being that a service center building is in the game where a kindergarten building is in real life (that, and all the impassible "video game fences" around the edges of the in-game area).There is a very active modding community for the game, as well. My favorite mod for Call of Pripyat is 'SGM', which adds a ton of content and improves the graphics.Awesome game. highly recommended if you like survival FPS games.

Posted: October 7, 2016
												An excellent game.The story is a bit light compared to the first Stalker (Shadow of Chernobyl).The ending was a bit disappointing. I finally got all of the godly equipment and I didn't even get a chance to use it to the fullest extent. Still, this game was pretty good.When you start out, you're going to be an absolutely garbage fighter. What you need to do is get:1) Strelok's Gun with scope and silencer in Yanov.2) Free Military Gear from Pripyat from the Army armorer.3) Find and give all upgrading tools to a technician and upgrade all your equipment for maximum durability and accuracy.4) Find and equip the Oasis and Bubble Artifacts.5) Get the best detector by trading in 3 Veles Delectors to the guy in the Science Bunker at Yanov.If you are poor, go to an anomaly zone with your detector out (Press O to pull it out), find some artifacts and sell it. You will become rich very quickly. Another way to get money is to sell medical kits and anti-radiation syringes that you'll find off of dead bodies. Everytime you go to Pripyat, bring some broken guns and have them repaired for free, and then whenever you go back to Yanov, sell those guns. This should easily cover the expensive round trip.This game is like a Russian rags-to-riches simulator.Cheeki Breeki/10

Perhap's the most polished of them all, with a heck load of improvement's and solidness from the u-i to the gameplay.Gameplay+ Spot-on atmosphere.+ Option to free-play at end.+ Combat is once again twicthy but solid.+ Many new item's, medicine's and lil weapon's.+ Improved hud & perhap's the best of them all.+ Reward's really feel like reward's & have better loot.+ Weapon's now really feel like weapon's & they hit.+ Mini-map and world-map has once again been polished on.+ A.i has been improved in many aspect's & doesn't bug so often.+ Side-quest's have been very improved & made upon interesting.+ Wearable's most better here due to option's of removing helmate's,more upgrade's.+ Reputation system, you can side between 2 faction's which differ to different consequences.- Game can be very-easy at the lowest-difficulty.- Artifect's can make up for easier farming as they respawn upon every emmision.Story+ Multiple ending's.+ Each mission is set at a great pace & balance.+ Just same old scary at time's but more better pacing.+ Over-all story is more interesting as it's from a different angle.- Cutscenc's are pretty sucky.Design ( Graphic's ) Included+ Many improved-animation's.+ Lighting improved on many aspect's.+ Improved & responsive u-i and interface.+ Finely-optimized can run on low-end rig's.+ Over all area's are more better looking & planned.+ Menu & the whole atmosphere is even more spot-on here.+ All item's have nice-quality picture's as well more information.+ All model's have been improved same for all the over-all aspect's.- Many micro-stutter's in between.Sounds( + OST )+ Sound's from enviromental to gun's are simply so pleasing.+ Strange random sound's really add immersion.+ Music is good-on & just fine.- Voice acting is one of the more worser & purely laughable.ConclusionMany improvement's & a feeling of being in a different zone, a whole-world of polishness & enjoyment is available here.===================================================================Click me and follow us as Curator

content:
Posted: January 21
What I Like About This Game1.The Zone is the most terrifying place to visit in any gaming department2.Players  would be hard pressed to describe something so bleak and unforgiving3.New level of textures/lighting4.Fantastic sense of place5.Lots of tense exploration6.Numerous improvements over the previous games7.Some cool new enemies to take on8.Still charming despite it's flaws9.Great NPC interactions10.Better side jobsWhat I Hate About This Game1.Some recycled props, but no where near as many as Shadow Of Chernobyl2.Ever present "stutter" is still here when entering a spawn area for the first time3.Still taxing on older systems despite the leaps forward in stability and polish4.The story takes too long to get interesting5.Pripyat isn't as interesting as the surrounding wastes6.Eating mechanic is tedious7.Supplies are too available8.Predictable encountersThough it's not quite as surprising as the original, it's still a standout game that deserves to be given a chance by anyone That Follow The Series. There aren't many titles able to offer up such an affecting atmosphere mixed with enjoyable mechanics, and even if some bits of the game remain uneven, it's an experience that will stick with you long after it's over. Although i must say even this game still give me a heart pumping when playing, you do not know how you end up dying either by nature or killed by mobs. The enemy is still a bullet sponge and still hard to kill.even an enemy with shotgun can headshot you from long distance and not to say you die easily. Side quest is a must do for you to get better gears in order to survive this nuclear wasteland. Overall it is a mustplay FPS game with much to offer.(Note:You Will Bleed to death in this game unless you do not have bandage to stop the bleeding. There is no such thing as Heath Regen in this game and enemies is really insane in the damage department from the early game you start playing.)

content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												I've played through this game 3 times now and this game gets better every single time i play it.  The first two were on normal and the hardest difficulty but that just wasnt enough for me so i went and installed the MISERY mod to get the real ball busting experience.How does one describe the greatest game ever made? is it the story? the world building? the game mechanics? the difficulty and responsibilities the game gives you to manage? the innumerable ways to play the game?  For all of those questions i would tell you to look no further than the Stalker franchise.  If ever a game was to be the flag ship of PC gaming THIS is the game that people should look at in reverence and awe.  Games of today hold your hand, coddle you and all but tube feed you because they dont trust you to anything intelligent  with their property....no mods, tutorials for everything and a streamlined experience so that nobody strays too far from the course like some sort of amusement park ride.  The Stalker games fly in the face of all of that and rewards you for being different and when everything that can go wrong does...finding your own way to survive in the Zone.  Finding secret stashes, managing your limited resources,  risking your life in Anomolies (elemental effects like acid, fire, wind and the like) and doing perilous quests that arent for the foolhardy.  You arent John Rambo and you dont run around with a fully automatic LMG shooting wildly like in most modern games. This game cements my love and facination with the true Survival Horror games like the original Resident Evil series before they started taking steroids. You are just one man with fear in his heart, a deathgrip on your ♥♥♥♥♥♥ beaten up shotgun, a dream of seeing a rusted ship you call home and only a fistfull of shotgun shells to guide your way back in pitch black darkness.This game is the most liberating feeling knowing that your life is in your hands and at any moment a mutant could two shot you from behind.....you live by the ability to stay level headed and just how many rounds you have left in your gun(s).   This game is my pride and joy please at least try playing it its well worth $20.See you in the Zone, Stalker...

												This game is a gem, seriously, It's really great.The atmosphere is simply awesome,A game that is not in the United States.The night is mostly realistic and beautiful.Emisions are just so great.The guns are great to use.You need to eat to stay alive.The radiations and the environment (emission, radiations, etc etc...) will kill you if you are not carefulThis series is really great, really, and the mods make them even better.I could say a lot about the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. franchise but there is just too much to say, the game itself is awesome.I'm also a fan of every Fallout games but Bethesda should really take some ideas from them especially in questions of realism.It's not the greatest game in terms of open world but you probably won't even notice because of the game being so awesome.Do I have to say that the thunder looks real great in this game? I'd suggest this game to anyone who likes open world, post-apocalyptic, FPS, atmospheric, survival, horror, challenging  and semi-realistic games.If you haven't played the previous S.T.A.L.K.E.R. then I would suggest you to play them, It's a real great series, you won't be disappointed.9.5/10 for the whole S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series in general.Only thing that sucks is that we can't make all the characters in the game speak in Ukrainian and It's the same for all the S.T.A.K.E.R. games, when I play a game, I'd love when the characters speak in their language for a question of immersion.My personal list of recommended mods for Call of Pripyat: MISERY + The Armed ZoneCall of Chernobyl + Arsenal Overhaul or STCoP Weapon Pack (I personally play with both, different folder for Arsenal Overhaul and another one for STCoP)Arsenal OverhaulPripyat RebornThere are some small mods that you can find on Russian sites which adds weapon packs, and those are really great.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												This is the best in the series, IMO and one of my favorite games. Was made by the talented developers at GSC Game World, which later became the 4A games that made the fantastic Metro series. This game's great and even better with mods( which you can find at moddb). This is a MUST have for anyone interested in post-apoc FPS games.For new players:- Takes a while to figure out and get into, but you won't put it down when you do, so be patient.-During emmisions(storms), there will be a yellow arrow or maker on the map indicating a safe place for you to hide until it passes.-Some get confused about what you should be doing, but it's to check helicopter crash sites and see what went wrong. You can get more information about how to get to them, by asking other NPCs and the locations are marked on your GPS.- Starting weapons feel inaccurate and underpowered to me, so I suggest youtubing "STALKER Call of Pripyat secrets" to find where the hidden stashes are for a decent early weapon with a scope.-Start on vetern difficulty. You can change it later in-game if you think it's too hard.-For mods; I'd suggest atmosfear, absolute nature and absolute structures, which all make the game look gorgeous, but keep a pretty vanilla experience. Check out Misery after you beat it, because it's much harder and a major overhaul changing most of the game.-If you play without mods, try increasing the contrast in settings to the max, because it makes the game look much better.10/10 - We need a redux version of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games.

number of helpful: 28 of 30 people (93%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
												The STALKER series was, is, and will always be one of the most beautiful and interesting game series ever created. At first glance, it is "just" a single-player first person shooter game, albeit a good one, which includes elements of survival horror. It takes place in the Zone of Alienation (the area in and around the Chernobyl Nuclear Reactor in Ukraine, which was the site of one of the world's most shocking nuclear disasters in history.) However, in the fictitious game world of STALKER, this "Zone" is home to much worse than radiation and wild animals.In STALKER, the zone is a place where the very fabric of reality starts to break down. Strange mutants with unexplained psychic abilities and deadly "anomalies" (Areas where the laws of physics simply do not apply, leading to the creation of highly valuable artifacts) pose a unique threat to the player that makes for interesting gameplay, while the threat of encountering a group of human enemies makes simply walking around from place to place feel tense.The STALKER series is one of the very few games that manages to pull of one of the greatest feats of game design in all of history: It makes you question every decision you make. Every step could be your last. The game's level design is impeccable, based on the real Zone of Alienation. The audio design and color palette make the environment feel oppressive but beautiful in a sad way. The combat is gritty and difficult, and you will need to develop new tactics to defeat some of the more powerful mutants or large groups of human enemies. The game also has a big focus on exploration and elements of survival which fit seamlessly into gameplay. The game's lore is rich and there are many mysteries to solve. The modding community is strong, and there is an ever-present player base. The game has aged well.It is always a worry of mine that games based of of real life events (especially tragedies) will dilute the importance or impact of those events, but the STALKER games approach the real-life Chernobyl disaster with maturity and respect. In fact, the game has probably done nothing other than make more people interested in learning about the disaster that took place.All in all, STALKER has a special place in the hearts of many-including my own-and with good reason.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
												Note: played these on discs for years, have just bought Steam copies as there is some compatibility issue with the original DRM and win10/skylake. . . The main problem with this and Shadow of Chernobyl, were that they were so profoundly good that no FPS has ever really lived up to the potential of these games. SOC remains my favourite of the three, but this is a close second. There aren't many games this old that I still play (Supreme Commander is probably the only one; and the STALKER series is the only old shooter I play). And I can't think of a game that does gun ballistics better, or has more satisfying shooting mechanics.  And ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ there are some tense moments, even when you know what's coming. . . I would recommend playing with the Stalker Complete Mods (made in 2011, download from ModDB) for a first play through as they improve the graphics somewhat and fix most bugs, without changing much gameplay-wise. Only consider Misery or AA for subsequent playthroughs if you are up for a serious challenge. Hope you enjoy this as much as I have.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Last instalment in S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series of games.Game set in perviously unused locations in the Zone, with exception of part of town of Pripyat.You play as Major Degtyarev, member of Ukrainian Special Forces, sent to the Zone to investigate mysterious crash of army helicopters sent to try and capture Wishgranter.Gameplay is much less linear than in pervious Stalker games, but on other hand, game does not guide you by hand like in never titles, so it is sometimes easy to get lost or lose sense of what to do next.Although game is (relatively) old, graphics are still very much presentable, and for example, in some instances game looks much better than say, Fallout 4. When you introduce various mods into it (yes, game is fully moddable, with huge depositories online for various improvements and/or changes), game simply looks amazing.Although gameplay seems a bit more simplified than in pervious games, most of it is same. Shooting and ballistics play huge role in game, as well as weapon condition/ammunition types, so give it time to get used to it.Stalker series of games always had very ''eastern slavic'' feel to them, simply because authors of game are from Eastern Europe, and are very good at translating look and feel of post-communism decay and changes. Abandoned towns, villages, factories, overgrown roads, roaming wild animals, frequent weather changes, indescribable horrors and mutants, bandits and stalkers await all who enter the Zone. But, once you are in, you will not want to leave.

Especially if you aren't so good with horror type games (Like me)The combat, especially against mutated creatures certainly gives me the feeling of "Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ I am going to die if I make a mistake" unless of course you play on a lower difficulty; however a game like this is meant to be difficult and punishing to mistakes. It's meant to resemble a harsh world filled with creatures and people that wants to tear you apart, eat you or just blow your brains out and steal your stuff. It's also one of the only games that I actually enjoy doing the side missions on. Hell, it's necessary too in order to gain better gear, but it doesn't feel like it, they don't feel tedious.As I said before, definitely worth a buy.CHEEKI BREEKI

CoP & Misery Mod (2.1.1) ReviewThird installment in the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series and probably the most polished one in terms of atmosphere, gameplay & optimization. While Vanilla is fine as it is and probably what most would choose to play, Misery totally changes the difficulty bringing a complete overhaul to the Zone. You will have to think through every single of your move; strategy is your number one priority every step in the unknown can as well be your last. Realism is what Misery aimed at and successfully manage to hit a peak with very few features lacking due to engine limitations. If you're not a seasoned hardcore type of player that enjoys suffering mashing the load save hotkey you should avoid a first playthrough with Misery which recreates the Zone into a much crueler and starving enviroment.[✔]> npc interaction> meaningful difficulty slider> gear customization> realistic weapon ballistics> mechanic requires vodka to fulfil your requests (XD)[✘]> awkward mutant animations (probably limited due to X-Ray engine)> stealth combat lacking (AI sometimes telepathically knows if you killed their comrade)> can't purchase tracksuit as outfit (XD)Howdy ho, what are you waiting for? Get out of here S.T.A.L.K.E.R. & cheeki breeki.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
Here's to a Good Day's Work.S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Call of Pripyat = Fallout + Deus Ex + UkrainiansI know I'm rather late to this radioactive party, but I've finally revisted the Zone.For those not in the know, Stalker is an FPS dystopic horror that is known for its open world exploration, scary mutants, and almost-RPG aspects.  This is the logical sequel to the first game, Shadow of Chernobyl, but you don't really need to have played the first to enjoy this one.Call of Pripyat is set in a post-Chernobyl disaster area, the Exclusion Zone or just "The Zone".  Although it's forbidden for anyone to enter, fortune-seeking scavengers known as "Stalkers" regularly find their way in to this cess pool of rust, mutants, and otherwordly death-traps known as "Anomolies".  They do this mostly to dig up "Artifacts", strange new types of matter that display all manner of bizarre and potentially useful phenomenon, which fetch a high price in the scientific, black, and black scientific markets.The gameplay mechanics are a good blend of open-world scavenger hunts and solid shooter mechanics.  There are a wide variety of traditional weapons to use that often feature multiple ammo types, fire modes, and optional attachments.  One would think that with new Artifact-based tech, you might find more exotic weapons as well, but other than a slight exception toward the end-game, you won't find any gravity guns or psy-grenades here.I say that this game is an almost-RPG simply due to the fact that, despite not having attributes or XP points, there is still a "grind" flow to the gameplay and a sort of character progression through acquiring gear, artifacts, and equipment upgrades.There is a main mission to follow, which I found mostly uninspired, and a few side missions, which I found much more intriguing.  However, most of your time will be spent simply heading out to points of interests to dig up artifacts and scavenge useful or valuable items from the dead.  Then you will head back to safety when you need to take shelter from the intermittent deadly storms called "Emissions" and/or to sell your loot.  Rinse, repeat.  Fortunately, the game is full of interesting environments, fun shooting mechanics, and a variety of enemies that use a lot of different tactics and abilities to kill you.Enter the Zone if you... Played and enjoyed the first game.  Although I feel CoP lacks the scope, mystery, and even some of the scariness of the original, this is offset by better mechanics and overall polish.  Both are great and if you enjoy one you will likely want to play the other. Love post-apocalyptic themes and environments.  CoP is full of bizarre mutants, rusted out ruins, and unearthly anomaly areas. Like yourself a good open-world shooter.  This is one of the shining stars of the genre.Head back to the Cordon if you... Prefer on-rails, level-based shooter gameplay.  Stalker requires a far more methodical approach if you want to avoid getting killed over and over. Hate "gritty" settings.  For all the sci-fi of the Anomalies, mutants, and artifacts, the Zone is otherwise a bleak landscape of swamps, crumbled concrete, and rust.  I think it is beautiful in it's own way, but I know it's not everyone's cup of Dogolov. Want more RPG mechanics.  Stalker is definitely a shooter first before anything else.  It is no Borderlands, for example.The Bottom LineAs a fan of the original, I loved this game and in my first run through I racked up about 60 hours.  I found that most of this time was spent hoarding gear and supplies I'd never really use, however.  Where some missions were rather difficult (such as getting through the tunnel to Pripyat without losing anyone), I found that the endgame seemed almost an afterthought.  There was little reason to explore most of the areas in Pripyat, with only a handful of missions actually requring that you do so.  With a complete arsenal of fully upgraded armor, kitted out weapons, and thousands upon thousands of rounds of the best ammo, I found finishing the last few missions an absolute breeze.  Although this was a bit of a let down, I still enjoyed the experience overall and enjoyed how the ending elaborated on the outcome of many of my choices througout the side-missions.:::!!!PROTIP PROTIP PROTIP!!!:::There are a couple of important mods for this game now-a-days.  At a minimum I'd suggest getting Call of Pripyat: Complete, which overhauls the graphics and makes other great changes to the base game while still keeping it mostly similar to the original experience.If you really want to ramp of the difficulty and immersion, there is also the Misery Mod, which puts an emphasis on harsh survival and is probably the most popular mod for the game.

												Call of Pripyat is the best game in the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series. This has the best main plot with a Fallout 3-style ending that changes depending on your actions in game. Very atmospheric with plenty of side quests that reward exploration and help flesh out the lore of the locations. Has a lot of depth with gun play and survival mechanics, requiring you to eat food while in the field and keep yourself bandaged up to avoid bleeding out. Call of Pripyat stands on its own feet and doesn't require any previous experience with the series; a must play for any FPS fans.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
												Im gonna skip the amazing graphics, sound, atmosphere and gameplay, and tell you the most important thing: this game has the best AI in any game to date. The developer was inspired by FEAR in terms of AI in battles: the enemies flank you, sneak up on you, take cover, give commands. But this is not just an FPS, it is also an RPG, and HOLY CRAP! if this aint the best RPG out there, then please let me know! Thus, the AI extends outside of combat. Monsters travel in packs and engage in fights with other monsters and humans for survival's sake. If the fight seems to be in their favor, they will engage, otherwise they will fall back and move along. Squads of stalkers patrol the Zone: sometimes to defend their base, sometimes to recapture a point. Sometimes it's just one greedy stalker trying to retrieve an artifact from an anomaly so that he can sell it later.And that's another thing about this game: artifacts and their anomaly counterparts. You see, this is the Zone. Radiation has chnaged many things, not just animals and humans. You will find these mini puzzles with an expensive artifact as a reward. Sometimes it's a timed electricity trap. Sometimes it's a gravitational anomaly that holds the ground and water up in the air in an unnatural fashion.Marketing is killing the gaming industry nowadays. Sales people push developers to improve on graphics and numbers: more DLC, more weapons, more maps, more more more. And it seems like everyone has forgotten the other ingredients that make a game good. Such as AI.If you haven't played this game yet, buy it now! I have spent most of my time playing STALKER: Clear Sky (cheaper), which puts more emphasis on factional warfare. But as far as I can tell, this one is just as good, if not better.

Then they disappeared out of thin air, leaving a horrendous odor that would've made a burning tire dump smell like a rose garden.To this day, I never leave safety without my anti-bloodsucker underwear.Alright seriously this is a good game, as many people before stated it's got a great atmosphere and sound along with original music. My most loved gem about Call of Pripyat is that it captured my imagination of how Pripyat is now. (Believe me I know it's not really a zone full of anomalies and mutants, but it's my imagination and muck off if you think having an active one is bad.)

content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												Where you around, or have you heard about the Chernobyl, Russia nuclear accident in 1986?This survival-horror/RPG/Shooter game is centered around the aftermath in a fictional timeline after those events.The Stalker series is considered one of the best modern survival games of the genre.Why? Because, when you are playing them you feel like you are in Chernobyl, Russia.You feel the fear, you see the greed of your fellow man, and you get to decide what type of man you really are.Are you one who takes advantage of hardships to make your life better, to the detriment of others?Or, are you the type who does what needs to be done to survive, but you also take the time to help your fellow man?Are you there to get rich off of rare resources and plunder whoever you can?Maybe you are there to show the world that even in the darkest times, humanity can be a beautiful thing?Find out these answers in the final installment of the STALKER series.It is recommended that you start with the first game in this series, S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl.The second game, Clear Sky did not get good reviews at release and many people suggest skipping it entirely as it is a prequel to the story of the first game.This is the final game in the STALKER series before the developers closed shop.There have been a few attempts to bring the STALKER series back, but as of 2016 that hasn't happened.The studio did re-open this year and released a remake of Cossacks 3 which received generally positive reviews.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												This game is literally the love of my life.Horrifying, radiation-riddled waifu/husbando.If you have a thing for slow(-ish) and methodical FPS, survival, horror, sci-fi, and post-apocalyptic scenes, you will not regret giving this game a try.You should keep in mind though, that this game (Call of Pripyat) takes place after the "main" events of the game. If you care for story (you kind of should, but it's not necessary to enjoy the game), you should play Shadow of Chernobyl first. It's older and the first game in the series but it's not worse in quality.Clear Sky is the second game in the series and a prequel to Shadow of Chernobyl. You can ignore it.I have probably around 300-500 hours total in the game, but I only recently (130 hours of gameplay) bought the game on Steam for ease of reinstall. (The game has a somewhat active modding scene.)The ONLY downside this game has is that it runs on a single thread on a single core, so the game stutters on almost all computers unless they have a very strong single-core/thread performance. (Hyperthreading or multi-core CPUs won't help.)

number of helpful: 13 of 14 people (93%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20
												This game is simply a masterpiece. I bought it when it was first released and have played through not only the vanilla game, but the most popular mods such as 'Complete 2009 mod' (which adds some extra flavour and gfx upgrades) and 'Misery mod' (which adds a LOT of extra flavour and turns it into the most brutal survival game in existence), and i am still playing it to this day.It is so atmospheric, this is the only game i have actually felt scared to enter certain areas, espcially in the dark! Everything about it is awesome and has some of the best lighting effects i have seen in a game to date.This is an absolute must buy in my opinion, its inexpensive and there is no excuse not to grab it! Sure it can have some performance issues with misery mod just due to its sheer scale, but these issues can easily be rectified with a quick google search and adjusting some mod settings such as Alife distances. I am running it at around 80-120 fps on my current rig, and while there does appear to be a minor memory leak after prolonged play sessions which will make you lose a few FPS, a quick restart of the game fixes this every time.One of my favourite games of all time, and there are new complete overhaul mods still being created to this day, making it worth a buy for sure. Just do it, you wont be disappointed.

number of helpful: 12 of 13 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												I have just sneaked into the Waste Processing Station, which is being used by mercenaries as their camp. I have to find a notebook containing their plans and then return to Owl with the intel.I am heavily outnumbered and outgunned. If I pick a fight with anyone, I'm dead. If I get spotted, I'm dead before I can get out the door, let alone the compound. Where is the notebook? Somewhere upstairs, I'm sure.It's so dark I can't see anything immediately around me but the handrail of the staircase silhouetted against the fading daylight from outside. I can't risk using my flashlight. Hugging the deep shadow against the wall, I crouch and move silently. There's the notebook! Got it! Now to get out.Can I sneak out the same way I sneaked in? I can. I pick up a jerry can of fuel as a bonus on the way out. Not a shot fired (and just as well because ammo is expensive). Who says stealth is dead? Not me! I stop to eat before starting back, just in case I need some energy to sprint for safety.I almost make it back to the Shadovsk when I'm ambushed by a pack of mutants charging from behind. Just Flesh, so easy to handle. Mission accomplished. I'll head back to  the WPS later when I'm better armed and can hold my own against the mercs: right now I need the money that intel will get me.No hand holding. No follow the NPC leader. No warnings of any kind of impending death. Just me and the Zone.I had heard the S.TA.L.K.E.R. series was solid (and was already a Metro 2033 fan) so I bought Call of Pripyat on sale but then it sat there in my Steam library, neglected while I played other newer games. And then I heard about the Misery Mod. It sounded hard. It sounded scary. It looked fantastic. Misery 2.1 is cruelty ratcheted up several notches to the level of sadomasochism.Run out of medkits? You die. Miss your headshot and don't duck back into cover fast enough? You die. Forget to pop an antiradiation pill? You watch your health slowly bleed out (and then you get into a firefight). It is just the most awesome, scary, thrilling and realistic gaming experience I've ever had.If you want to experience a game that is as brutal as if you were in the irradiated zone around Chernobyl in real life, Misery Mod 2.1.1 is it. UPDATE: Heading out from base, whether in Zaton, Jupiter or Pripyat, equipped and loaded for a day in the Zone of Alienation (I have now been freeplaying Misery as a Recon for hundreds of hours) not knowing whether I'm going to encounter mercs or bandits, bloodsuckers or chimeras, wondering if I'm going to locate a new stash (170 looted so far) or just find a new ledge I can climb onto, or even acquire an unknown 23rd artifact type to add to my collection: every day in the Zone is a joy, an adrenaline rush, and a meditation on the beauty of the maps and excellent gameplay that the developers and modders created.If I were shipwrecked on a desert island (with my PC and a power source) this would be the game I would want with me.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2016
												I have not played this game for a very long time, however I noticed one thing over the course of all of this time... I kept remembering this game from time to time. As somebody who is not a fan of jump scares and the "horror"-genre, in general, I was surprised by just how much I enjoyed this game.I was all about the open world. This world is very atmospheric and it really felt like you were just trying to survive, even if in reality it did not take much to become a bad♥♥♥♥♥who could go in with guns blazing most of the time. There were still plenty of surprises and challenges, some of which took a while to figure-out because there were more than one way to approach the situation, however the FEELING of "OMG, I have to stop the bleeding, find food, sell of this stuff to make money, and get ammo for my gun!" was always present. Never have I played a game where I was actually afraid of walking out at night and actually tried to get back to a safe area before darkness... kind of how you would do in real life, right? The atmosphere, especially with the lighting effects, and the creepy anomalies, made me explore every nook and cranny. Sure, you could probably run through the main story in a solid 10-15 hours... but why? I had a blast just exploring, at times doing repetitive artifact farming just because it was FUN figuring-out the spots where you could make a profit and simply LIVING in this world.If you like open world exploration (divided into several very large maps/area) and appreciate a focus on atmosphere, you will probably be able to look past the occasional cheap horror jump-scare and enjoy the game for what it is: an exploration masterpiece that ends waaaay too soon even after 54 hours. You will remember this one, unlike the many other games you may have also played along the way to get to this one.
