content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												Another game I should've reviewed a long time ago. This is an attempt to keep the Stalker feel with a new game, but since it's impossible to score a 11/10 like Shadow of Chernobyl, Call of Pripyat will have to settle for a 10/10.  This title keeps the Stalker atmosphere, with improved graphics (one of the first dx11 games), new maps (photorealistic to the areas they represent), and new gameplay and AI "Alife" system.  The same STALKER experience, while a slightly shorter game with fewer sidequests. Most negative review are from performance issues (try CoP Complete 2012 mod) or people that didn't give the game enough of a chance.  Try it and you won't regret it.10/10

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												Decided to re-write this review since I don't have a limit on characters now, I don't think.Anyway, STALKER Call of Pripyat is the 3rd game of the STALKER series and in the order of chronology, it falls in last (the first being Clear Sky, the second being Shadow of Chernobyl). STALKER is a survival semi-RPG FPS game that requires you to focus on multiple areas at once. Eating, weapon and armor management, inventory management, etc. The series is loosely based on the book Roadside Picnic by Boris and Arkady Strugatsky, although there are many differences. The act of searching for artifacts in an exclusion Zone is there, but the rest of the story is vastly different. Call of Pripyat's story, in particular, has almost nothing to do with the book. You play as USS Major Alexander Degtyarev, who is sent into the Zone following a failed mission conducted by the military to essentially map out the Zone for a full-scale military assault on the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant (CNPP). The game starts out with a cutscene that lasts maybe 5 or so minutes to give you backstory and such, and then thrusts you into the zone with bare essentials: food, bandages, first aid, and a couple guns with ammo. From there on, you're on your own. The game expects you to figure things out yourself and doesn't really outright tell you what to do. This is either exciting to you or a put off, depending on who you are. For me, it was refreshing. The first thing I did was walk up to a couple stalkers after I spawned and asked them where the nearest settlement was. They point to Skavodsk and you head there for more work. STALKER does a good job inducing a feeling of Isolation by putting you in wide open areas with very few people to be seen, except around settlements. Even then, the stalkers in these settlements will occasionally head out to gather supplies, hunt, artifact search, or just duke it out amongst themselves, so you'll find Skavodsk empty at times, aside from the merchants.  STALKER is also one of the most immersive games for me. The combination of music, ambience, and the general loneliness is so well done that it's hard to turn the game off. In Pripyat especially, there's a feeling of paranoia, as the background ambience includes whispering and quiet, soft chattering in Russian, so it always feels as if someone is nearby, and you don't know if they're friend or foe. One complaint that I have for the game is the English voice actors being really bad and making the game seem sillier than it really is. However, this can be fixed by downloading a Russian voice pack mod and english subtitle mod (I don't understand why these features weren't included to begin with but I'm glad the mods exist). Speaking of mods, there are several mods that make the game even better. Complete, MISERY, Atmosfear and many other mods all manage to make the game more immersive, difficult, fun, beautiful and overall great. Some problems with the base game are the glitches and crashes that occur, but with some mods, some of these glitches are nonexistent, although some still remain. I highly recommend playing CoP with mods.STALKERs mutants are also something to be addressed in themselves. There are mutants galore in the STALKER games. From the mostly docile Flesh, to the hulking Pseudo-Giant, to the mind bending Controller, every mutant is unique, and requires their own set of tactics in order to make it out in one piece.There's so many things I'd love to talk about in STALKER. I can't possibly put them all in one review. All I can say is buy the game and find out for yourself just how well made this game was, and how much love was put into it. Here's hoping bitComposer can help get STALKER 2 off the ground, and Survarium is just as good.

content:
Posted: April 9
												This is a great game, however it does have some flaws. I will be focusing on the flaws in this review but don't let that deter from buying the game. It is excellent, buy it and play it. My main complaint with this game has to do with the combat. Even on master difficulty I found the game to be pretty easy as most firefights against targets with firearms just devolved into the classic shooter "Wall hide" tactic. The AI seemed dumb and was almost always a pushover. I finished the game having completed every quest I came across and looking back I haven't felt like i've been in one firefight that felt worthy of this game's incrediable atmosphere. Don't get me wrong, the combat is great but it just doesn't mesh well with the terrifying atmosphere of this game. There's something off about being on edge for 2 minutes sweeping an abandoned laboritory thinking there's going to be a bloodsucker or shotgunner around every corner just to find a group of zombies that fight like mentally challenged kindergardeners. I guess my main point is that the AI just isn't challenging enough. I also don't like how the more dangerous mutants like the Turors, Chimeras and Psuedogiants are boring bullet sponges to fight. I remember one time I was sweeping through an underground complex when I came across a large mutant resting with it's back turned to me. I unloaded my G36 into it's back expecting it to turn around and come rushing at me trying to tear my face off and instead it just slowly got up and loped after me. The fight devolved into me training it around for 5 minutes pumping bullets into it. I ended up running out of ammo for my rifle 500 rounds later and had to resort to my shotgun to kill it. Luckily it only took 40 or 50 more rounds from that. The entire fight was boring as the mutant moved at snails pace and simply ate bullets without even reacting. Also the ending seemed anticlimatic and a bit easy.But nonetheless STALKER Call of Pripyat was one of the best shooter experiences I've had. The amazing atmosphere and sound design of this game blew me away. Definitely pick this game up.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												The "real" sequel to SoC. Sacrifices a little bit of the heavy, suffocating atmosphere and enthralling storyline of the first game for a massive improvement in virtually every other field. Surprisingly stable for something made by GSC, more balanced, devoid of the nerve-wracking loading times, dull random quests and broken mechanics. While the main storyline is noticeably more bland than in SoC, the side stories in all three of the main locations and the related quests more than make up for it. Increasing the size and decreasing the number of the main locations has been a wise decision, and while maybe a bit less varied in features, they are still rich enough. The re-worked survival, combat, anomaly, artifact and weapon customization systems all contribute to a much smoother and rewarding gameplay while the quests that involve going "off the grid" and often underground still ensure the teeth-rattling, creepy experience you all loved in SoC.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
												You're gonna want to play this game (and the other stalker games too) on the highest difficulty because the lower the difficulty, the lower the chance of a bullet hit counting as an actual hit. This means shooting an enemy in the head on easy may or may not kill the enemy, depending on your luck. Whereas shooting an enemy in the head on the highest difficulty will always kill the enemy (assuming your gun does enough damage).Not a great difficulty system, but knowing about it is gonna save you a lot of frustration.

content:
Posted: January 4
												With mods, this might be one of the best games I've ever played. It's really something to experience; once you load up the game you can feel the imminent threat of "the Zone". With an overcast sky and a foggy horizon, the lifelessness of the fallout is strikingly beautiful, yet bleak. This is the survival experience that I was looking for in the Fallout games. The world is out there to kill you, and it's up to you and your own skills to live. I was initially attracted to this game because of the mod "Call of Chernobyl". It expands the scope of the game so much, adding about a dozen or so new areas and making the game completely free-roam. Tweaking the game using mods like Nature redux and Armory Overhaul make the visuals quite up to date considering how long ago it was released. I would have more hours, but using the mod doesn't record my playtime on Steam. 10/10

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2011
												Call of Pripyat is the much awaited sequel of Shadow of Chernobyl, the first STALKER game. As soon as I completed SoC I sought this game out. Needless to say it took a few hours inorder to get really into it.The game starts out rather slow, though arguably all the STALKER games do. Once you get into the gameplay and fully immersed into the game world, you truly enjoy it. Pripyat is far more stable and less buggy then Shadow of Chernobyl was. Which is a major upside to the frequent crashing and freezing that game had. The gameplay feels a lot more streamlined with closer ties to sandbox games like Grand Theft Auto then RPGs.Really Call of Pripyat is well worth the price of admission. It lacks the heavy plot and character presence that Shadow of Chernobyl had, but makes up for it greatly in gameplay.

												As someone who has played all of the Fallout games, and most of the survival-multiplayer games, I can see why they would use certain aspects of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series in their ideas.Generally, Call of Pripyat is really fun to play, even after you beat the main story. This game is a great game with a great feel to it, but its story cannot be described as more than "good".

content:
Posted: May 4, 2016
												Call of Pripyat definitely lives up to the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. name! 10/10 obviously.These games have never failed to impress me. The Call of Pripyat Complete mod does volumes to improve upon the look and feel of this game, although without the mod I'd still say the game is damn near perfect like any of the other S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games. However, compared to the other games I felt like this game was... smaller... mostly because there didn't seem to be as much territory to explore. The story also seemed to be lacking a bit after playing SoC, which had an incredible story to it. They made it work though with plenty to do! I'm a huge fan of both the Fallout series and the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series, and although I spend way more time on Fallout, I have to admit S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is a way better RPG (if one can even consider Fallout to be an RPG).

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Of the 3 games in the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series, this one is my favorite.  CoP is great and if you use some graphics style mods for it, the looks are quite nice for a game this age.  Least is Clear Skys though SoC (Shadow of Chernobyl) has the most diverse endings possible, it's rather cryptic to play.Game play wise, it's wicked - you can and will get munched by things if you don't pay close attention to details.  I do like how when you hear things, like barking dogs or growls, you'll jump (almost nothing you hear is "friendly").  The story is decent and the play moves at your pace with plenty of open world feel to it.Downside:  No wait function and sleeping is only at certain times/places.  That gets annoying when you sure as hell aren't interested in going out in the dark/foggy weather in nasty areas or when you need to wait a couple game-hours for a mission.Some modes (and there are a few) help out a bit - especially graphics style mods for visuals but I'd avoid them until you've done a playthrough first. My personal favorites are Atmosfear and Absolute Nature for looks.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 3, 2016
												Absolutely amazing game with a superb atmosphere and interesting locations, people, and storylines.Pros:-Great atmosphere and doesn't overdo the horror element, but the intended parts *are* truly scary.-Unique locations, while some locations are underused, there is a wide variety of different things to look at and experience.-Interesting backstory that captures a lot of mystery. While the main plot is good itself, a lot of the best moments come from the side quests.-Enemies are well done. There is a decent range of different mutants with different focuses.-Alive world. Unlike something like skyrim where 99% of the encounters are scripted, the game's entire world has different squads and mutants shifting about. Since practically no NPCs are unkillable, this can lead to some people you have invested a bit of time into being killed while on patrol.-Better ending(s) than Mass Effect 3. While this game doesn't have a lot of traditional RPG elements, the branching endings make a lot of the questlines more meaningful.Cons:-The world isn't that big. Okay, this is probably a more extreme version of what I experienced with skyrim. After the 500th hour or whatever, you know the landscape to an extent to where the game world can't offer anything new. But yeah, the way the world is split up into three areas really limits the spaces you can visit without a guide. The earlier games handled this much better with smaller maps, but a seemingly larger space in total. Now, of course, this game does pretty much everything else better.-Bugs. It really doesn't seem that bad, but they do occur and I pretty much unconciously ignore them since I'm used to that type of thing. I would still consider it less buggy than Skyrim. I haven't ever had any quests break entirely, but I have had to reload my last save a few times.-AI. On any mission where you have to follow/lead around any AI, its failures become readily apparent. Due to some of the unreasonably strict casualty limitations to get some of the better ending slides, this can either require some save-scumming or just dealing with the worse ending. But seriously, the AI is extremely sucky against mutants and grenades. They feel like CoD level NPCs where they aren't even trying to fight properly against the enemy.-Graphics. I really don't give half a crap about graphics, but it is definately worth mentioning. Anyway, the "Complete" mod would be worthwhile for a second playthrough (or a first if you are particularily pedantic). It nice-inates the graphics while staying mostly true to the game. For better graphics you can try the Misery mod, but of course that changes a ton of stuff. While I have done 1-2 playthroughs with it installed, it adds instability to an already somewhat instable game.Anyway, its a great game that I would totally recommend!(Note: I got this game for free, but simply with my computer a few years back and not for any promotional thing or whatever by the devs. With hindsight, I would buy it at double price in a second)

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 5
												First off: I played this game for countless hours on CD before buying it on steam.The third of title in the S.T.A.L.K.E.R series, the game doesn't offer as much freedom as the Shadow of Chernobyl, but is a much more polished and straight-forward title. The story is not as open, there aren't as many factions, but what's there, works far better without mods than it does with its predecessor.It's therefore not a bad idea – if you don't mind a few spoilers – to start your journey into the series with this one. I don't think I need to tell you about the general setting, it's already well explained in the store-page and by other reviews.What I want to tell you about instead, is my personal experience and the memories I've shared with this game:There are few games that are this unsettling on an almost primal level. I was never a fan of the Fallout-esque style of post-apocalypse and neither of stuff like Mad Max. I don't know if it's the eastern European Atmosphere, or the way everything seems so dire, but something in the Stalker series (not writing the proper name anymore – ♥♥♥♥ dots!) just tickles me in the right places.I believe there's really a sense of venture, pioneering into a dark place, that the Stalker series does so well. Coupled with an eastern European attitude towards things (if something works, it works, while the german engineer would get one aneurysm after another) that puts a glimmer of hope across the entire fictious zone. In the deep darkness of it, there's a sense of comfort. Characters may seem opportunistic (most of them are, actually) and you shouldn't trust anyone, but again – somehow I can't help but build a deep feeling of sympathy for each and every one of them.To sum it up: No rose tinted glasses, you'll see visages of monsters, people and even yourself growing accustomed to this harsh world, but everyone is bonded by the sentiment of terror towards the things even worse – the oines you're not able to see.So, travel into the zone, but be warned: It might not stay a venture, but becom a second home.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												Most people love this game for the extreme atmosphere. It's probably the best example "post-apocalyptic" without actually being post-apocalyptic. The STALKER series takes place near and in Pripyat, Ukraine. In this world, the 1986 Chernobyl disaster released a magical and anomalous effect in the surrounding area named "The Zone". Outside of The Zone, the world continues as normal, however adventure and fortune seeking individuals smuggle themselves into the Zone to acquire artifacts, anomalous objects that are often used in and outside the zone for their beneficial properties, such as absorbing radiation or regenerating health.I'm sure you can read more about the world of STALKER in another review or on the wiki page. For this game, you're playing as guy sent into the Zone to investigate crashed helicopters. Your can also go on side-quests given to you by various fractions. Some of these quests are time limited once you accept them, so don't pile on a ton like you would in Skyrim.The combat in this game is pretty fun. You're far from a bullet sponge, specially in your basic armor. Firefights with bandits and other humans requires hit-and-run tactics, and taking hits causes blood loss which can be stopped with medkits and bandages. The Zone's monsters range from four-legged beasts that charge at you, zombies that are surprisingly accurate with their firearms, various humanoid creatures that leap long distances or attempt to control the minds of you and people around you.The graphics are dated and the firearm animations are janky; however, this game series has rather productive modding community. Check out hubs like /r/stalker on reddit for lists of popular mods (including the popular MISERY mod that dramatically increases difficulty).One thing to note, this game has more text than dialog. Most of it is optional, but on my first playthrough, I was blindly following map markers, not really knowing why I was doing the things tasked to me. It greatly detracts from the wonderful atmosphere of this game, so make sure to pay attention and read the text.

												The Stalker trilogy grew with time improving in each new chaper more, so this last one receive the benefits from the experience devs gained releasing other 2.The search for manufacts continues and is even more improved the system to find them with ultra modern detectors.The annoying emissions continue even inside this game, but this time the system was improved by devs a lot so that they're no more a problem, i completed the whole game and i never got killed one time by any of them....The improvements are made increasing the number of places you can now hide to take cover, so, wherever you'll be, you'll always find a close cover in the zone near you, you'll no more be forced to 20 miles marathons in 30 seconds like in CS.A new, great and very nice feature of this game are the Achievements, no, not the Steam ones, cause this game has none, but i'm referring to special ingame achievements, and they are not useless, each one will give you ingame various bonus, very useful to survive in the Zone, some of them will help also to make money easier so that you'll no more have that problem too and if you'll play smart you'll be rich already at 1/3 of the game ^^This was probably the first and only Stalker game where i had some real fun and less stress, but at end, with the Gauss Gun in my hands i was really too much overpowered hehe ^^In clonclusion, probably (i repeat, thanks to the experience from first 2) the best chapter of the serie, altough not perfect, but very close to be, recommended to experienced fps players and to everyone who want a challenge but without too much stress.My Final Score is 78 /100

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Call of Pripyat is an open world (3 large zone) apocalyptic first-person shooter that follows the event after SoC. This time you play as Military faction investigating the anomalies of your army operation failure.Gameplay:Besides facing againts humans, the anomalies aspect manage to fill the uniqueness of the game, and scary stuff.+Not a backtrack series from its previous games, and with a more entertaining environment + layouts, especially the anomaly zones and infrastructure of every area+Mutants ranging from horrifying predators with extreme agility, to many with psychic powers+S-Grade quests/missions with npc including bandits+Addictive Achievements+More guiding/tutorial dialogs from npc+Anomaly hunting is also easier than its previous series CS, as your PDA interface and maps are easier to read+no more random hazard areas of anomalies but replaced by fences and hills that close your openworld border+Highly Strategic AI movement, including mutants (They spam)+Hilarious secret stash locations..+Entertaining platforming to many hidden locations+Drugs, might need nerf.+No more time-limited missions+Game changing missions that affect your finale storyline and heavily on the latter progression.+Never forget the low-requirement PC specs, Lab X's RayEngine illuminati confirmed~Fast travel are more accessible, but may be glitchy for mutants and other enemies to spawn~Deadly Emission weather, that will put you to many desparate situations, a good thrill~Credits are easier to earn because anomaly hunting are waaay easier here~Upgrade feature seems similar, and is a definite relevant for end-game combats, owh and Pendrive have been replaced by Tool kits that you need to explore everywhere to access higher tier upgrades~Fairly nice music, but abusable in letting you know enemies are near during combat-Weight management is not easy, but that'd get you thinking and managing your inventory-Team crossfire, gotta have that realistic combat on.-Limitation on enemies's camping spot and not moving out from there-Strong handicap for AI during night time as their aiming remains unchanged.-Punishing penalty for poor gun shooting"An Emission is coming!" *PC crashes*, great game. Jokes aside, the developers have byfar possesses the best understanding in addressing what their players wants for the game from its past series of all the games I've played,as they are shown quite well through this series. (Trivia: one of my house's fusebox switch actually did went short-circuit, specifically on the socket plugged to my pc)And I open another bottle of Cossack vodkaReview: 9.9999/10, need more.High-end SPOILERS-The mysteries of Monolith faction, NPC Guide, Origins of Anomalies and X-labs remains....

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												Welocme to the  Zone. A Post-Apocoliptic hell-on-earth. Radioactive anomalies and crazed mutant creatures. Oh yeah, and the odd bandit raid and zombie attack. Your travel agent is a moron, unless you are Major Degretev ( I just mispelled that), a USS oprative sent in to investiagate a failed operation to the Zone. In which you discover the nature and the sheer disructive power that is the excusion zone around Chyernobl. Gameplay 9/10. A solid method to a well filled nitch, some will find it similar to Fallout exept it is not 100% rediculus, also the artifact hunting is a cornestone of the game in its story and its economy.Graphics 8/10. Good for a game of this type, however I don't recommend cranking the graphics to 10 unless you have a good rig.Story 9/10. It is hard to mix story and  non-linear gameplay, but they did a good job encorpeating it.Realism 2/10. Yes I actually made this a catagory on which I grade. This, like many other FPS games are the same. You can somehow walk out into a hail of bullets in an overcoat and somehow come out on the other side and laugh. Also if any of you have burn yourself on the oven taking something out, that is about 500 degrees F, a fire anomaly here is 1000 degrees C, and you can pitch a tent there for how long you can make it before taking  a decent amount of damage.Another thing to know, none of the weapons in this game have their real names, ex Martha is the name for an M9. Overall a good game which is short on realism and difficulty, which is fine. For anybody that thinks the Zone is too warm and cuddly for you, I deeply recommend the Misery mod. It is a full concept modification that changes and enhances, well every aspect of the game. As far as graphics are concerndmore contrast and darker colors, while taking the definetion up a notch or three. ( Do not attempt a high or even mid graphics if you have a low end rig). And for gameplay and realism. Well I'm not sure if you noticed, but it is called Misery for a reason. Most will spend a few hours on it and rage quit if they do it for their first playthrough, so don't. Get some COP playing on master under your belt before playing. Also, dont do what I did first time round, which is pretend you are still a tank, play this like Ghost Recon (not future soldier) avoid detection and invest in a sniper rifle. This is not for every STALKER but is worth it.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												As a technical note, I've played this game until its final culminating 10 minutes, because the game just doesn't manage to keep itself running when I reach a certain point in the final evacuation, about halfway through the mission. After seeing videos about the final minutes, I haven't missed too much.So, S.T.A.L.K.E.R.. Perhaps my favorite game series of all time. In many ways a review of this final installment of the series is a commentary on them all. Excluding obvious technical remarks about poor optimization, poor stability at times and glitches ranging from hilarious to potentially game-breaking, I have mostly praise to deliver.Stalker-games all center around on adventuring - and at times, merely surviving - in what possibly is the most wonderful theme that has ever blessed mankind, which at the same time is one of the most horrific disasters striking that said mankind. Stalker-games' relation to the accident at Chernobyl is tangential at best (the same could be said about its relation to the Roadside Picnic novel and Stalker movie), it still captures enough of the real to make for compelling fantasy. Reality does not stop at the theme itself, but the fact that much of the speech and non-spoken text is also preserved in its original form of Russian (even though it should probably be Ukrainian, but what do we stupid self-centered westerners know?) makes the game feel so much more genuine than your run-of-the-mill modern shooter, where the most foreign element you encounter is heavily accented English.Even though Stalkers do not aim to be ARMA-like simulators, they nonetheless take certain pride in their genre. Iron sights are viable, even mandatory, and different weapons and alternative ammunition are plenty, if somewhat dumbed-down in this third installment, compared to the first game. Armor and weapons can be upgraded with numerous convincing-sounding doodads which, while not always presenting itself too clearly what their actual benefit to the player is, serves as an addictive middle-term goal. With some differences I would say all Stalker-games can be discussed as a one entity. Even though balance changes between each game, and the first game being possibly mechanically most poor, if you like one Stalker-game, you probably at least tolerate them all.To say something about Call of Pripyat itself, while being immensely recommendable to all shooter game fans, it still falls short compared to what I see as the Ultimate Stalker, Shadow of Chernobyl. While it does quite well exploring its own side of the universe, it still manages to deliver the story as more simple, much less mystical and intriguing as the first two games did. It feels too much like an epilogue, which it irreversably is. Possibly this is partially planned. Without going into too much (spoiler-)detail, to the player the Zone no longer bears any mysticism. You have already learned its secrets, already know what makes it tick. You no longer even play a lone wanderer intent on deciphering its secrets, you are a government man on a mission that only accidentally happens to uncover more of the truth. And even in this it manages to do so in almost sorrowful frontier fiction -fashion: now that mystery is solved, control can be established and the myth has to make room for reality. What was already a world of the past ceases to exist altogether. In a considerably concrete way the game punts you out to the post-Stalker world. The Old can be revisited, but never again experienced in the same way. Or that is how I, with a touch of melodrama, understand it.S.T.A.L.K.E.R.-games offer a quite unique and compelling setting in an enjoyable, if unpolished way. Their genuine delivery feels exceptionally loving treatment of an IP, at least comparing to many modern shooters, or games in general. If one requires alleviation to Stalker-withdrawal, Metro-series is a worthy runner-up, if not a perfect match. 5/5 x 3.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												STALKER Call of Pripyat was my first STALKER game and I can't quite say what I think of it. Overall the game was brilliant, despite being a tad bit dated I still enjoyed it nonetheless. It was exciting to start without knowing anything about it and then scavenging for artifacts through anomalies. You do quests for the people and in turn they offer you better deals or money. There's quite a bit of medicines to be used(but I never used them) and there's quite a bit of customization with the weapon and armor mods which allow you to adapt your playstyle. I was however disappointed when I reached Pripyat. The zone is very barren, not much to be done and seen. The whole thing is bugged for me, not letting me finish my game and despite having found loopholes around it, I still can't quite finish it. This one part completely ruined the game for me. The Complete Mod for it also seems to be bugged and has negative reviews. I also noticed no more artifacts spawned in anomalous areas after having left Pripyat and went to Zaton/Yanov. Overall I don't think it's worth 20€ in it's state. It's a good game, but requires fixing.>I'd give it a 7/10(the ending completely ruined it, I'll try to fix it and update the review if possible)>Pros: Customization, plenty of quests that affect the ending, perks/achievements, very good atmosphere, fun to discover how the game works and all it's tricks, spooky ambiance with challenging enemies.>Cons: Graphical bugs, many other bugs which might make you unable to finish the game or quest, lack of content in the end-game, my artifacts didn't respawn after emissions nor did I have any use for most medicines in the game as all of it was trivial(running through anomalies and healing up afterwards proved to be easier)

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11
												The S.T.A.L.K.E.R. game series is one of, if not my most, favourite game series.The games all have a unique and really cool theme to them, the post-apocalyptic zone around the Chernobyl powerplant. The atmosphere from these games is something alot of games struggle to do as well as this series, and Call of Pripyat is yet another wonderful extension to it.Whilst the game is old and does show it age, with some rough edges here and there, it is the most refined out of all the games. The Russian/Ukrainian audio and dialouge is really authentic, and will have you really immersed. This game brings a sense of dread, wonder, fear, and curiosity like no other. The weather system is really well done, with everything from sunshine, rain, storms, and even nuclear emissions. Ammo, armour, and weapons are scarce, and so are other supplies. This game will not hold your hand, so first timers may find it difficult for awhile, but it's definately worth pushing through.One downside is the story element. Not that the story is bad or anything, but it can be easily overlooked and forgotten as it's not really in your face for most of the game. First time players will probably not understand anything, but if you are interested I highly recommened playing the older games, even if they are quite rough around the edges.All in all, fantastic game. Highly recommend to people looking for something different than usual.

Posted: April 16, 2016
												The most polished STALKER game, and unfortunately, probably the last.COP takes the best parts of SOC and Clear Sky and blends them into one game. The storyline features some rpg-esque choices and consequences, many side quests/faction content and a highly improved weapon/suit upgrade system (first introduced in Clear Sky).Graphically, the game's textures and models look quite outdated, but the game makes up for it with superb use of DX11 lighting and shaders. There are also many graphical mods available to improve the quality of the models and textures. On the subject of mods, the game still has a thriving mod community that makes everything from gameplay overhauls to total conversions.Whether you've played the previous STALKER games, or are a fan of RPG/FPS hybrids (or just FPS/RPGs), COP is well worth your time.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												The S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series is one that scratches an itch that many people weren't aware they had, that of a story-based first-person shooter that doesn't skimp on the aspects of character improvement. To be fair, its narrative lacks the strength of an epic such as Half Life, but it makes up for it by presenting a plausible pseudo-scifi flair that doesn't require too much imagination to comprehend. The long and short of it is that, in the area around the Chernobyl catastrophe (known as the "Zone"), radioactive influence has caused the birth of a number of strange anomalies, both helpful and harmful. The former come from 'artifacts', mysterious objects possessing helpful properties like increasing the body's ability to heal, and the latter is in the form of arcane occurrences such as areas where gravity is magnified to a fatal extent, or even things as run-of-the-mill as your typical postapocalyptic creatures seeking to kill you.What sets the STALKER franchise apart is the emphasis on the balance between the fictional nightmares of the Zone and the interactions with other people just like you -- fortune-seekers trying to locate artifacts for their value in the world at large, while avoiding the pitfalls of anomalies and mutants. While these other Stalkers may not be perfectly represented as flesh-and-blood people, it is entirely possible, within the scope of the games, to make alliances with one faction (say, the Bandits who seek fortune for themselves at the expense of others), which would then make others view you as an enemy.Call of Pripyat is itself the latest (five years old, mind you) expression of the series, bringing together Shadow of Chernobyl (the first game)'s narrative coherence with Clear Sky (the second, oft-panned game)'s factional warfare and open-ended nature. In CoP, you find yourself in an open world, with 3 main maps available to get your Stalker on. There is a centralized story to follow, involving your character as a special operative for the Russian government attempting to track down the cause of the crashes of an entire squad of other operatives, as if flying over the anomaly-filled Zone wasn't reason enough. But within that overall framework, you are free to either maintain your military nature and focus entirely on the mission, or you can go off and become a Stalker yourself, searching for artifacts and misplaced caches of military gear.As far as the story goes, it's a pretty linear progression. Each map has a list of things for you to accomplish in the story's progression, and at the end of those things it opens up the way to the next map. It serves a function of allowing you to explore each area, without losing track of the bigger picture always lurking just beneath the surface (unlike other open-world games where you can never complete the 'main quest' and still explore the entirety of the world). This hampers the game somewhat, though, as you as a player may feel railroaded into performing some things just for the sake of progression, even if you want more time to just float around the world.The real appeal of CoP comes from exploration. Sure, each map is, in the end, just a collection of a dozen or so "points of interest", each of which corresponds to a specific scenario -- here is a building that you can explore, there is a field full of Boiler anomalies that superheat the air, and so forth. But in your first playthrough, at least, exploring each of these locations feels deep enough that it feels like you're really blazing new trails into the mysterious and dangerous Zone.As far as character progression goes, there aren't any RPG aspects insofar as levels and skills -- no stat distribution screens here. Instead, a fluid progression system emerges from acquiring and upgrading new gear. And while there are certainly high and low ends of the spectrum for both weapons and armor, an interesting upgrade system performed by a mechanic NPC means that even a beginning-of-the-game weapon can perform adequately to let you handle the toughest of mutants and the most heavily-armed NPCs. The real limiting factor is money -- but, as you get more money and/or loot to sell as you do more things in the world, it functions as a sort of experience system, where getting enough money lets you buy a new suit of armor, or perhaps a few upgrades to the suit you already have that increases its survivability in radioactive environments.Moving on to artifacts: As explained earlier, artifacts are mysterious (there's that word again) objects possessing unique abilities that, more often than not, are helpful to your character. This comes at a cost, though, as many artifacts are still inherently radioactive (represented by a +# representation, based on the radioactivity), and will cause you harm if you use them for too long. Their use is through their placement in an "artifact pouch", wherein their effects -- both positive and negative -- will be able to affect you. Or you can always just carry them in your backpack, where they can't hurt you, but can't help you either. And thus a balance has to be struck between using artifacts that help you in the near future -- mental protection as you're about to fight telepathic mutants, for example -- and either bearing the radioactivity, using your precious anti-rad meds as a stopgap measure, or using one of the slightly-rarer anti-radioactivity artifacts (which have -# in the radioactivity measurement), the lattermost of which can negate the other artifacts, and even give you a baseline radioactivity resistance.With that, I come to the final point, which is the plethora of in-game stats that the player has to take into effect. There are eight, each with their own means of being inflicted and being protected against or healed. Roughly speaking, these stats and a brief summary are:1.) Impact -- The effect (damage and flinching) of gravitational effects (anomalies or stuff being thrown at you telekinetically), or being smacked around by mutants with physical attacks2.) Wounding/Bleeding -- Slow health loss through cuts, bullet wounds, etc.3.) Explosion -- Self-explanatory4.) Firearms -- The effect (damage and flinching) of gunfire5.) Burn -- The damage of thermal effects (fires, thermal anomalies, etc.)6.) Chemical -- The damage of chemical hazards (typically anomalies)7.) Electric -- The damage of electrical anomalies8.) Radiation -- The damage and effect (screen blurring, stamina drain, etc.) of radioactive objects and anomalies9.) Psy/Mental -- The damage and effect of mental attacks (almost exclusively by psychic mutants)As you can see, there are many stats to be concerned with, but they fall into two general categories -- combat and environment. For the most part, environmental resistances are only momentary concerns based on the current situation -- no need to worry about Burn resistance unless you're going into a field of hot anomalies -- wheareas the combat stats are all-round necessities. The trick is to balance finding armor with the stats you need (with upgrades providing some measure of balance for stats they lack), artifacts that will resist what you're about to do in the immediate future, and using on-demand items that temporarily boost resistances.In the end, the Zone is worth at least one solid playthrough, even if in doing so you explore every point of interest, locate one of every artifact, and collect every piece of gear possible. An emergent mod community has also put together mods doing everything from merely adding a handful of gear to be found, to some introducing entire new zones imported from the previous games. In the end, I would conclude that S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Call of Pripyat is worth playing, if for no other reason than to demonstrate that an FPS can have a non-setpiece story, and some aspect of RPGs, without losing part of itself in the process.

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 30
												Okay, let me start this off by saying I highly prefer SoC over CoP. The reason being is quite simple:In Shadows of Chernobyl, you are a Stalker trying to make their way through the Zone with a simple task: To kill Strelok. If you want to, you can completely ignore the story and just carve out your own path doing Stalker-like things. On top of that, the Zone herself is fairly dangerous and desolate, and in an odd way, fairly beautiful as a result. However, in Call of Pripyat, you're no Stalker. You're military. You know, those guys forcing Loners to pay just to pass through Cordon without getting shot. You're -pretending- to be a Stalker just so you can safely find out what happened to some downed helicopters, and that honestly ruined the experience for me right off the bat.I really tried to like this game since it's still a S.T.A.L.K.E.R title, but that one little fact really soured the milk. Maybe I'm being petty, but after fighting against the military and seeing my fellow Loners get gunned down, I can't just switch sides. Especially since I prefer to role play while spending a few hours in this setting. And yet, here I am giving this game a positive recommendation, and that's all due to mods.I've tried Misery, and as much as I loved how it made the game considerably harder, I got the feeling attempting my first playthrough this way was a mistake, so I'm back to vanilla for now. However, not too long ago I learned of Call of Chernobyl, and holy hell did that save this game for me. Add to it the add-ons from DoctorX (Questline, Faction Relations, and Dynamic Faction Relations), and I'm now going through what I had hoped this game would have been. I'm a Stalker again. I'm a Loner. My motives are my own, and I do what I must to survive. That is why CoP still gets a recommendation from me....Oh, and speaking of CoC, I'm currently in a playthrough in which Duty and Freedom have declared an alliance.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2011
												Unbelievably much much better than the predecessors, this is like the STALKER game you always wanted. It has this certain 'final touch' that all the others lacked and so you'd constantly get stuck or screw yourself over, this one is more easy and smoothly to play, while it also has the very immersive and realistic landscape of Tchernobyl, with better implemented enemies such as even creepier mutants, zombies and the works that was missing before.. At times I was too scared to go on, and coming from me, that says something. It should be noted that it is also extremely crash-happy still, so make sure to save often. It really encourages exploration and actually leaves it up to the player to how much time they really want to invest in it, and it rewards that. Very neat design.

												Love it.Tips for Misery noobs:1. Always survey the area before making your move2. Rushing in guns blazing is never a good idea3. Conserve ammo4. Think before you leap5. Use grenades6. Keep moving**7. BATTERIES!8. Buy things in this order in terms of priority     Equipment>Weapons>Ammo*>Armor>Mods>Food*   * - You should loot these primarily, buy only if needed   **  - The AI are Olympic grenade throwers for some reason    Despite being old, this is an overall fun and enjoyable game for survival horror and FPS fans alike although it leans towards FPS and strays from the survivor horror aspect a little bit. For first time players of this game i heavily reccomend playing on Master off the bat, seriously Easy is just a poorly balanced FPS where you swim in guns and money.     While for intermediate users who prefer a challenge, you should try the MISERY mod for S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Call of Pripyat.It's literally Dark Souls in Chernobyl as it takes every aspect of the game and makes it significantly harder and also adds some new elements to make it even more unforgiving, For true STALKERS only.My Evaluation.Pros - Little Handholding - Do things at your own pace - Combat is not too easy or too hard - Survival elements and equipment management does not feel like a choreCons - English voice acting is horrible, russian vocals with english subs is better - Money comes by too easily* - some areas are disappointingly easy* - Radiation is redundant and pointless** - Misery Mod fixes thisI have 200+ hours on this game at least, i own a CD and this on steam.Happy hunting stalker!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												If survival FPS is what you are looking for then look no further. I started the series with Shadow of Chernobyl, which I highly recommend to play first. Even though the two stories arent strictly linked, the game and atmosphere feels alot more developed once you play through SoC. If you decide to jump into Call of Pripyat anyways then once you get past the steep learning curve youll find yourself in a pretty large world without much indication of what to do. Basically all you need to know is that everything is out to kill you and unless youre 10+ hours into the game, everything will kill you without even giving you a chance. Hitting that F5 button is a must every 2 minutes because you can and you will die every 2 minutes in your first playthrough. Getting money to buy better gear is a must and doing the side missions just happen as you go along. Once you find yourself being able to kill bandits and small fry mutants, then you are in a position to actually start the main story and continue the game as intended.Pros of this game is that the atmosphere in this is unmatched by any game ive played since its release up to the time of this review. The gun physics is amazing as the bullets are physical objects and shooting just doesnt get any more satisfying than this, that I can garuantee. The survival elements of this game are really harsh at first but once you get mid range equipment, you should be able to get a reasonable income for items and such to keep you going. End game is mainly about exploring and the survival elements are very minimal as youre probably pretty rich by then and the stores always have enough supply. Cons are that even though the game is open world with alot of varying activities, I have to say that to me the main story felt no different than doing a very long series of side missions. Theres also the fact that once you reach a certain point in the game, the atmosphere changes from survival to just completing missions and loses alot of its immersion (IMO). On the plus side again though there is a HUGE amount of mods available for this game and trying them out gives you a new experience every time.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												Call of Pripyat is what Clear Sky should have been. Here, the game finally offers a completely new map with new places to visit and NPCs to interact with. Also, it continues the story of the first Stalker game. You, as a stalker and agent, investigate why several helicopters crashed during their mission which aimed to scout the area so that the military could find out how exactly the Zone had changed after the events of the first game.This seems to be the most stable of all the Stalker games and it should also be noted that the only one offering you to stay once the main story is completed. It was annoying in the previous two games that I was not exactly notified that once the journey to the centre of the Zone started all my side missions would remain incomplete. Here, at the end of the game, you can make a decision to stay and complete any unfinished quests you had or explore any undiscovered areas. Also, this Stalker game seems to be the only one that rarely had any crashes when I was playing it - it is a stable version where you encounter few glitches or bugs. This is of course all the feedback on the vanilla game as the COMPLETE mod was also released for this version further enhancing the Stalker experience. Still, it is commendable that GSC Game World put enough time and effort to release a functional game that was enjoyable without having to wait for further patches on the date of release.Call of Pripyat should be picked up by those who liked Shadow of Chernobyl. Do skip Clear Sky and pick this one in its stead. After installing the game install the COMPLETE mod to have the best Stalker experience to date.

												Previous games : STALKER Chernobyl and Clear Sky.I played both many many years ago.Game style : slow pace shooter meets RPG in open world environment   *A little bit of RPG.....,talk to persons, encumberance, buy and sell goods, upgrade your weapons and armor,    tweak your characteristics with artefacts, get missions by approaching NPCs   *Shooter : pistol, shot gun, sniper, grenades, rocket launcher, take cover, aim for the head   *Slow pace : most of the time you will spend on moving from one place to anotherDifficulty : played on Veteran which is recommendable as long as you take cover.Story line : Although the universe you are in is derived from a book serie, the story line of the game is poor and paper thin, like shooters mostly do.Dialogues : Short and necessary to pick up missions. Missions are not always that clear.Combat system (8/10) : shoot, throw, stab and hide in cover.bleed, use bandage or use artifactloose healing points, use med kit or artifactAtmosphere (9/10): unique setting, always the feeling of being in danger, playing during night time brings on the most joy / thrillGraphics (8/10) :ok, game is 7 yrs old but looks still fine to me. I played Crysis 3 just before this oneand was not shocked (even when standing in an electricity anomaly). Played Pripyat on the highest settingsMusic (10/10) :It's atmospheric and blends very well during gaming, not to mention the additional sound of lightening,barking dogs, howling wolfs, crows, mourning zombies.Difficulty :play at least on veteran level, difficulty can always be changed during course of the game,Bugs :this version is bug freeHello, anyone there ? : Two places, the Jupiter factory and the zone Pripyat are underdeveloped.It's just me, myself and I.To play or not to play  :If you played Chernobyl and Clear sky before, it will feel more of the sameIf you never played STALKER, go for it if you do not mind that pace is slow I hope to see a STALKER 3 in near future and some more budget to get it on a higher level

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
												More mutant mayhemThe story in CoP takes up where SoC left off (although you play as a different character) so it seems fitting that I played the games in that order, missing out Clear Sky (for now). As with SoC, this is quite a tough game (no hand-holding here), although it didn’t seem quite as tough as the original. It’s also a good deal shorter, with the main storyline taking about 15 hours to complete (there are, of course, a fair few side quests, but I didn’t complete all of them). The graphics are an improvement over the original, especially if you use some of the mods available. It’s also less buggy. The voice acting is okay, if a little variable, as are the character animations. This is, in many ways, a straightforward continuation of what has gone before, and the impressive STALKER atmosphere is maintained along with the challenging gameplay. Despite the improvements, however, there is less diversity in the environments compared to those found in SoC, and the world is less expansive than it is in SoC. And the story, although more coherent, is somewhat lighter. But this is still an immersive and enjoyable game to play. 3.5/5

												The most polished game of the trilogy, STALKER COP follows the story of Shadow of Chernobyl, its a free roam FPS with RPG elements like looting, buying & upgrading weapons, sleeping, etc. Just like SoC, it provides a unique atmosphere of complete desolation & loneliness, mixed with a hostile enviroment full of mutated creatures, zombiefied humans, factions that collide with eachother & lots of natural hazard like emissions that force you to take shelter, radioactive areas, dangerous anomalies, etc. Its a unique experience, you'll love it or hate it. If you're tired of hollywood-like games and you're looking for something more underground, this is the game for you.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2012
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R Call of Pripyat is the third, and with GSC Game World closing down, most likely the last game in the stalker series. The stalker games were a surprise hit right from the start and it's a shame to see the series end, especially with this game where everything seems to turning in the right direction once again.Call of Pripyat, like the other stalker games, is an open world first person shooter with some minor RPG elements thrown in for good measure. You roam the radioactive wasteland surrounded Chernobyl, searching for "artifacts", valuable and rare commodities created by the various spacial anomalies created by the nuclear meltdown so many years ago. To keep things interesting you will have to contend with other stalkers wanting the artifacts for themselves, shadowy organizations with their own secret agendas, the Ukrainian military and of course, horribly mutated monsters.One thing that Call of Pripyat does notably different from it's predecessors is slowing things down quite a bit. Instead of every map being a battlefield of constant and relentless attacks by seemingly unending forces from the various factions populating the zone combat is now much rarer. This has the very welcoming effect of making the game world feel like the radioactive wasteland it's supposed to be, every encounter is more intense because of it and it feels a little special when you encounter a group of stalkers who promptly tell you to holster your weapons or get lost rather than simply open fire on sight.The faction system that was present in Clear Sky has all but been removed and this also helps push the pace of the game more towards Survival Horror than Mindless Shooter. While the factions still exists, still do battle with one another and still treat you differently depending on your actions there is no constant defend and attack missions and broken faction relations and this goes a long way towards making you feel like you're playing your own game, rather than just being another soldier in a never ending war.Despite all the good there is still plenty of bad however. The game is much smaller than both it's predecessors and the great storyline and mysteries from Shadow of Chernobyl is nowhere to be found. Also the difficulty has been toned down considerably which will elate some and irate others.The engine is still pretty bad, the animations have been cleaned up a little but are still very clunky and despite the graphical enchantments that the series has been undergoing since Clear Sky this game still has that "raw" feeling of Shadow of Chernobyl. That feel like you're playing something half-done. Something that could have used another year of polishing. While this might normally be enough to make you quit the game Call of Pripyat manages to accomplish the same fear as the original. It makes you enjoy it despite it's many flaws. Sure you will probably grab the first graphical enhancement mod you come across but that's not because you can't play the game without it, it's because you have to play the game regardless and just want to spare your eyes a little.Call of Pripyat is a good way to end the stalker series I suppose. It's a good game and has many improvements over it's predecessors. But completing I still feel like something is lacking. A true "S.T.A.L.K.E.R 2" might not be something we will ever see but it sure is something we can hope for.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												Самая лучшая и комплексная часть. Объединяет все лучшее из двух предыдущих. Я три раза начинал игру заново, чтобы попробовать другой путь прохождения. А когда начал играть, спустя 3-4 часа, понял, что я совсем не продвинулся по главному заданию, а все время изучал мир и выполнял второстепенные. :) Мы играем за майора Дегтерева, которому поручают расследовать мистическое крушение военных вертолетов. В итоге, нам, по ходу игры, доступны три большие локации с открытым миром, это Затон, Окрестности завода "Юпитер" и Припять. И еще куча квестовых линий за разные группировки. В игре очень классно сделали разделение мира на группировки, но, при этом, есть нейтральные зоны, где уживаются все и можно со всеми поговорить.Я не хардкорный сталкер :)) А просто люблю изучать мир, исследовать все, поэтому в последнее свое прохождение немного отредактировал конфиг actor.ltx, чтобы дать ГГ двойное время бега (в игре огромный мир и большую часть времени приходится бегать, поэтому не люблю то, что персонаж быстро устает) и двойную переносимость (очень часто случайно подбираешь ружья с трупов и инвентарь захламляется, и бывает, что перевес случается совсем не вовремя...) В итоге, я получил лучшее удовольствие от этой части и может пройду ее еще раз на большей сложности. :)Моя оценка: ОТЛИЧНО. В игре практически нет минусов, все сделано очень качественно и детально.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												Stalker has been considered by many a post-apocalyptic first person shooter game. But it isn't, your in a Cordon zone of the Chernobyl area that has been abandon since April of 1986 due to NPP4 catastrophic failure rendering the environment hazardous to live in. Yes, the place dose exists for real, all locations are based on real locations in the real zone. Life is still going on everyday for the people out side of the zone. The Stalker game series is inspired off the book "Roadside Picnic", which is a short science fiction novel written by Arkady and Boris Strugatsky in 1971. More information on this book is available on a wiki, and the book is also available in English now.  The game is a open world exploration as well as mission directive, Remember that.Call Of Pripyat is the final game of the Stalker series, it is like a advance version of Shadow Of Chernobyl. It is less buggy and very mod friendly at that. You still in the cordon off zone like a prison, but up far north just out side of Pripyat. The game developers did a very good job of brings the real locations to life in the game, I even saw a over head veiw pic of Pripyat and recognized all the locations there. There is trading with traders, and the different factions. Many dangerous anomalies to contend with, and artifact to collect and sell for money. Have to watch out for the areas that are radioactive still. One of the things to remember is question everyone and trust no one. Being skeptical with a gut feeling at times is better than a fire fight, When in this game it is important. At the end of this game you can decide to leave the zone which ends the game completely, or stay and live in it for a while. Go back to Jupiter or Zanton, take care of unfinished business if you wish.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												Stalker has been considered by many a post-apocalyptic first person shooter game. But it isn't, your in a Cordon zone of the Chernobyl area that has been abandon since April of 1986 due to NPP4 catastrophic failure rendering the environment hazardous to live in. Yes, the place dose exists for real, all locations are based on real locations in the real zone. Life is still going on everyday for the people out side of the zone. The Stalker game series is inspired off the book "Roadside Picnic", which is a short science fiction novel written by Arkady and Boris Strugatsky in 1971. More information on this book is available on a wiki, and the book is also available in English now.  The game is a open world exploration as well as mission directive, Remember that.Call Of Pripyat is the final game of the Stalker series, it is like a advance version of Shadow Of Chernobyl. It is less buggy and very mod friendly at that. You still in the cordon off zone like a prison, but up far north just out side of Pripyat. The game developers did a very good job of brings the real locations to life in the game, I even saw a over head veiw pic of Pripyat and recognized all the locations there. There is trading with traders, and the different factions. Many dangerous anomalies to contend with, and artifact to collect and sell for money. Have to watch out for the areas that are radioactive still. One of the things to remember is question everyone and trust no one. Being skeptical with a gut feeling at times is better than a fire fight, When in this game it is important. At the end of this game you can decide to leave the zone which ends the game completely, or stay and live in it for a while. Go back to Jupiter or Zanton, take care of unfinished business if you wish.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												And now, the final part of the stalker revisions...Call of Pripyat. To remind my readers, this is now based on the vanilla experience, as this will conclude the 3 stalker games' revisions. What can i say about this game? Was it fun? Yes. Was it more sandbox-y than Clear Sky? Yes. Did it feel empty and hollow? You bet. For all the mechanics that the developers improved upon they possibly refined a little too much, to the point that the streamlined gameplay somehow made the game easier. This is Stalker we are talking about here. It's not supposed to be easy.....is it? Even on Master skill this game was easier than Clear Sky or Shadow of Chernobyl on Stalker (Medium) skill. The developers improved the upgrade mechanic, to where you no longer need to fetch flash drives and bring them to the respective mechanics. Instead, you're left with finding tools in each of the first 2 maps to bring to the mechanics, and then have to travel to Pripyat to find the last of the tools. Not quite as tedious to some, but still requires you to do some work. The graphics in my opinion took a step in the wrong direction. While the lighting may have improved a little with the DirectX 11 renderer, most of everything else seemed like it was ripped from SoC in terms of quality. Maybe this had to do with the larger, albeit fewer, maps. Honestly, i really couldn't tell much of a difference at all between DX 9 and 11, aside from a little improved lighting. The characters still have the same facial animations, reload animations, etc....The sound was vastly improved,and while the sound effects still aren't of a caliber as say Battlefield, they do the job. Now, when the emissions hit, however, the sound design improves because it brings back the creepy vibe of SoC. When i first loaded the game up and experienced my first emission, just the sound of the storm brewing and approaching was haunting. I was running for cover as if I PERSONALLY was going to die. The gameplay mechanics stay intact from the other 2 games, except your character feels too much like a bullet sponge. Enemies go down rather quickly, yet, you can take several shots without too much worry, as long as you have a relatively good armor suit. The emissions respawn artifacts, allowing you to continue artifact hunting in anomalies you already cleared. However, this brings more money to you. Sell the artifacts, make a bunch of money, buy an exoskeleton suit in the first map......wait...what? That's right, you can buy an exo suit from Nimble very quickly in this game if you have the funds for it. Not really that difficult to have the funds for it with the abundance of artifacts and the side objectives having a wealthy payout. Now, i know that some gamers would say, "then don't buy the exo suit." Not the point. The point is, as i stated in my review for Clear Sky, what made that game so well constructed was the pacing and balance. By Nimble giving you access to an exo suit and top notch weaponry from the get-go, it ruins the pacing of the game. Some gamers may enjoy this, sure, but in a franchise that prides itself on being difficult, is this the stalker way? Is it right to have access to this equipment so soon? Ask yourself that question when you approach Nimble when you first reach the ship in Zaton....Hunger has returned, giving one of the immersive factors of SoC back. Not only that, if you find yourself hungry, it affects how quickly your stamina drains while running. Keep the food flowing to keep that stamina up. Weapons also seem to degrade very rapidly here, even when upgraded for reliability. This rubbed me the wrong way here only because it's like a false difficulty. Now, the first 2 stalkers games felt like sandbox games, but were still somewhat restricted. This game is more sandbox then the first 2 combined, yet was substantially shorter. A completionist run on Master can be completed in around 15 hours, really depending on how much artifact hunting you do. While Zaton and Jupiter (first 2 maps) had interesting designs, the new Pripyat map was where the game had the potential to REALLY shine. This sprawling city with numerous buildings that you had access to, and underground tunnels, unfortunately felt amazingly empty. You had a selection of primary objectives to do, and very few side objectives, but unfortunately, that's about it. There were only a handful of anomalies to find artifacts, and just no real reason to venture around the city. The best part of Pripyat if you ask me was the underground lab. Very creepy, claustrophobic, and dangerous....reminds me of the labs in SoC. Then, the game just kind of ends on a very unfulfilling final mission.....(NOT SPOILING).Last bit of the gameplay that many people enjoyed, but not me because of the ruining of the pace.....STASHES. Many gamers were not satisfied with the stash mechanic in the first 2 games, where you couldn't access the contents of a stash until you received the coordinates for it from a dead body. In CoP, you have access to the contents of EVERY stash in the game by default. You get some coordinates for the available stashes by completing some side objectives, but some of the stashes include very powerful weapons, food, medkits, etc. Again, while you don't actually HAVE TO access the stashes, it's just another con with the pacing and balance of the game. In SoC and CS you had to get your hands dirty to find the coordinates for the stashes, and even if you did get coordinates, they were totally randomized. If you've played the game enough to know what each stash contained in SoC, you would fight enemies until you got the coordinates for that ONE STASH you really needed. Nothing good comes easy. Gotta work for it, unlike CoP which just hands it to you. I still would recommend this game because, as i stated in my CS review, the Stalker lore grabs ahold of you. The modding community also made quite possibly the most popular Stalker mod of all 3 games for CoP...Misery. Even if this game is easier than the others, i would still highly recommend you play this vanilla first...on Master skill only. If it's too easy, try Misery. Happy hunting Stalker.7.3/10

												STALKER plays like fallout in many ways but in fallout if you dont see anything your safe. in STALKER your only safe in a few places. if you get caught outside at night you have a flashlight but night is VERY dark and unforgiving. monsters range from dogs to 'bloodsuckers' that can turn invisible, swarm you, and quickly take you down if your not ready for it.a pistol can save you but shouldnt be relied on for long. i highly recommend this game for anyone that likes fallout, metro or any similar game. unlike metro and fallout STALKER is scary and brutal. you want the good stuff, you have to earn it.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												On one hand along with ShoC, these two games are one of the best I've ever played.  On the other, the developers are long since fired and have gone on to new studios, new games and won't see a dime of your money.  The story behind the game is sadly wrapped in greed, bad treatment, and corruption.  Which is probably why the story IN the game richly portrays those things.  While it's one of my favorite games and the second best of the series (ShoC > CoP > CS), I'd recommend you get it for as cheap as possible.  Also it's aged like vinegar unfortunately.  It was ahead of its time when ShoC came out with advanced A-Life AI that lived and breathed in the world instead of sitting waiting for you to show up and interact with it.  But by the time CoP was released it was already aging and it's been a long time since this game released.All three games have wonderful modding communities that add replayability to it and are still active even after all this time.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												This was the most enjoyable FPS I have ever played. After trying out various mods for this game, I eventually went with Misery Mod 1.0 (2.0 was too much for my wimpy laptop, but I personally think 1.0 was better anyway). I also completed the game on Master difficulty.Modding aside, CoP is a brilliant open-world shooter. While there is a story that the player eventually needs to progress through, the open-world element puts you in control of the pace of the game so you can explore/merc all you want and then perform the essential plotline tasks when you're ready. I loved the idea of three gigantic levels taking the places of seven or eight smaller ones. The gunfights are technical and challenging. The finale of this game is terrific - probably the most intense gunfight I've experienced in a game.By the time I was done with CoP's prequels, I was craving more difficulty, so I installed Misery, which was pretty unforgiving in the early game. It also creates a bleak atmosphere, adds new weapons, and changes the sound a bit. The mod also tweaked the random events, keeping the player on edge. I HIGHLY recommend this game with the Misery mod.

												Awesome game, retains a suspenseful tone and a strong horror vibe, stepping up enemies with the player; it's a great game and I highly recommend. It's a challenge, it's well-done, it's based on a book...This game pretty much has it all... with the exception of the Steam overlay.But, 'Slow down, chief! Put that shooter away first...'When you suit up in an exoskeleton with night vision and a full-auto shotgun to stomp out a group of bandits who swindled you ten minutes ago, when you push home the final of 3 rpg rounds you've saved the whole game to blow up the Pseudogiant in the next room, when you use all your food and medkits, but just manage to survive that Emission with cover still a mile away, when you turn Beard down and keep that Bubble artifact... when you feel the Call of Pripyat at last and with iron resolve trek through the Jupiter Plant's long-sealed catacombs...... You will love this game with all your heart and soul.Why are you still reading this? GET OUT OF HERE, STALKER!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R Call of Pripyat like the rest of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R series, is a cross between the fps and rpg genres. It takes place in Chernobyl Ukraine after a second disaster which unleashes all kinds of horrific crap into the Chernobyl exclusion zone. Now i will say that the story is kind of lackluster, and the game it's self can be rather punishing for a new player, but once you get the hang of it the game offers a good balance between making you feel like the god of the apocalypse, and a scared Bunny who just want's to live though the day. But the best thing about this game is it's atmosphere, it really helped me get into the world they've built, and plus most of the in-game locations are modeled after their real world counterparts so it feels almost like you are actually walking though the dead city of pripyat. Another great thing about this game is that for the most part, you can do whatever you feel like doing, and explore a large open and mutant filled world, with alot of upgradable and customizable Guns and Suits. Well i know this review was kind of long and i probably only scratched the surface of what this game is, but i think that about covers the basics and i just want to finish by saying i loved every second of this game.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2015
												Although this is my first and only S.T.A.L.K.E.R game I can see how it definitely is in a league of its own. I am a really huge fan of horror games, first person shooters, and open world, and this game puts all of those together beautifully and in such a unique way. Also if you like to push yourself in video games this game is definitely the Dark Souls of FPS and I feel the best way to immerse yourself in this game is to play it on master and if you find it too difficult then that's too bad because that is the life of a S.T.A.L.K.E.R.(plus there's the Misery Mod). Plus I can't count how many times I've been killed by one shot on master difficulty, or how many times I have to repair armor/guns. Also its also the little things in the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. world that can be the most meomorable. I would wonder through the world and stumble upon four other S.T.A.L.K.E.R's playing music and drinking vodka with dead animal carcasses everywhere, and I would be talking to a bandit and a dog mauled him during conversation and his bandit buddies would walk away (because freinds stick up for one another right?). I haven't come close to finishing it as I just got to Pripyat in the game, but I can also tell you that the sidequests aren't too repetitive, unoriginal, and boring. The only problems I have so far are the stiff characters and the english voice acting of the AI, but again, there's a mod that has the AI speak russian if you want it to be realistic. The graphics aren't mind blowing (but they are really good none the less and it's always worth killing yourself to watch an emission take place), but if you play for the graphics than you are not welcome here. Once I'm able to finish the game I can talk about the story.

												A worthy successor. It keeps everything that made SoC good but adds a more expansive and living world. It's very well done. There's not much more to be said that I haven't said in my review of SoC. A word of advice to you modders though; before playing the Misery mod (the mod that makes this game more difficult than running through Dark Souls using the broken sword) I'd suggest properly preparing yourself for iminent death. I was torn apart by Pseudodogs within 30 seconds of starting the mod. If you enjoy challenge, immersion, and the previous STALKER games you'll love this one....... and if you enjoy an insane amount of difficulty you should download the Misery mod.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												An awe inspiring experience. The atmosphere and open world enviroment are so immersive, you'll forget it's a game. The firefights are moderately paced, tactical engagements where things such as manpower, stealth, weather, and other little factors play just as much of a role as pointing and shooting. While the story is a solid continuation from SoC, it suffers greatly from very poor english voice-overs, some spotty writing and liberal use of Deus Ex Machinas in side quests and the main story. Overall, this game is a treat. It may not be as flashy as the equally stellar (but more linear) metro series, but if you wanna know where metro took it's inspiration, pick this one up. The great modding community have extended the life of this game very well since it's 2010 release, so definitely check ModDB if you find the time.
