number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												This was the most enjoyable FPS I have ever played. After trying out various mods for this game, I eventually went with Misery Mod 1.0 (2.0 was too much for my wimpy laptop, but I personally think 1.0 was better anyway). I also completed the game on Master difficulty.Modding aside, CoP is a brilliant open-world shooter. While there is a story that the player eventually needs to progress through, the open-world element puts you in control of the pace of the game so you can explore/merc all you want and then perform the essential plotline tasks when you're ready. I loved the idea of three gigantic levels taking the places of seven or eight smaller ones. The gunfights are technical and challenging. The finale of this game is terrific - probably the most intense gunfight I've experienced in a game.By the time I was done with CoP's prequels, I was craving more difficulty, so I installed Misery, which was pretty unforgiving in the early game. It also creates a bleak atmosphere, adds new weapons, and changes the sound a bit. The mod also tweaked the random events, keeping the player on edge. I HIGHLY recommend this game with the Misery mod.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2015
												Although this is my first and only S.T.A.L.K.E.R game I can see how it definitely is in a league of its own. I am a really huge fan of horror games, first person shooters, and open world, and this game puts all of those together beautifully and in such a unique way. Also if you like to push yourself in video games this game is definitely the Dark Souls of FPS and I feel the best way to immerse yourself in this game is to play it on master and if you find it too difficult then that's too bad because that is the life of a S.T.A.L.K.E.R.(plus there's the Misery Mod). Plus I can't count how many times I've been killed by one shot on master difficulty, or how many times I have to repair armor/guns. Also its also the little things in the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. world that can be the most meomorable. I would wonder through the world and stumble upon four other S.T.A.L.K.E.R's playing music and drinking vodka with dead animal carcasses everywhere, and I would be talking to a bandit and a dog mauled him during conversation and his bandit buddies would walk away (because freinds stick up for one another right?). I haven't come close to finishing it as I just got to Pripyat in the game, but I can also tell you that the sidequests aren't too repetitive, unoriginal, and boring. The only problems I have so far are the stiff characters and the english voice acting of the AI, but again, there's a mod that has the AI speak russian if you want it to be realistic. The graphics aren't mind blowing (but they are really good none the less and it's always worth killing yourself to watch an emission take place), but if you play for the graphics than you are not welcome here. Once I'm able to finish the game I can talk about the story.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
												10/10If, before playing the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games, I had described in detail my perfect gaming experience, I doubt I'd have arrived at anything close to Call of Pripyat. Sometimes things fill a gap we never knew we had. Like Pascal's "God-shaped vacuum in the heart of every person", there was a S.T.A.L.K.E.R.-shaped hole in my Steam catalogue. Shadow of Chernobyl, the first game in the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series, is often (and rightly) touted as a flawed but ground-breaking masterpiece. The second, Clear Skies, is all too often disregarded. Call of Pripyat, IMHO, is one of those rare instances when the third in a trilogy improves on what has come before. Some have pointed to a superior story in Shadow of Chernobyl, and this is a natural impression given by the novelty of the first in a series. The burdens heaped on the difficult third of the trilogy's shoulders (following an already classic first and an almost universally panned second) were daunting. That it can stand alone as a masterpiece, and take pride of place in the trilogy that birthed it, is truly impressive.The sandbox, free-roaming FPS skeleton of the game is all but flawless. Gone are the irritating and frequent zone-transitions of the first two games - the map is divided into three instanced zones, but within those zones the travel is seamless. It is a rich and believable world, but you will require a fast CPU and/or installing game on an SSD to avoid micro-pauses every so often as you move through the map. Mob AI is vastly improved upon, and, despite all three games in the series using the same "X-Ray" engine, CoP's graphics are an improvement beyond what could be expected. Call of Pripyat's cast of weapons and armors are as loveable, believable, and as almost-touchable as the characters. Weapons are almost all faithful renditions of the NATO and Warsaw Pact arsenals, with nods and developments to the alternate history STALKER narrates. No min/max table lurks behind the equipment; no backwards-engineered dps spreadsheet. Instead, a well-balanced cast of items, with pros and cons emerging naturally from the real-world items they reproduce.Like the two S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games that preced it, Call of Pripyat mods extremely well. The modding community has developed a catalogue of astounding size, quality and diversity. As is usual for a well-modded game, some mods almost inarguably improve on the game, some add extra content, while a few simply break the experience. I recommend playing through without mods first. After gauging the experience, I recommend either MISERY, a massive and thorough reworking of the game; or if you prefer to retain the gameplay and difficulty of the vanilla game while improving on the graphics, a combination of mods such as Atmosfear, Absolute Nature and Absolute structures, and Particle Paradise will yield excellent returns. Although the "Complete" mods are sound for the first two S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games, I cannot recommend the CoP Complete Mod. It significantly dumbs-down the combat, while implementing graphical tweaks either similar or inferior to those previously mentioned.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2014
												Call of Pripyat is a mixed bag. It incorporates the gameplay and graphical improvements of Clear Sky and introduces new and large areas to explore. It's also the most polished and bug-free of the STALKER games. But at the same time it seems to have lost its spirit: the game is very unchallenging and the Zone doesn't feel like the oppressive and bleak place it should be anymore.Despite its shortcomings Call of Pripyat is recommendable simply because it works. It has a lot of content in both items and quests, it's very free-roam right from the start and it's overall the most accessible of the three games.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R Call of Pripyat like the rest of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R series, is a cross between the fps and rpg genres. It takes place in Chernobyl Ukraine after a second disaster which unleashes all kinds of horrific crap into the Chernobyl exclusion zone. Now i will say that the story is kind of lackluster, and the game it's self can be rather punishing for a new player, but once you get the hang of it the game offers a good balance between making you feel like the god of the apocalypse, and a scared Bunny who just want's to live though the day. But the best thing about this game is it's atmosphere, it really helped me get into the world they've built, and plus most of the in-game locations are modeled after their real world counterparts so it feels almost like you are actually walking though the dead city of pripyat. Another great thing about this game is that for the most part, you can do whatever you feel like doing, and explore a large open and mutant filled world, with alot of upgradable and customizable Guns and Suits. Well i know this review was kind of long and i probably only scratched the surface of what this game is, but i think that about covers the basics and i just want to finish by saying i loved every second of this game.

												[Warning, Walls of text incoming, also, this is gameplay only, I had a much longer review planned]The GameplayThis is easily STALKER's strongest point. To put it frankly, it's awesome. The open world is fun to roam around, the locations are all unique, the way they handle the difficulties is very cool, and using the guns feels very nice, even if some of them do sound like pea-shooters. To go in to a bit more detail:	The game starts you off with a bit of food and medical supplies, a light vest, a gasmask, a pistol, and an AKS. All equipment has a durability meter. Now don't worry, that's just equipment, so your grenades, medpacks, and food will remain in tip-top shape. Lower durability means lowered stats, and if it's a gun, it may jam at the most inconvenient times. Durability lowers either by taking damage, or shooting. Do yourself a favor and shoot in single fire mode, as that helps you both control your shots better, and saves on durability. Your inventory consists of the storage, your helmet and armor slots, and your 2 gun slots. Do note that certain armor takes up both the armor and helmet slot, so watch what you wear. Your 2 gun slots can carry whatever you want, it's not limited to primary and pistol. You could have any combo, the choice is yours. Your inventory automatically extends, so you can carry what you want. The only thing that will get in your way, is the weight limit. At the beginning I think it's about 50kg. Going over that limit over-encumbers you, causing you to move slower, and sprinting drains your stamina really really fast. Going 10kg or above the weight limit will cause you to stop moving all-together, meaning you'll have to drop some items if you wish to move at all. You can, however, get drugs that temporarily increase your carry weight, and you can upgrade certain armor to increase the carry weight. I'm pretty sure some armor comes with a base carry weight increase, though I haven't taken the time to check that out. Throughout the game you will battle Zombies, Snorks, Burers, Blind dogs, Boars, Pseudo-Dogs, Rodents, Bloodsuckers, etc. Sure, there's Flesh monsters, but what you do to them is more akin to Genocide than Battling. You'll also encounter Anomalies. These are rather odd entities that, depending on the anomaly, can do all sorts of things. Some are simply pillars of flame triggered by movement, others do such crazy things as teleport you, or even trap an entire squad in a world of emptiness. And by the way, that's a side-mission that you can easily miss. Most of the anomalies are found in, quite obviously, anomaly fields. 	Now you might ask yourself, "Well why would I go to an insanely dangerous area filled with the oddities of an already strange world that could practically rip me apart?" Well the answer, is Artifacts. Artifacts are strange items scattered throughout the world. They are found only in Anomaly fields, with 2 exceptions. Exception 1 is certain scripted artifacts, exception 2 is when you get the prototype detector. With the prototype detector out, you can detect them out in the open, albeit very rarely. Artifacts are extremely useful in that you can either sell them for varying amounts of money, depending on how rare they are, or you can equip them, if your vest has the slots for it. The only downside to equiping them is they usually give a fair amount of radiation every second, so it's best to get some radiation-reducing artifacts before working on the more useful ones. The upside is a lot of the artifacts have some rather good effects, just make sure to mouse over them and see just what they are. But what do you do then? What do you do when there's no more Artifacts to find? Well, that's where Emissions come in. I mentioned these earlier, but now I'll explain what they do and what they are. Emissions are the result of the Zone basically releasing any excess energy. They happen every day at a random time, and when they begin to form, you'll hear all sorts of crazy sounds, and see the clouds forming in a strange way. Seconds later you should get a PDA side-mission telling you to find cover, along with a radio broadcast telling all stalkers an emission is approaching. You have around 2-3 In-game minutes to find cover, which is marked on your minimap, before the emission hits the land. Anyone caught outside either dies, or turns into a zombie. Another way to tell an emission is approaching is monitoring the mutant activity. Mutants spawn more often both before and after emissions. You can survive these while outside though, you just need Anabiotics. If you survive 3 emissions with these, you'll be immune to them, though they will drain your health like crazy and you will black out. After an emission is the most important part though. After any emission, artifacts have a very large chance of respawning at Anomaly fields, empty or not.	Now that I've covered Emissions, let's move on to something I mentioned while I was talking about them. Achivements. These are not normal achivements though, these ones have in-game advantages and disadvantages. One gives you medical supplies every day in your personal box, another gives you AMMO everyday, but spawns more dangerous mutants, and another spawns rarer artifacts much more often, but causes bandits to sometimes fight you. Of course there is some that are just there to be achivements and nothing more. One in particular was supposed to do something, specifically the one you get for exposing Magpie, but because of a programing error, it doesn't do anything. So far, it hasn't been fixed, and seeing as GSC Game World was disbanded, I don't expect a fix anytime soon. 	Now going a little deeper in to how the game works, everything has Stats, technically making this game an Open-World RPG. Guns have the usual stats like damage, accuracy, and even Flatness, which decreases the arc of the bullet. Armor has stuff like radiation resistance, psy resistance, armor, chemical protection, et cetera. A nice feature is that certain guns can have attachments. You know, the usual, like grenade launchers, scopes, and silencers. As for movement, it's all the usual, but with a few tweaks. For instance, you can lean left and right with Q and E. You also have 3 stances, but the last one isn't the one you expect. Standing, crouch, and low-crouch, which is basically prone but a slight bit faster. And no, there is no prone stance. For fighting mutants, and especially humans, it's best to try and get headshots, as they'll 1-shot most humans and do a good chunk more damage to mutants. If YOU get hit, you have a large chance to Bleed, which will drain your health until it's fixed. There's 3 color-coded degrees to bleeding. Green, your health goes down slowly, and you can just leave it and it should fix itself up in a couple of seconds, yellow is when you should apply bandages, as your health drops faster, and red is when you HAVE to apply bandages, as your health will be gone in a matter of seconds. The game also has hunger, so on top of the emissions, the mutants, the anomalies, the bandits, and your equipment's durability, you gotta make sure you had your mini-wheats for breakfast. Thankfully, they downplay it quite a lot, so you only really need to eat either when you sleep for more than a few hours, or if you are adventuring for a LONG time.<Score>And that's really the basics [and a bit of the advanced] of the gameplay, I don't really know what to say other than, it's STALKER's strongest point, with atmosphere being VERY close behind it. It's easily a 10/10.<Final game score>9/10This is one of the best games I've ever played, and I will continue to play it until the day I die. My final thoughts would have to be:If Fallout 3/New Vegas had a baby with the Metro Series, you'd get this.

												I was kinda disappointed, even though they added some new great things, it had me longing for the original SoC game play. I don't think some things were 100% finnished, and it seems to really need mods to help the game play, which isn't good or bad but for me, personally, but I had a hard time getting the right mods together. In vanilla gameplay, the first things I realized were wrong were the ak-74u and the gun sounds. They were waaay to quite, kinda unsatisfyng, Thankfully theres a mod for that that isn't so hard to find. The ak-74u on the other hand just looked wierd, the ejection port was on the left side; I had to watch poorly renderd casings come out the wrong side of the gun. A.I., of course, is also bad. It needed mods. Once I got to modding I saw a lot of great mods, or from the cover they look good. A lot of recent bad reviews kept me from the bigger mods (misery, complete, ect.) so I looked for mods with good reviews. the SGM mods (both 2.2 and geo) were o.k. but still not the expirince I was looking for, So then I tried the a couple of mod packs. Some had this others had that, none were good enough. Now, I finnialy tried misery 2.0 and it was actully really good. Over all, I give it a 8.5/10 after getting misery, amazing realistic, horror survival game play.Then I got the "killer mod pack" now it's a 9.5/10, at least.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												The game has been out for several years now, and this won't be a review on the game itself.Rather this is a review of the excellent MISERY 2.1 mod I had installed recently.MISERY is a "hardcore survival overhaul" mod for STALKER: COP, which sets out to do just that. And it does.Guns that you loot from enemies are now in very poor condition, it's FAR more expensive to repair them or to buy new guns/ammo. NPC's will meet a gruesome end during emissions, which force you to take cover in a good-sized building or meet that end yourself. To top that off, emissions are frequent occurrences in the game, breaking out every 9-12 hours of in-game time.Furthermore, stealth is vastly improved, all character voices are Russian rather than English. And you can even specialize in one of 3 classes added by the mod, each with their own required playstyle.The list of changes added by the mod is too large to list here in a review, so I'll include a link to the mod's guide below.http://www.miserymod.com/?p=1462MISERY turns STALKER into an enormous challenge, and I highly recommend it if you have the nads for it :)

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												Atmosphere. Something that is so important in many games and something that Stalker completely nails right from the start. You begin the game on a lonely hillside and (if your PC is up to the challenge) the whole bleak and scary Pripyat region opens up around you. An urgency sets in that makes you desperate to reach the dim point of light in the distance that marks one of the few safe havens in the Zone. I've played through the game a few times since its release and even now I can't quite put my finger on how they managed to make even the open daylit areas so scary - and then you reach a point were the games narrative demands you go under ground and the fear just seeps out of the game in a wonderful adrenaline fueled way. You'll jump at every noise and wave your torch about in panic. For a game to make you feel insignificant and unprotected even when you are packing an automatic machine gun and plenty of ammo is a triumph in game design. Is it a FPS? Yes, and I for one enjoyed the rather clunky combat as it added to the realism. Is it an RPG? Yes, and the search for better gear and better anomoly upgrades to help combat the Zone will force you to brave the most dangerous areas. Above all, for me, this game is an adventure survival game. From the moment I stepped into the Zone I felt that I was simply trying to survive in a way that many other 'survival games' fail to achieve. The Zone is the enemy here - and it is trying to kill youIf you like your games atmospheric then I wholly recommend Stalker - it is absolutely dripping in it

content:
Posted: January 17, 2012
												Probably the best unmodded Stalker game. You can't go wrong with this either. The atmosphere is still there, and it can still be very challenging on Master. You don't really need any gameplay mods for this on your first playthrough, but you can use Atmosfear, and Absolute Nature and Absolute Structures to improve the visuals. Make sure to turn off Nuclear Fallout and Psy Emissions in Atmosfear, those are crap. If you want a much harder early game experience, try the Misery mod. If you want tons of added content, use SGM.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2013
												STALKER: Call of Pripyat (CoP)Another excellent installment in the STALKER series. I love these games - they succeed in combining FPS and RPG gameplay like no other. When pressed to describe the STALKER games, I find it easiest to explain them as "RPGs without all the fiddly bits." You have quests and inventory, but no stats and levels. There's no inflating abilities with experience points - everything you do, you do to move the game along, not to build a gold stash or level up for a boss fight.CoP is the most polished of the three STALKER games. Not easier, though - combat is still challenging, and ammo scarce. But the quests are more linear, with fewer distractions as you move through the story. I approve of that streamlining, as CoP has more story to tell than the other two games. Total game time here is the same as the others... roughly 30 hours, give or take, depending on how much you choose to accomplish.Why I enjoy the STALKER series so much is that they delver a plausible game world. When you explore, you will find distant locations that have no bearing on the game's story, yet are meticulously crafted. Unlike most RPGs, you don't feel like the center of the universe. Instead, you feel like a visitor to a world that has been there before you arrived, and will continue after you leave. And dangerous! Here is a game where you stay on the roads, and seek shelter at night. A game where a pack of wild dogs is actually as dangerous as it should be. Each NPC has a name, and goes about his own life in the Zone. CoP plays this to the extreme - when the game ends, you are treated to a slideshow that describes what becomes of roughly 20 NPCs that you will encounter through the game. For each character, his denoument is affected by your interaction with him. I found this very rewarding.My one gripe is that CoP plays down the faction wars that were such a big part of STALKER: Clear Sky. I missed picking sides between Freedom and Duty. But all of the familiar factions are present in this game. Freedom and Duty have reached an easy peace. Stalkers and Bandits are still two sides of the same coin. And Monolith is still a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥Yes, I do recommend this game. And as always, STALKER games are best with their accompanying "Complete" mod. These mods bring higher-quality graphics and sound, and excellent weather effects to the STALKER series, without changing the core game. They also minimize some of the repetitive NPC quotes you hear in the game. They are a must, even for first playthrough. Link: http://www.moddb.com/mods/call-of-pripyat-completeLooking forward to Survarium.... http://survarium.com/

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												If I had to choose between the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games, I'd pick Call of Pripyat. Many good features from the previous games have been polished such as trading, upgrading items, combat, artifact detection and collection, and even questing. The plot and ending really got to me.The open world is an issue. The pacing of progression between questing areas is a bit of a different flavor from previous games. In Call of Pripyat, your progress between zones is limited by story progression. This is in contrast to SoC where your exploration was (mostly) only limited by progressively more difficult opponents and anomalies. On the other hand, while CoP locks you into a zone, it's not exactly a small space. Later in the game, you'll even find yourself with reasons to go back to previous areas for bonuses and min/maxing.The RPG element has been well polished as well. The importance of your equipment choices cannot be understated. With a wide variety of weapons, armor, attachments and modification trees (like talent trees!), consumables, and artifacts(stat altering) your options are quite vast. There are many situations in the game where the proper equipment can turn a fevered fight for survival into a even back and fourth or perhaps little challange at all.As a STALKER game it would be poor form for me not to comment on the atmosphere. This is something I feel Call of Pripyat, like it's predecessors, did very well. At a glace, some may see only a melancholy dystopia sprinkled with shock and a little horror, but there's so much more to it. While the darkness and gloom are very evident, beneath the surface lies the subtle thrill of being on the edge of an unexplored frontier with somthing to discover around every corner. You never know who or what you'll run into next.The themes behind the game and STALKER in general are fairly mature. For all the good in the game, it's still (IMO) dark, gritty, and brutally honest about "might" and it's connection to what is "right". There is good in this world, but it's few and far between. As for the plot, it certainly helps to have experience in the previous games. From the get-go you're aware your character's motivation is ethically dubious at best. To his credit, the MC grows and confronts these issues making him seem more relatable.If you want a full experience I recommend you play the previous STALKER games first. There are plenty of references and even an important character or two. Problem is, I don't believe any of these games have aged particularly well graphically or mechanically. But if you can suffer though some imperfections, the experience is worth it.One final and important note, there are some good mods for Call of Pripyat as well as previous games. If you manage to get though the game, modding is definitely a way to expand re-playability.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												I am so very torn by this game it's unreal. I can't love this game and yet I want to, I can't hate it and yet I want to. I suppose I was just so excited at the premise of an open world shooter set in Pripyat, the idea alone is worth so much and yet I find myself ambivalent. It's really fun to explore the dark, depressing but not tense world of post-Chernobyl Pripyat (and the outlying areas, you don't actually REACH Pripyat until much later) but it feels so sparse. I know you'd expect that sort of thing from an irradiated area but it feels like a few meagre locations interspersed with mostly identical grassland with the occasional swamp or trees or anomaly, it works from a canonical standpoint but I feel it cheapens the whole "open world" aspect. The almost utter lack of voice acting prbably wouldn't have bothered me so much except it makes it impossible to distinguish people. They have no personality of which to speak and whatever voice acting you DO get is at best okay (sometimes you can CLEARLY hear the same person switch between two different voice actors, one in English and one in Russian), I really feel as if the NPC's in this game are a serious impediment to the enjoyment of what is otherwise quite a fine game. Gunplay is a bit turgid, the guns don't really have much feeling to them and there's no real discernible differences in firepower within the same class of firearm. All the pistols are like peashooters to most enemies, shotguns are okay and so on, although I kind of liked the Gauss Rifle which brings me to another issue in the area of sound. Most of it is actually quite good, especially at night when it gets actually really atmospheric with rather haunting animal noises, crickets and a bit of fairly repetitive but good background music. But a lot of the audio sounds so uninspired and boring, especially gunfire (with particular note to the Gauss Rifle, it sounds terrible), item noises sometimes don't make sense and can get repetitive (although that is understandable). The ending was also really abrupt and very unsatisfactory. Yet despite its many failings this game has quite a bit to offer the discerning gamer, even if I can't quite elucidate my reasons for liking it. All I can say it's atmospheric, the world is pretty good looking if sparse and the concept of anomalies and stuff in Pripyat is interesting and quite engaging. This game might not live up to its potential but it is worth your time. I sincerely hope they get some experienced devs to make the sequel this IP deserves.EDIT: I suppose in retrospect this review looked quite negative, but this is a really engrossing game at times and the fact that there's no hand holding or explanation of which to speak means that it's on you to figure everything out and that's always a plus for immersion. If it's ever on sale do buy this game, for all its flaws it is still a good game.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
												now this wont be a full reveiw upon first writing but im going over the baisics of what i want to say ( becuase ive got a dam lot to say about this game i mean look at this intro :D )The S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Series as always been my favourite series of games for a number of reasons, whether it is the crazy amount of weird and wonderful guns, suits and items, or the weird and whacky storyline, i love almost everything about this game , and i will say why now.Story:one of my favourite parts about the stalker games is the story lines that always seem to have a big twist at the end or something like that. Anyway, the story in CoP is really quite cool how they made it all play out, one of the best bits is being able to see how you affected every other stalkers life while you were in the zone at the end of the game with about 20 or so slides telling you about what happend after you left the zone.Weaponry:With a decent selection of weaponry for all play styles, this game can make you play through it many times just so you can play around with the guns and ammo types ( two for each gun except the PKM, Sniper rifles and the RPG ). from shotguns to expermental gaus rifles, this game unmodded provided me with atleast 70 hours before i even thought about modding it.Suits / Armour:Stalker has system whereby you can wear suits that affect your carry weight, protection for various envriomental hazards, gunfire and can effect your mobility. CoP by far offers the most diverse Suit system by allowing the player to (with most suits) mix and match head gear and main body suits depending on your play style, (gas masks for artifact hunters, military helmets for combat, and high-end mixes of both). There is a massive variety of upgrades that can completley changes the suits performance (Servos on an exoskeleton, alloying you to sprint).Upgrading your equipment:CoP allows you to collect tool kits and gie them to technicians, who will reward you with the ability to upgrade your guns and suits more (and a small cash reward). You can turn a AK-74 into a laser fast firing assault cannon, or make it a more accurate mid range sniper.still wip

												This is my opinion.S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is like an art to me. It really captured the sense of Russia in an apocalyptic stage. It has some open world elements to is with a very good story. It might seem a little old for the new gamers but once you get in to it than I’ll think they will share my vision. The coolest part of the staler series I think is the psy damage you can take. That moment there is some kind of anomaly that makes you insane, making you hear voices and makes you see things there aren’t there. And the emisions  make you feel like you have to outrun a nuclear explosion. next to that there are more kids of damages you could receive like burns, poison damage, bleeding damage, radiation, starvation, shock damage, Rupture (from mutants animals), and explosion damage.The mutants are quite scary and you can always hear them from a far adding to the horror element of the game. Some mutants turn invisible and become visible again once close to you trying to suck you blood. Other mutants try to control you brain. And that really makes me♥♥♥♥♥♥bricks.Call of Pripyat is one is one of the few series that S.T.A.L.K.E.R. has to offer. What I did miss in the game was the ability to join factions just like in S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Clear sky. I really do recommend the game.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												An atmospheric shooter based in the aftermath of the nuclear catastrophe in Chernobyl, with the slight twist of mutants, lethal anomalies, warring factions and other delightful treats. The combat with humans involves high damage, bullet drop and cover to cover stressful gun battles. Mutants meanwhile, require a certain level of awareness and responsiveness as the different mutants require adapting tactics with haste. The game also includes survival elments such as hunger, radiation and the like. Exploration plays a key role in getting equipment to survive the various trials the game throws at you, as does interaction with the various factions. The graphics are a bit dated, but there are mods to deal with that, and if you find the game too easy, there are also mods to tweak the difficulty to provide a more challenging, rewording experience. Overall, 8/8.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												--This is a neutral review from someone who is not familiar with the S.T.A.L.K.E.R series--S.T.A.L.K.E.R is a series I really want to get into because the community isn't stupid and the game looks damn good but the older S.T.A.L.K.E.R games are a bit to old for my liking so I got this one becuase its the latest.Now I tried to get into this game, I really did but Christicle on a bicycle this is hard, the game gives you a little bit of backstory and then dumps you in a field. This appears to be one of those games that you learn about the hard way, for example every now and then something called an Emission explodes across the whole map and wipes out everyone, I found myself getting killed over and over again by the first Emission until I eventually gave up and Googled it, I discovered that you have to hide underground in order to escape it...I guess this is just the cruel nature of this game because it gives you little to no information on anything, not even the basic mechanics are revealed to you and you have to study up everything just like Dark Souls.The atmosphere in this game is astonishing and I have never seen a game come even close to the dark, creepy and radioactive atmosphere that this game has, I spent most of my time too afriad to enter buildings because of the various sanity destroying sounds coming out of them.S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Call of Pripyat is a game I really want to get into but the difficulty and various mechanics that I know nothing about keeps scaring me away from it. Some people say that this game is a Fallout 3 ripoff and I find that really offensive because the developers must of worked really hard on this game and I feel like they didn't get the respect/money that they deserved because this game is different and somewhat ahead of its time.Now get out of here Stalker!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19
												This is aside of the Borderlands-series the only open world-game I really enjoyed and that didn't start to be boring after a certain amount of time. It manages to capture this postapocalyptic feeling in a much more realistic way than for example the Fallout series and the constant feel of danger. As, how the game puts it: Not the factions or the mutants are your true enemy here. The Zone itself is what truly wants to kill you, spit on your corpse and kick you out again. And this hostile environment is in no other game better captured than in the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series. Especially the beginning until you have your first "real" gear the zone will toy with you like your a dandelion seed in a hurricane. PROS:+ So far the perfect example of "hostile environment"+ Manages to convey the dullness and loneliness+ Gun play is good+ Incredible amounts of mods - recommend you to go to modDB since they should have most mods up there+ Due to being quite old it also runs on potatoes+ Graphics can be pushed with mods to look decent even nowadays, especially ATMOSF.E.A.R. - a weather mod does a tremendous job CONS:- Especially on higher difficulties (and with difficulty-increasing mods) very unforgiving- You will die a lot in the beginning as the game has the same concept of a "tutorial" as the Souls-series (none)- Nothing for those with problems with jump scares - not as much as the game does it on purpose, but you WILL sometimes just hear a mutant a split second before it is on top of you

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												Why does monolith call?I got fallout 3 right when it came out and every expansion when available as well. I thought that was the epitome of survival wasteland fps/rpg gaming. Then I find this stalker shadow of Chernobyl game and think generic knockoff. After going through stalker 1.0 with all the weird bugs however, I soon realized this was fallout on steroids.The mood of the game, the difficulty (initially), even the lighting was exceptional. Also, what I'd call the rpg elements of getting better gear felt more natural as opposed to leveling stats on my guy in fallout. Walking around the metro shooting ghouls with the terrible shotgun whilst paused in v.a.t.s. pales in comparison to going into the labs around Chernobyl. Chernobyl had zombies but also included cloaking bloodsuckers lurking behind you, snorks ready to pounce, a behemoth flesh creature, along with mutated dogs, poltergeists, and various other startling abominations.Clear sky brought in the interesting concept of modifying weapons and factions. That was about all Clear Sky offered save for an upgrade to the Xray engine. Oddly enough, the factions were lost with the next installmentNow with the most refined version of Call of Pripyat what was interesting before is even better.  Hunting in anomalies for artifacts using a detection device and throwing bolts is a very interesting way of essentially mining the environment. Secret stashes that can be found at any time without prerequisite was a good addition. Call of Pripyat also saw a better structured campaign. SoC was too loose, CS was to linear, CoP to me is just right. Though don't get me wrong the game in all iterations is open roaming, but CS felt like walking through levels and SoC had areas of no interest.I've just been playing a heavily modified Call of Pripyat and it's almost like a new game again. the mods give it a high replay ability factor. Sneaking into a mercenary base and taking out heavy geared mercs then looting everything is oddly satisfying. Then, trying to walk back in complete darkness to sell loot with all manner of hostile creatures about is icing on the cake. I recommend anyone interested in good games to play this.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2011
												It doesn't have quite the oppressive, loner atmosphere that characterized the first game, but mods (in particular, Misery) easily fill in that void. This game has three very large open areas to explore and a great deal of handcrafted, well-scripted quests as opposed to the endlessly generated "go here, fetch that" quests that were the daily fare of the previous two games.The overall plot arc isn't as interesting as its predecessors, but it does reference them well. It also has several endings, Fallout slideshow style, based upon your involvement throughout the game, which lends towards a satisfying conclusion and encourages replayability. Call of Pripyat is the culmination of the systems introduced in the previous two games - setting, gameplay mechanics, and introduces an extra layer of attention to detail and care that pushes it above its predecessors.\I'd call it the most complete S.T.A.L.K.E.R. experience. If you play only one of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games, pick this one.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												The STALKER series is notorious for being an amaziing immersive astmospheric mix of FPS, RPG and Horror. Call of Pripyat is by far the best in the series when it comes to guns and ccombat. Finding a gun you really like and being able to upgrade your weapon to how you want and putting your life and trust into one gun to help survive out in the harsh world of STALKER makes the atmosphere and immersion far beyond any FPS game has ever even came close to. The world of Pripyat makes for a great RPG and creepy atmoshere. Creeping around at night in the dark with all the horrible sounds going on around you makes you really appreciate a good atmosphere in a game and also that your gun is fully loaded and your reflexes are fast enough to be ready for what could be coming at your through the darkness at any moment. Open world and plenty of side quests and NPC to make for a great RPG and enough guns to keep you playing for hours. Although the story starts off pretty good, it ends pretty weak compared to Shadow of Chernobyl, which has an amazing story with 13 endings! DDo yourself a favor and buy the whole series and then download STALKER Complete for each game. These are bug fix mods and tweaks. They fix most if the major glitches and problems the vanilla games have. Also, check out LURK ffor Shadow Chernobyl and Misery for Call of Pripyat for the best possible way to play STALKER - Shadow of Chernoyble and STALKER Call of Pripyat.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												The third installment in the series and clearly the superior in manny ways. The only problem I have with Call of Pripyat is the lack of exploration, and since I played each STALKER game in order I feel that this one reverted from the progress they made from 1st to the 2nd game in the series. I feel like there is much less to do but much more cluttering side stuff. It feels like an RPG more so than the previous. I still however recommend this highly due to the general feeling of the game, smaller but more packed. Mods are also quite supported and I will recommend that you do a second playthrough with the "Misery" mod installed.Overall: Same as all the other games in the series a must have  but it feels very distant due to the missing of actuall chernobyl for some reason. 9/10... GET OUT OF HERE STALKER!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												I think that (without a shadow of a doubt) that this is the best game I have ever played. FACT. I've played many games both on PC and on console, but really the whole S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series is one of my favorite game series of all time. As soon as I bought the game and started playing it, I was in love with the game.I love how the game is EXTREMELY atmospheric. I think if it had Occulus Rift compatibility, I would definitely break some windows with my screams of terror. The AI is a little (ahem) crazy, but there are many modded overhauls for this game, such as MISERY, Call of Pripyat Complete, and more. If you want a challenging, atmospheric, IMMERSIVE game, I'd say that every S.T.A.L.K.E.R. game is going to be perfect for you.The downfalls of really each of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games is the lack of multiple weapons. There are only a good few weapons in the game, but getting the MISERY mod overhaul will definitely add several weapons to the game. The graphics (texture-wise) are pretty good for its time when the game came out. However, the lighting, especially for S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Call of Pripyat, is PHENOMENAL. The lighting uses DirectX 11, to bring the most satisfying lighting effects for any game, maybe even for some next-gen console & PC games.To make this all short:Yes. Buy the game. This series has what some components of Fallout should've been. Once you play it, you'll see exactly what I mean.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												This is definatly one of the most fullfilling games I have ever played. The S.T.A.L.K.E.R series in my opinion has very few flaws to begin with. Add the Modding community behind it and any percieveable flaws vanish and what is left is the near perfection that all games should aspire to achieve. Very much its own brand, the game has 4 shining stars that make it so great.     Frist and foremost is the atmosphere created right from the get go.  No other game has as believeable an astmosphere as the S.T.A.L.K.E.R series. Very engaging and at times frightening.  Getting ambushed by whatever whenever is an experience players shouldn't be left not having and stalker lets ya have it......alot..like seriously. Fire fights are quite amazing and requires  strategy to over come.  Another star atribute this game possesses and the open sand box aproach to FPS.  You can go anywhere you want on the three maps, which are giant. There are some "dungeons" to be explored to but most gameplay takes place in the open areas. Now i say open areas I really mean on one of the three main maps that are mainly countryside or urbana areas.  Because it is sandbox you can choose whether or not to mess with the missions or if you want to just explore and shoot ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and monsters.  To open the other 2 map areas some missions are required but after that you are free to do as you please. At the end of the game you can also choose to end it or continue to explore and do as you please.  Looting. pretty much all I have to say. The inventory system in this is great. You can take ammo, armor, medkits, food, energy supplements, weapons, and artifacts from downed foes and add them to your collection. More shooters are starting to do such with looting and inventory and I positivly agree with it and the first fps i remember playing with such a system was the S.T.A.L.K.E.R series. I love the blend of FPS and RPG games.    Ballistics. Some don't even know what it means. But S.T.A.L.K.E.R sure does. believe it or not the game engine has a ballistics calculator.  When you fire a round in game it has bullet drop and starts loosing energy at a distance. They really couldnt do alot with it since true ballistics would need wind drift, atmosphereic pressure, temperature and other variables into account that would take alot of man power and computer power to put in a game, but modders have been playing with this and have done some pretty awesome stuff.  I would recommend this to any and all gamers if you got the balls to survive the Zone

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												Great game, nearly as good as the orginal game. It's been awhile since I've played the orignal but I only have fond memories of it. Playing 'Call of Pripyat' let me relive those great memories but in a new game. If you liked the orginal I can almost guarantee you'll be happy. Solid 4 out of 5 stars! I hope to see a remake of STALKER some day.Pros- Very much like the original (from what I can remember)- Challenging- Variety of "Shooters" to give you playing options- Shooting mechanics tweaked. I remember the original having an annoying problem of bullets flying too random and never straight.- Enemies do a good job of keeping you on your toes. Always loved the idea of psychic dogs- The survival aspects add to the game but are not overwhelming (Bleeding, eating, weight management, etc.)Cons- World is maybe a little small; could use a little more variety- More enemy variety- Why do zombies shoot so straight- More anomolies & artifacts- This is an older game so graphics are dated and somewhat kills the immersion. It's hard to believe that when playing the original I couldn't get over how good the graphics were- The same oddly shaped pink "diet sausage"...  could be Pro...?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2012
												This game is a jewel of the genre of apocalyptic games, and escpecially S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series. UI is practical and simple, storyline is very good (but wish it was longer), new graphics engine really brings the game to the table. And that atmosphere....This is why S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games have fans all around the world. The atmosphere in this game is simply amazing, it makes you want to put hundreds and hundreds of hours of gameplay even after you finish the game.Great thing is that this series has also a very big modding community, so it is always interesting to play. Be that a graphics/weather mods (i.e. Atmosfear 3), arsenal mods, overall improvment of the game (Complete mod), or global mods which create an entirely new storyline. There are easily a couple of hundred hours on this game. I would recommend it to everyone, especially people who like post-apocalyptic genre, realism, atmosphere, and simply a well made game. My rating: 15 out of 10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												Call of Pripyat is a game that is a natural sequel to ShoC. Although it has fewer areas to explore, the amount of detail in each is staggering and the design is much more open, leading to less running into fences and what not. The addition of Blowouts is a great touch, and the roleplaying takes a queue from Fallout this time around, lending itself to more decisions on how to side with, and the benefits for doing so.You can also repair weapons and the mods you can acquire are much, much more numerous and functional, beyond simple silencer + scope + gl. A lot of dummied out features make a return, from unused weapons, armor, enemise, and lore-elements. The anomalies are also much more dangerous.Again, the AI is a complaint. It is equal parts smart (dogs will form packs against you and hunt you down, human ai will flank you) and dumb (human ai in an emission has weird priorities, choosing to casually walk to safe cover rather than running like mad).Well worth the purchase.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												Before reading this review make sure you’ve read my reviews of the previous games: Shadow of Chernobyl http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561197984765152/recommended/4500/Clear sky http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561197984765152/recommended/20510/(And just like with the previous games, I played this on the highest difficulty and WITHOUT MODS, don’t spend your time complaining about that)   Call of Pripyat is the last game in the series which happens a few years after Shadow of Chernobyl.You play as Major  Alexander Degtyarev, who is sent in to investigate the failure of this operation which the reasons why are extremely anti-climactic and the ending leaves you somewhat disappointed, in fact the story in this game is made to quite existent but it just ends up falling flat on its face onto a turd. Call of Pripyat does add in a few new things: on the map areas are now highlighted with a bubble, the hunger system was brought back and emissions happen on a somewhat regular basis and you must take shelter and wait for them to be over. Call of Pripyat also improves a few things as well: now the gunplay is so much better than before, weapons jam a lot less than clear sky, and it only takes one bandage or med kit to stop you from bleeding out when clear sky it took a random amount of healing items.Just like the previous games this is a strangely compelling game but it still comes with a few issues:Everything weighs more in this game and you’ll be over the weight limit quite a lot in this game so you’ll be walking everywhere instead of running, when in the previous games you could carry two assault rifles, one sub machinegun, one handgun, one shotgun and a stack of ammo and healing items, when in Call of Pripyat I was over the limit on just having two assault rifles, one handgun, and a stack of ammo and healing items.With gunfights it’s still very random on whether the enemies will hit you or not and how much damage they dish out to you. And lastly this game does get quite boring at times since to begin with the mission objectives are really, really boring, since it’s usually go here examine object, and that the landscape is very baron and there’s quite a lack of enemies around. This is a fairly good game and getting this comes down to whether you can be patient with it otherwise you’ll probably be too bored to play it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												The third and last in the series (both by release date and chronologically), Call of Pripyat is by far the most polished vanilla game in the series. Unlike the prior two, in which a vanilla playthrough of the game was... bearable, while mods made them excellent, Call of Pripyats vanilla playthrough is perfectly fine, although mods still greatly improve the game. The story continues, and although starts a separate storyline (of sorts) it does tie in to Strelok's own storyline, and with that it indirectly ties in to that of Scar's. Much like the previous two, mods can absolutely change your experience with this game, whether you're just downloading mods to help optimize the game or change it completely, Call of Pripyat has far more complete overhaul style mods than the last two, almost turning it into a different game. Misery, for example, is probably one of if not the most well known of then, which turns Call of Pripyat into a hardcore survival game that will truly test you. This, again, not  only allows for a user to tailor the gameplay to their preference (and its performance to their rig), but also adds a ton of replayability.Much like the last two in the series it is excellent with tons of replayability and a great story to boot, worth every penny.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2013
												After spending more than a year playing the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games I finally completed the trilogy.  It took me so long, I think, because I was almost afraid to play the games sometimes.  Not in a scary game sort of way but in a I-never-want-this-to-end sort of way.  I didn't want to proceed until I felt I'd fully absorbed certain elements of the story.  The choices you are forced to make in the games are compelling and have had a lasting effect on me.  I'm am a little sad that the journey is over for now.CoP seemed to differ from the previous games in that it was a fair amount more approachable to newcomers.  The first two games were unforgiving and had a marginally tough learning curve.  GSC prettied up the HUD a little, which made managing your character less of a chore.  But the gameplay was still the awesome gameplay from the first two games and the story was just as compelling as SoC.I can't recommend these games enough.  Play them now.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												Fallout 3 has always been my favorite game of all time. If you're a fan of the recent fallout games then you will fall in love with Stalker Call of Pripyat. This game honestly blows me away (Litterally, in-game). The atmosphere is wonderfully eerie, especially at night.Pair this game with the Call of Pripyat Complete Mod and you will ejaculate on your keyboard while crapping your pants. The mod will enhance the atmosphere and gameplay greatly! Night time will actually be pitch black darkness and the only thing you'll see is the silhouette of the hills against the night sky. The only way of being aware of your surroundings is to crank up your volume and listen out for the horrors that might be lurking around you as you trek through this open world. Your flashlight is your best friend at night and can also be your enemy, as it will reveal what is in the total darkness and cause you to crap your pants. Night vision goggles/scopes are a huge help. After installing the mod, i never went back to the vanilla version, and it made this game into a horror game. It's hard to play the game at night (in-game) cause i found it wayyy to scary. I've played my fair share of horror games, but this was a little too much for me, thanks to the Complete ModFYI, the mod is PURELY a graphics mod. It visually enhances the game to add more "realism" and i highly recommend downloading it20/10!!!! This game is pure addrenaline and survival when paired with the Call of Pripyat Complete Mod! The Vanilla version would be a 10/10 for me. This game is amazing and needs to be put out there more. It's rare that games will forever leave an impression on me and this is one of those gamesGet this game, download that graphics mod, start up the game, and head over to the abandonded city of Pripyat at night. Prepare to Alt+F4 when you get there

												This game is a jewel of the genre of apocalyptic games, and escpecially S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series. UI is practical and simple, storyline is very good (but wish it was longer), new graphics engine really brings the game to the table. Be that a graphics/weather mods (i.e. Atmosfear 3), arsenal mods, overall improvment of the game (Complete mod), or global mods which create an entirely new storyline. There are easily a couple of hundred hours on this game. I would recommend it to everyone, especially people who like post-apocalyptic genre, realism, atmosphere, and simply a well made game. My rating: 15 out of 10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Call of Pripyat is a fine example of what every open world survival horror game should be.Like its predecessors, Clear Sky and Shadow of Chernobyl, Call of Pripyat is set in a very warped exclusion zone.  Compared to the previous entries in GSC's fabulous series, it is the most stable by far, most graphically appealing, and perhaps the scariest.  The AI is superb.  Beyond superb.  I remember reading somewhere that in Shadow of Chernobyl, they had to tone the AI down to make the game playable.  In its original state, an npc could have easily beaten the game itself without player influence.  It was that good.  And it still is amazing.  GSC managed to take probably the best AI model I've seen and place it in the scariest, darkest, and outlandish things imaginable(and unimaginable for that matter).  When placed into monsters that make villains like Chris Walker and SPC-106 seem like drinking buddies, it puts you into ITS ballpark.  In S.T.A.L.K.E.R., you don't get to smirk at stupid decisions by bandits or monsters.  In fact, I've been outsmarted by the AI.  And that doesn't happen often.  The AI isn't supposed to outsmart the player in video games.  YOU'RE supposed to outsmart IT.  GSC essentially threw that to the wind.  I'll give an example.  In one of the quests, you have to hunt down a creature called a Bloodsucker.  Which is already a name to run away from really fast.  So I packed up my AK, a few bottles of Vodka, a few first aid kits, some bandages, and headed out.  Aside from distant gunshots and screams that you just can't mistake for anything besides a human being torn apart, it was a pleasant enough day.  I reach the hunting spot.  Now, Bloodsuckers can turn invisible.  The standard way to deal with them is to get them to chase you in a straight line, then flip around and unload assault rifle fire in their faces.  The bloodsucker however decided to run away from ME.  So I chased after it and it led me on a wild goose chase around the map until we reached the swamps again.  Guess what had happened while we were gone.  Its friends had formed an ambush, while the first creature tired me out and lured me back to give them all an easy kill.  And that was the AI's doing.  No scripting, no cutscene, no quicktime event.  It did that all on its own.  And that's only one of the nightmares you will encounter in this game.  Most horror games scare you by giving you no defenses or weapons.  You're only choice is to hide or run.  In this, you have plenty of weapons.  And I still get scared out of my wits while I play this.  Because in GSC's rendering of Chernobyl, all the weapons in the world aren't going to give you an advantage.  Overall it has a solid storyline, believable characters, and fun sidequests.  So in short, it's probably one of the best games I've ever played.  And if you ever start to get bored of the bounty of content in Call of Pripyat, the amount of player made mods will take care of that.  To make a long story short, this game is worth EVERY. SINGLE. PENNY.  Of course, if you don't like games where you're not a god, where the world isn't at your mercy, don't buy this.  Because in S.T.A.L.K.E.R, you aren't god.  You're mortal just like everyone else.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4
												Call of Pripyat is the best game in the franchise. I think it is by far the most polished game out of the three, you can tell that developers took what they learned from making the first two and used that experience to make the ultimate Stalker experience. It’s the only game in the franchise where I felt compelled to do the side missions, mainly because of how good the ui is compared to the other two, I was able to navigate through the menus much easier and track each quest I was doing easier too.  The open world feels alive no matter where you are, you could be on the left side of the map but you feel like there is stuff going on the right side of the map without you even being there unlike most other open world games where it feels like the world is waiting for you. They did add repairing and upgrading weapons and armor in Clear Sky but it feels much more refined, thought out and balanced in this game making it a real addition and improvement to the series. The gunplay feels the most refined out of all three games, the difficulty on master feels balanced again which it wasn’t on Clear Sky. The first few hours of the game is great which it wasn’t in the other two, it was usually very frustrating because you were so weak and were not able to hit anything with your weak weapons but in Call of Pripyat you are able to obtain a very reliable inventory of weapons by just doing a few side missions in the starting area. The side missions also offer up a bit of variety to the game and also some small side stories that are cool to experience that have no ties to the main story, they are pretty well executed overall. The story is the most simplistic out of the three, I was never found the story to be a very strong aspect of the franchise so I was ok with the story being very minimal in this game. The only negative I can think of in this game is the travelling between locations can get pretty boring at times especially compared to other games like fallout where you can listen to a radio while travelling to keep you occupied or other open world games where you can use a vehicle or a mount to get around. Looking at the series as a whole now it feels like Shadow of Chornobyl was the main story while Clear Sky and Call of Pripyat were the prologue and epilogue which I think is interesting. I love this franchise overall and like I said in my Shadow of Chornobyl review, mods are definitely not needed.9/10 (Amazing)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												By itself, Call of Pripyat is alright and mostly recommendable - way better than Clear Sky, but still far from delivering on the original promise of the STALKER concept. As all of them, CoP is genuinely at its best when you're left to roam freely, explore, scavenge, pick your own battles and soak in the atmosphere. The linear parts of the game are forgettable and the graphics, well, I guess there the engine is starting to show it's age. But it's pretty alright.However, the Misery mod for Call of Pripyat makes it an absolute hardcore survival masterpiece. It is by far the toughest, most fully-featured, and mercilessly dreary single-player survivor shooter out there - nothing comes even close. It always walks that fine line between jaw-droppingly challenging, frightening and just kind of stupidly insane, and that definitely makes it not everyone's cup of tea. The name doesn't lie - you can say a lot of things about Misery, but it's hard to call it "fun". It is a game out to murder you, both with bullets and monster claws, AND with its complex inventory/item/health/trade system which forces you to think about a lot more than just armor and bullets. Maintaining your health, stamina and the state of your gear isn't simply a matter of walking up to a couple of stations and spending some currency - oh no, this game throws one of the most arcane inventory/item/stats management systems out there at you while providing virtually no instructions, charts or stats bars, only vague indicators. For every new nifty acquisition there is a price - cheap food is radioactive, suits with gas masks constrain and muddy your vision, and carrying more than just bare necessities makes you constantly run out of stamina, even from just walking. It gives you few cues on who is friend and foe, and foes will drop you with deathly-accurate fire from long range. You will die. A lot. But in the process of making you miserable, Misery inspires not just respect and curiosity for the Zone (like STALKER games are wont to do), but sheer awe and terror of the place. It's a game that, many times, made me basically forget everything I was doing and RUN for my (virtual) life, as far as my realistically-puny stamina would allow - not through scripted setpieces like horror games do, but through sheer incidental immersion in the gameworld, which I knew at that moment just happened to be randomly trying to murder me. Even after many days of play, it repeatedly turned me into a lowly scavenger, hunting mutated pigs for something to eat, racing NPCs to a dead bodies just to get some loot off it before they cleaned it all up, and spending as much as 2 weeks of game-time just to scrounge up enough cash for a brand new gun that - gasp - actually works and doesn't jam all the damn time!So yeah, while I think Call of Pripyat by itself is just barely recommendable as an alright game, I give a very hearty recommendation to the Misery mod - with the warning that it takes a certain kind of masochistic player to properly enjoy its hatefully hardcore survival charm.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
 Originally posted on December 26, 2010 After being let down by Clear Sky's unfinished gameplay, I was wary of Call of Pripyat, and although the game is beginning to seem a bit dated, it is still tons of fun.Graphics-The game looks both technically artistically brilliant. While the engine is beginning to show its age outdoors at long distances, the lighting effects, foliage, clouds, and especially the decaying urban environments all look fantastic. I have only played the game maxed with DX10, so I can't attest to how great the DX11 features look. However, even so, the game looks and plays phenomenally.Sound-The music and atmospheric noises are as good as ever, and the voice acting is decent, which is good for a game from Ukraine.Gameplay-They've really integrated features that worked from Clear Sky with features from Shadow of Chernobyl. You can upgrade weapons and repair them, using special calibration tools (which are a bit too difficult to find), but ballistics feels much more like it did in the first, and the focus is much less on combat with humans and much more on exploring and finding mutants. Factions are in place, but no one will attack you on sight unless you've made an enemy of them. Even bandits. This makes for some interesting interactions out in the wild. There are now blowouts which require you to hide indoors or you will die. Gone is the wonky factional combat from clear sky, and perhaps most importantly, gone are the bugs, glitches, crashes, and other instability issues. That stability is what makes Call of Pripyat so refined.The story is weaker compared to the first, but it is still quite good, and the atmosphere of the game itself is great. If you liked STALKER, you won't be disappointed by Call of Pripyat. That being said, I'm expecting big things from STALKER 2. They've had plenty of time to refine their formula and train their skills. Now it's time to shine.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												I think that (without a shadow of a doubt) that this is the best game I have ever played. FACT. I've played many games both on PC and on console, but really the whole S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series is one of my favorite game series of all time. As soon as I bought the game and started playing it, I was in love with the game.I love how the game is EXTREMELY atmospheric. I think if it had Occulus Rift compatibility, I would definitely break some windows with my screams of terror. The AI is a little (ahem) crazy, but there are many modded overhauls for this game, such as MISERY, Call of Pripyat Complete, and more. If you want a challenging, atmospheric, IMMERSIVE game, I'd say that every S.T.A.L.K.E.R. game is going to be perfect for you.The downfalls of really each of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games is the lack of multiple weapons. There are only a good few weapons in the game, but getting the MISERY mod overhaul will definitely add several weapons to the game. The graphics (texture-wise) are pretty good for its time when the game came out. However, the lighting, especially for S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Call of Pripyat, is PHENOMENAL. The lighting uses DirectX 11, to bring the most satisfying lighting effects for any game, maybe even for some next-gen console & PC games.To make this all short:Yes. Buy the game. This series has what some components of Fallout should've been. Once you play it, you'll see exactly what I mean.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												Fallout 3 has always been my favorite game of all time. If you're a fan of the recent fallout games then you will fall in love with Stalker Call of Pripyat. This game honestly blows me away (Litterally, in-game). The atmosphere is wonderfully eerie, especially at night.Pair this game with the Call of Pripyat Complete Mod and you will ejaculate on your keyboard while crapping your pants. The mod will enhance the atmosphere and gameplay greatly! Night time will actually be pitch black darkness and the only thing you'll see is the silhouette of the hills against the night sky. The only way of being aware of your surroundings is to crank up your volume and listen out for the horrors that might be lurking around you as you trek through this open world. Your flashlight is your best friend at night and can also be your enemy, as it will reveal what is in the total darkness and cause you to crap your pants. Night vision goggles/scopes are a huge help. After installing the mod, i never went back to the vanilla version, and it made this game into a horror game. It's hard to play the game at night (in-game) cause i found it wayyy to scary. I've played my fair share of horror games, but this was a little too much for me, thanks to the Complete ModFYI, the mod is PURELY a graphics mod. It visually enhances the game to add more "realism" and i highly recommend downloading it20/10!!!! This game is pure addrenaline and survival when paired with the Call of Pripyat Complete Mod! The Vanilla version would be a 10/10 for me. This game is amazing and needs to be put out there more. It's rare that games will forever leave an impression on me and this is one of those gamesGet this game, download that graphics mod, start up the game, and head over to the abandonded city of Pripyat at night. Prepare to Alt+F4 when you get there

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												This game does NOT hold your handThis game does NOT make you feel like a godThis game is actually challenging, and requires you to think correctly, so get out of here CoD fanboys and the like!Call of Pripyat is the easiest out of the three games, but still challenging when you get to Yanov Station and beyond, this game features random events, such as Emissions, Artifact spawning, and mutant spawning. This game is not a "go out there, bang bang, thousand hostiles down in section one alpha" kinda game, you have an inventory system, where you can only carry 50 kg of room, you have to decide which is more important, weapons, ammo, food or med-kits. You WILL run out of bullets quickly unless you can aim for the head, I'm a bad aim so I carry 100-200+ ammo for my assault rifles, the mutants don't seem to deal as much damage as they would in say.. Shadow of Chernobyl, but still stay clear of them, your armor and weapons deteriorate too.Artifact hunting! This should be rather easy (in the starting map) artifacts are found in anomalies, spots where the laws of nature and physics had been corrupted, these anomalies are very dangerous to human health, in these anomalies are artifacts, which are used to be either sold or used to help you get past an anomaly or increase your base health, or remove radiation, be wary, most artifacts harm you but at the same time can help you.  This is all I can say, Duty is standing behind me trying to get me from typing this, so I must go! Good luck stalker!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4
												Call of Pripyat is the best game in the franchise. I think it is by far the most polished game out of the three, you can tell that developers took what they learned from making the first two and used that experience to make the ultimate Stalker experience. It’s the only game in the franchise where I felt compelled to do the side missions, mainly because of how good the ui is compared to the other two, I was able to navigate through the menus much easier and track each quest I was doing easier too.  The open world feels alive no matter where you are, you could be on the left side of the map but you feel like there is stuff going on the right side of the map without you even being there unlike most other open world games where it feels like the world is waiting for you. They did add repairing and upgrading weapons and armor in Clear Sky but it feels much more refined, thought out and balanced in this game making it a real addition and improvement to the series. The gunplay feels the most refined out of all three games, the difficulty on master feels balanced again which it wasn’t on Clear Sky. The first few hours of the game is great which it wasn’t in the other two, it was usually very frustrating because you were so weak and were not able to hit anything with your weak weapons but in Call of Pripyat you are able to obtain a very reliable inventory of weapons by just doing a few side missions in the starting area. The side missions also offer up a bit of variety to the game and also some small side stories that are cool to experience that have no ties to the main story, they are pretty well executed overall. The story is the most simplistic out of the three, I was never found the story to be a very strong aspect of the franchise so I was ok with the story being very minimal in this game. The only negative I can think of in this game is the travelling between locations can get pretty boring at times especially compared to other games like fallout where you can listen to a radio while travelling to keep you occupied or other open world games where you can use a vehicle or a mount to get around. Looking at the series as a whole now it feels like Shadow of Chornobyl was the main story while Clear Sky and Call of Pripyat were the prologue and epilogue which I think is interesting. I love this franchise overall and like I said in my Shadow of Chornobyl review, mods are definitely not needed.9/10 (Amazing)
