content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												I was looking for a new rpg game. (Finishing Skyrim and Fallout on my ps3) and I couldnt find one that suited my fancy. With the amount of Rpgs out there I was overwhelmed. And so I searched on the youtubes and it Showed this little gem. I heard of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R seris was good, but never really though about it. It was cheap so I figured why not and I purchased the game. I started the game and was immediatly thrown into a giant world without a clear objective and I was a bit confused. Eventually I found the main base of the stalkers. I enjoyed it . BUt it got boring. It was a bit easy even with the added survival aspect. I laid it off and stoped playing. After a while on browsing my steam library I saw a report on hardest mods in the gaming world. And I found misery. AND I MUST SAY IT IS HARD AS @#$%. But I love it. A good game on its own. BUt if you want a hardcore rpg survival get the misery mod Base Game: 7/10 MIsery 9/10

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2013
												tl;dr Treasure Hunter!This game is about treasure hunting! Search for wanted treasure that you can either choose to keep or sell for profit. Find artifacts in anomalies, or find a stash of weapons and ammo hidden under a log!This game was incredibly imersive, which was awesome! I love this game. Easily ranks one of the best games I have ever played. Sniper game play was best gun play ever! (I stalked around always sneaking, and modified my guns for accuracy, arcing, and velocity.) Master difficulty was a great challenge!  (end of tl;dr)Description of this game seriesAttempt to take out an entire building of sentient enemies with stealth attacks. The more silent you are, the more deadly you become. Enemies see only whats in their vision, but hear whats in their hearing range. Crouch for an aim boost with near silent movement. Turn on night vision and pull out your silenced weapon to become the ultimate STALKER! (easy, but still fun!)Each NPC has a unique name, and they will remember if they like you. They can die from enemies too, though. The killed NPCs are replaced with a tenth as many fresh new NPCs, which makes you feel like you put a dent in the zone. If you shoot your friend once, they will forgive you. If you shoot them twice, then its war... Plus their faction will also like you less.FactionsThere are different groups/factions. Zombies, Bandits, Loners, Stalkers, Duty, Freedom, Military, and most feared of all Monolith. Bandits rob Stalkers, and Stalkers collect artifacts. You can save anytime you want. I suggest keeping 4 rotating saves. Which makes winning a serious battle, actually possible. Making you the most badass in the zone! Although, no one truly knows how cool you are due to saves! ;D (I wish there was a video replay, where it played back your battle. It would be sweet to see how elite your character is, minus the reloads of saves.)MutantsMutated animals run around constantly. The types of mutated creatures become really sneaky and different than you can imagine. They will often attack other mutants types, and even patrolling squads. Sometimes wiping them out. You will have to make decisions on helping NPC communities survive, which plays out as a different game with different endings.Better EquipmentBetter equipment comes much faster from purchasing from a specific NPC for costly prices. But you will gain access to similar guns later, from fallen enemies, except armor never drops from enemies. You can watch a bullet fall with gravity as it speeds towards a distant target. If you choose to use a sniper weapon, you will have to adjust your manual aim to compensate for this new thing called gravity. Also, the distance between you and your target feels real!Upgraded EquipmentYou can also upgrade your favorite weapons and armor from certain characters. You scratch my back, I'll scratch yours. My favorite weapon is the silent sniper's Vintar BC named Tide. And the upgraded exoskeleton with servomotors.Treasure Hunt!Now for the meat of the game! There are artifacts which you treasure hunt for!! They are expensive, and fetch a very pretty penny when sold. But they also have bonuses which will help you defeat certain mutants and especially more anomalies. Artifacts are hidden, invisible from sight, but spring out when located in anomalies, which are dangerous ghost like traps. If you hear your radiation meter going off, throw a metal bolt by pressing 6, to see if you are about to get zapped by stepping on a trap. Also, if you hear radiation, you are probably getting pummeled with radiation poisoning. Might want to step back. Find better artifacts to get less exposure! But nothing* will save you from a storm, so if they say to take cover, then get inside where its safe.Lastly, the atmosphere is really in depth. Everyone speaks with a Russian accent, and when the wind blows the bushes wave. Day/Night cycles and eating let you feel like you are really camping in the zone. Its cold and a loner's friend.ControlsPress N for NightvisionPress P for MAP, stats, and current chat logsPress 6 for boltsPress Y to change your ammo typePress 9/0 for automatic fire or single shot firePress O to pull out your radiometer/geiger counterI switched my shift to sprint, ctrl to regular crouch, z for low crouch, c for flashlight.Press F to take stuff or talk to peoplePress Q/R to lean around corners for less risky exposure to shots fired.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2011
												Great game, one of few I consider my favorite games of all time. The game allows for VERY dynamic things to happen and some (maybe most I'm not really sure) have a real life scenario. I missed a target in a mission and failed it, no retries. Although I'm not really sure if it had a real effect on what happened to me it did impress me at the time. Sometimes things just complete themselves when you're not there because the game doesnt really revolve around you. You're just there to enjoy it. I did sure enjoy it too, lots of things to do, dynamic EVERYTHING (varies), very scary and suspensful moments, not being invincible at all, and just having an almost open world (different zones but mostly open). This game and the series is a must play and even if it does get boring or even not that challenging, there are many MANY mods to make it different and even more diverse. This game is overall impressive.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												This game was the first game I bought on steam, and now after 3 years on steam I wanted to play through it again and its still just as amazing as 3 years ago. It took me 56 hours to complete the game back then and I played 12 hours just exploring, searcheng for weapons and trying the Misery mod. This game has value, huge value at this price so just buy it! Its one of the most immersive games ever created because of how the world just plays out on its own. For an example, everyone can get killed and then theyre dead throughout the game. Its hard to explain what makes it so great and immersive so you should experiance it for yourself. And dont let the graphics throw you off and dont compare it to games like Fallout 3, theyre alot more different than you think.So if youre looking for a great survival, horror, fps and immersive game, this is the perfect game for you!(Its also perfect for roleplaying!)I give the game 10/10, never take on a bloodsucker again!PS.Play it on master difficulty with no crosshair. It may be difficult as hell so quicksave often but it adds to the immersion and it makes the world feel more dangerous.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												This is basically STALKER 3.  It still falls short of being the best in the series.  The plot and gameplay are definitely better than Clear Sky but not as good as the original Shadow of Chernobyl.  This could have been the best in the series if the ending of the game was better.  It's anti-climactic to say the least.  That's not to take away from the definite improvements from STALKER 1 and 2.  The menu system, artifact system, weapon binds, and graphics all are a great improvement.  The plot and faction interactions are bland and devoid of enthusiasm like the original.  Yes this is definitely worth adding to your collection if you enjoyed the original just don't expect it to be better than the original.

												the day breaks, and a silent mist falls over the zone. as i step out of my dwelling i stop and gaze upon the swamps in frount of me. anything could be hiding in there, any of the monsterous spawn of the zone could be lurking in the very fog that covered the swamp before me, but, i had to go. i whipped out my PDA, the claw anomaly was only just across the swamp, i could make it. i slowly pulled my klash from my bag, wet with dew i loaded in my only mag. the cold steal bit like the cold of the morning itself, my hands where shaking. i then began to walk into the mist. it was quite, only the cherps of frogs glazed my ears, as i stepped carfully through the swamp. i began to imagine what awaited me on the other side of this swamp, so many artifacts, so much money. i could even ask nimble to order me a new rifle. my mind flew, it was going so fast i wasnt paying attention to the swamp. i snapped back to reality as i stopped walking, i heard something. it was distent, barley noticable. so i kept on walking, nevertheless i still gripped my rifle harder. then something scampered past me in the fog, i rose my klash frantically trying to find the shadow, something anything at all in my sights. again right behind me something touched me, the fog was so thick i could barely see. my heart  began to race and my breath quickened. soon they were all around me, and a deep growl rose up over the frog's chrepping. i stood compleatly still, and i held my breath. i clutched my klash toward my heart and i prayed to what ever god was listening. then a loud thud shoke the earth, and the growling fell silent. then another thud, and another, louder and LOUDER. soon, it was right behind me, i felt the warmth of the large beast or what i assumed was a beast behind me. i was going to burst my lungs burned, i felt the heat of the animal's head moving parallel to mine. it let out a deep feral breath, this, this was it. it lended in and then it spoke. its words where clear, and shoke me to my very bones. ..............................ah nucheekibreekiivDAMKE

content:
Posted: January 13
												The Rating System: Good refers to the obvious positive qualities, the Bad is reserved for nitpicks and gripes that don't necessarily ruin the experience, the Ugly is for the worst parts of the game, meant for serious consideration before purchase.The Good:Call of Pripyat has a lot of positives to name, though based mostly on this author's personal taste.For gameplay, it's a very challenging game, with each bullet or enemy presenting a serious threat, as damage is high, ammo is scarce and repairs are expensive. You cannot easily hoard money in CoP, as the merchants in the game will only buy quality equipment, and equipment that is in top quality is exceedingly rare. Every hit you take makes you bleed, and depending on your armor, will eventually cause you to bleed to death if not handled right away. The game also uses a Resident Evil 4 style inventory system, but with a realistic weight value, restricting you to only a handful of equipment at a time.The NPC's don't excessively spout nonsense at you as soon as you walk near them like in a Bethesda game, they talk to you when they feel like it, or until directly spoken to. This actually makes the game feel more warm and inviting, when a colony of people who you've been helping out see you coming in the door and welcome you, asking how you've been and then adding a little sad comment when you walk off without saying hi back. What's more, because there's little voice acting in the game, the character's "performances" are up to your imagination, and their dialogue is nice. Each quest you do pays off tremendously, either long term or short term, as each ruble you aquire is valuable, and having friends is even more valuable in the Zone.The AI is pretty smart, taking cover and using their equipment intelligently. The animal AI is more impressive to me. As an example, sometimes you see packs of wild dogs play-fighting together, resting by a gas station before the pack leader barks and they begin roaming off again. Oftentimes, you'll find monsters attacking NPC's, and you have a dynamic choice to try and save them - which is hard, but helps you make friends and leads to a convenient trader if you're carrying too many goods, since you can trade with anyone - or let them die for their equipment and deal with the monster yourself.To summarize, it's a very very very immersive game, just don't expect it to be easy. Get used to quick saving often, though thankfully the game only needs to load once, and it loads quickly.The Bad: It's a pretty buggy game at times. On one occasion, I reloaded a quicksave and found one of my friendly follower NPC's crouching over and over and marked as an enemy on my HUD. Every time you reload a save, enemy behavior resets, so sometimes a fight will have a weird cease fire for a couple seconds, letting you get a free kill until they notice you're there again. There is no real "story", no grand goal to work towards, it's all about meeting neat characters, interacting with the world and discovering the hidden lore sprinkled throughout the environment. The game also really doesn't like being alt-tabbed, and will crash with irritating frequency when you do, and you will need to because of two reasons: 1, the game is VERY stingey with hints on certain quests and you'll find yourself visiting the wiki often, and 2..The Ugly:The game has no native functionality with Steam. Even if you do force the game to recognize Steam input (such as opening the shift-tab overlay), the game will take 10x longer to load. The first time I tried loading the game with Steam input on, it took literally 15 minutes to load, when it usually only takes about 10 seconds for me. It also has a VERY obnoxious visual sway effect every time you start moving, and I don't mean a subtle one, I mean the camera sways like it's on a piece of string blowing in a hurricane. It made me sick to my stomach, and I had to mod the game to remove the effect, as the command console option I googled up never worked for me.Final verdict: 8/10A very exciting, challenging shooter, with a very immersive world and a crap main story that requires you to stop, talk to people and take in the environment if you want to learn anything more about it. It had a lot of little problems, but they were either ignorable or were easily fixed. It feels like Morrowind crossed with Fallout Classic - the eerie, weird atmosphere and silent NPC's of Morrowind, with the world interaction and focus on realism from Fallout Classic, if that makes sense. If you don't like a game with an excessive focus on realism or challenge, or a game whose story is mostly told to you by NPC text dumps and through exploring the environment, then you may not like this game as much as I did.One final note: You WILL go native for slav culture playing this game. Stay cheeki breeki, stalkers.

Posted: October 10, 2015
												This game, along with its predecessor Shadow of Chernobyl, is definetly one of the most atmospheric and immmersive games I've ever played. I can't remember a single time when a game has made me run screaming in terror while wearing prototype ukranian power armour and carrying enough guns to overthrow a small african nation. Trust me, be afraid of what's hiding in the dark. Coupled with a haunting environment populated and a constant tension from knowing that danger could come from any angle in literally any form, this game will keep you playing for some fairly unhealthy amounts of time. A great modding community and dynamic questlines will make sure that this game will stay fresh for your next few playthroughs.I highly, highly reccommend this game.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												This game was the first game I bought on steam, and now after 3 years on steam I wanted to play through it again and its still just as amazing as 3 years ago. It took me 56 hours to complete the game back then and I played 12 hours just exploring, searcheng for weapons and trying the Misery mod. This game has value, huge value at this price so just buy it! Its one of the most immersive games ever created because of how the world just plays out on its own. For an example, everyone can get killed and then theyre dead throughout the game. Its hard to explain what makes it so great and immersive so you should experiance it for yourself. And dont let the graphics throw you off and dont compare it to games like Fallout 3, theyre alot more different than you think.So if youre looking for a great survival, horror, fps and immersive game, this is the perfect game for you!(Its also perfect for roleplaying!)I give the game 10/10, never take on a bloodsucker again!PS.Play it on master difficulty with no crosshair. It may be difficult as hell so quicksave often but it adds to the immersion and it makes the world feel more dangerous.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												This is basically STALKER 3.  It still falls short of being the best in the series.  The plot and gameplay are definitely better than Clear Sky but not as good as the original Shadow of Chernobyl.  This could have been the best in the series if the ending of the game was better.  It's anti-climactic to say the least.  That's not to take away from the definite improvements from STALKER 1 and 2.  The menu system, artifact system, weapon binds, and graphics all are a great improvement.  The plot and faction interactions are bland and devoid of enthusiasm like the original.  Yes this is definitely worth adding to your collection if you enjoyed the original just don't expect it to be better than the original.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2013
												An oldie but a goodie.  Back when DX11 was new Stalker CoP was a great tool for benchmarking.  The atmospheric open world still stands out now as an example of what I look for in a game.  Extremely open, non linear, clearly designed for the leading platform with for the time, ground breaking use of PC capabiliies.  One of the few games I replayed more than once. An Excellent game but so dated now.  This was one of the most atmospheric games I ever played and the depth and openess was way ahead of its time.  A much missed title from sadly missed developers.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
												This game is amazing! You start out in a forest with some other people that don't trust you at all. You can go with them to where they're going but don't, that'll get you lost like me. Go directly to the ship, which I also didn't do. I just really didn't know what to do, so I went exploring, I saw it was an open world game and I just ran around. Most FPS games make it so that you have the accuracy of a god on steroids in games, when you aim, you shoot exactly that. In S.T.A.L.K.E.R. you don't, you'll be lucky to hit someone with your scoped assault rifle that's on a roof. Artifacts are easy as hell to get if you have the right locator, and try to make friends with everyone. Being a hostile nerd will get you killed in the first 20 seconds. This game's enemies are hell. Zombies look like people but when you get close they pull up their guns and start shooting at you. Like what the hell kinda game has gun weilding zombies!? Mutants are jerks, they will kill you using the powers of cheekie breekie. So don't touch em, unless they throw something at you, then kill them at any cost. Dogs are diiiiiiiiiiiicks! They chase you around trying to eat your face. And bloodsuckers are invisible monsters that try to scratch your eyes out. If there's a friendly NPC nearby, run to them then run away. Or ya know, take all of that ammo and useless guns that you carry for some reason and shoot at anything that makes a strange sound. Branch snaps? Shoot it.This game  will not hold your hand, it will make you decide who gets to live and how you do it. Your introduction to artifacts is getting one from an anomalous ship that tries to kill you. If you get it, someone outside asks you for it because they need it to pay for medicine. Like the smart mistrusting person I am, I gave it to him, made a quicksave, saw him run back to the base, call me an idiot, adn sell it, so I went back to the quicksave, ran at him, then shot him down and stole all of his stuff. Then I sold it.Best game 10/2 would play again. and again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again and again  forevs.

												An amazing edition to the Stalker series. Features much more polish and and optimization, and also looks better than SoC. There is also a huge modding scene, but every stalker game has TONS of cool mods to try out. I recommend you play shadow of chernoybal first however, just to get the origional stalker experience and understand the story, as CoP will not explain any of that to you. Personally I prefer playing the origional, but if you're interested in the series or this game in particular you can't go wrong, one of the best FPS's series to date. Now get out of here stalker.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												One of the many "Need to have" games on steam, out of all three in the series, this one is my personal favorite, polished, well rounded, an active modding community, despite it's age, some of which I can say are the best mods I've ever played, this game lives up to all expectations and then blows them out of the water. My personal recommendation for anyone looking to get into the Stalker series, many claim SOC is the best, and it is very good, get that one after this. But COP is by far the most polished, SOC is like playing a movie, the atmosphere, the music, it's a game near perfect in design, but this is still the better, avoid Clear sky unless youre a die hard fan, it's the ugly duckling of the three. Absolutely 10/10

												An oldie but a goodie.  Back when DX11 was new Stalker CoP was a great tool for benchmarking.  The atmospheric open world still stands out now as an example of what I look for in a game.  Extremely open, non linear, clearly designed for the leading platform with for the time, ground breaking use of PC capabiliies.  One of the few games I replayed more than once. An Excellent game but so dated now.  This was one of the most atmospheric games I ever played and the depth and openess was way ahead of its time.  A much missed title from sadly missed developers.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												This is basically STALKER 3.  It still falls short of being the best in the series.  The plot and gameplay are definitely better than Clear Sky but not as good as the original Shadow of Chernobyl.  This could have been the best in the series if the ending of the game was better.  It's anti-climactic to say the least.  That's not to take away from the definite improvements from STALKER 1 and 2.  The menu system, artifact system, weapon binds, and graphics all are a great improvement.  The plot and faction interactions are bland and devoid of enthusiasm like the original.  Yes this is definitely worth adding to your collection if you enjoyed the original just don't expect it to be better than the original.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2013
												Consider this a recommendation for the entire STALKER series so far (latest as of this being Call of Pripyat). The STALKER games are FPS/Survival Horror/RPG hybrids where the emphasis is on the FPS gunplay and the survival elements.You can get thirsty or hungry or need sleep and have to manage those needs alongside that of the deteriorating conditions of your weapons and armors. Ammunition, food, and drink needed to survive are scarce, but can be traded for with almost anyone if you have the right amount of goods or money to sacrifice for it. The game has large maps you can travel between like a sandbox game, and the gunplay is some of the tightest I've seen with really good gun physics. The games also have a wildlife simulation system similar to the one in place in FarCry 3 in a way; animals and mutants will run around and do their own thing after they spawn and kill each other (and maybe you) for survival or food.Despite the large amount of freedom these games afford you to carve your own path, they feel very focused and are best approached with a strategic mindset.

monsterous spawn of the zone could be lurking in the very fog that covered the swamp before me, but, i had to go. i whipped out my PDA, the claw anomaly was only just across the swamp, i could make it. i slowly pulled my klash from my bag, wet with dew i loaded in my only mag. the cold steal bit like the cold of the morning itself, my hands where shaking. i then began to walk into the mist. it was quite, only the cherps of frogs glazed my ears, as i stepped carfully through the swamp. i began to imagine what awaited me on the other side of this swamp, so many artifacts, so much money. i could even ask nimble to order me a new rifle. my mind flew, it was going so fast i wasnt paying attention to the swamp. i snapped back to reality as i stopped walking, i heard something. it was distent, barley noticable. so i kept on walking, nevertheless i still gripped my rifle harder. then something scampered past me in the fog, i rose my klash frantically trying to find the shadow, content:
Posted: December 13, 2012
												Best in the series. This has the best main plot with a Fallout 3-style ending that changes depending on your actions in game. Very atmospheric with plenty of side quests that reward exploration and help flesh out the lore of the locations. Has a lot of depth with gun play and survival mechanics, requiring you to eat food while in the field and keep yourself bandaged up to avoid bleeding out. Call of Pripyat stands on its own feet and doesn't require any previous experience with the series; a must play for any FPS fans.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 4, 2013
												As a franchise, GSC Game World's Stalker has come a long way. That the original Shadow of Chernobyl was actually completed and released to the public at all after a seemingly endless string of delays was a bit of a surprise. Sure, it was rough around the edges, but no other game out there offered such an intoxicating mix of horror and bleak beauty like Stalker and the irradiated wastes of its setting. While the follow-up prequel, Clear Sky, was a bit of a disappointment in how it trimmed out a bunch of elements that helped Stalker stand out, Call of Pripyat ditches a lot of the changes made and returns to the series' roots. It's not quite the revelatory experience Shadow of Chernobyl was, but it hits all the right notes for fans of the original and anyone else who values mood in their games and finds entertainment in being scared out of their socks. It also, thankfully, isn't nearly as buggy.To get the timeline all straightened out, Call of Pripyat is the second title to follow Shadow of Chernobyl and takes place after the events of the first. The game is set in the Zone, a tract of land surrounding the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant in which all life has been corrupted and twisted into hideous and deadly forms. Frightening and powerful creatures dwell in isolated underground testing labs and caverns, the landscape is full of dangerous traps that spout fire from the ground and trigger damaging windstorms, and every once in a while an emission blasts across the land wiping out anything silly enough to neglect shelter. Despite the fact that this land sounds entirely inhospitable, it draws fortune seekers in search of curios called artifacts that tend to spawn right in the middle of the anomalous traps. As a result, groups of these stalkers bunch together in whatever safe areas they can find, such as in rusted husks of beached ships, abandoned train stations, and the crumbling remains of Pripyat. The mysterious circumstances surrounding the propagation and sustainment of the Zone have also created several subgroups within the area, including factions that want to wipe it off the planet entirely and those that think its uniqueness alone justifies a need to preserve it.In this game you play as Alex Degtyarev, a new character and part of a military mission to discover what happened to a number of helicopters sent into The Zone following the climactic events of the first title. Everyone was curious as to what kind of power beat at the setting's center, and after watching Call of Pripyat's opening cutscene it's clear the military didn't have a lot of success finding an answer. As you comb the grounds in search of the damaged military vehicles and their crew members, you'll pass through three large areas comprised of toxic marshes, desiccated fields, decaying industrial facilities and urban wastes, all of which have their own set of side quests and feature plenty of scares and entertaining challenges.The game is structured like a role-playing title, with primary missions and quest rewards and a trading system where you'll repair guns, buy ammunition and medical supplies, wrap cuts with bandages, and upgrade your gear the further you go. There's no leveling or experience point systems, however, so the power of your character is more directly determined by the kinds of equipment you're carrying around. Like Shadow of Chernobyl, when you start out, you're going to be incredibly vulnerable to the dangers present in the Zone. You'll also be poor. Talking to NPCs, taking on quests, and hunting down and trading artifacts for cash are your best options for upgrades, which in Call of Pripyat is a more interesting process than in the original.That's because the modification system built into Clear Sky has been imported here, meaning if you talk to specific NPCs and give them what they want, they'll offer services that can do things like upgrade the reliability of your weapon, improve its accuracy, or boost the defensive parameters of your armor. Even by implementing these upgrades, you'll still need to keep an eye on your gear's condition. Call of Pripyat is a game where a sense of realism is crucial to the overall tone of the world, and as such that means your armor can break down and weapons degrade with use. Eventually, guns you've ignored will deteriorate and start to jam with such frequency that there's no point in using them anymore. You'll also need to monitor radiation levels and bring scraps of food on your journey to keep Alex in fighting shape, since it really doesn't take very long for a skittering mutant to claw the life from you.Though you do still interact with Duty and Freedom factions in the game, the flimsy faction balance system from Clear Sky has been tossed out for Call of Pripyat. The result is a more natural feel to the interplay of AI systems across the Zone. You'll see wandering bands of humans get into some large-scale fights against ravenous packs of mutated dogs and hulking boar creatures. You'll hear this combat in the distance and get the sense that this world is alive and chaotic and exists independently of your actions, which reinforces the elements of realism built into the game's weapon and armor systems and the general vulnerability of your character as you scamper from firefight to firefight.Guns in Stalker are not incredibly accurate, something that holds true of your weapons and those of your humanoid opponents. Bullets spray everywhere during a fight, encouraging you to crouch down behind cover and fire in quick bursts. It means you'll need to pay attention every time you go to shoot. If you panic and try to fire from the hip while on the move, you're going to get punctured and shredded in seconds. You need to be surgically precise, even after you've purchased upgrades, if you want to stay alive while out on your own. It adds to the authentic feel of the world that by using each weapon, you'll notice a difference in feel almost immediately. The variation between each firearm contributes to a greater sense of growing power and progression as you come across better equipment, keeping you motivated on your journey toward the Zone's secrets.If you're not questing, you'll find this world interesting enough to make simply wandering around to see the sights and searching for the occasional artifact entertaining. The windswept slopes and unsetting, icy soundtrack never let you relax, building a tension that keeps your attention glued to the events onsceen even if there's nothing happening except for wind swishing through tall grass. It's the threat of action that hooks you and draws you forward, since you never know if something like a cloaked bloodsucker or loping snork is waiting for you behind the next rise as rainstorms wash across the fields and day turns to night. It's an environment built with such clarity of vision, that feels so alien and hostile that simply managing to survive a journey from one location to the next feels like an accomplishment, a feeling amplified greatly when you manage to actually uncover a cool new item or pocket of bizarre activity.Unfortunately, there are elements that eat away at the atmosphere of the world, and those are the voice acting, quest text and delivery. The English voice acting in the game is from time to time decent, but frequently irritatingly overenthusiastic. I'm not looking to hear "Hey, bro!" screamed with the cadence of someone who just slammed a line of Jager bombs after I nearly lost my head in a snork nest. A lot of text is also copy and pasted between conversation trees with non-essential NPCs, which can be distracting, and the overall delivery of the story is very straightforward. So, if you want to learn all you can about the zone, it means digging through a lot of limp text in chat boxes.10/10

By: Primary

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												NOTE: THIS REVIEW IS FOR VANILLA STALKER COP.Stalker CoP is a return to the zone with more emphasis on exploration compared to its previous entries. It also features the least difficult intro segment compared to the prior games. While this may turn off some "hardcore" players, CoP is no easy ride. The game is still difficult and will punish players who play too quickly. That being said CoP is almost on par with SoC and sometimes is better on certain aspects. For starters players can now transition from day to night with the ability to sleep, bandages are back to being common again compared to Clear Sky, and the game has a better weapon upgrade system compared to its predecessor. CoP also has factions and brings artifact hunting to being the player's main source of income next to side quests. CoP however has the weakest main quest in the series. The player is tasked to track down helicopters that crashed in the zone, recover their information, and meet with any suvivors. CoPs strongest aspect is exploration. The main quest does not have the player explore every area in the game's 3 hub worlds (The Skadovsk, Yanon, and Pripyat) and players will be reward with excellent gear when doing so. The 3 hub worlds are large but feel dissapointing seeing that the prior games had up to 8 hub worlds to be in, however, memorable areas like Lab X8 are back and ungrounded caves are apleanty.Pros:- Fixes many problems introduced in Clear Sky.- Added ability to pass time via sleep.- The most stable version of vanilla stalker.- Arguably the least difficult intro segment compared to other Stalkers.- PDA map is more detailed- Ability to upgrade your headgear and expanded upgrade system in previous games.- Great amount of side quests.- Ability to hotkey medical items.- Added emission  storms which reset the anamolies certain areas.- Hud is now expanded to provide more information.- Hunger system is back, making food more than just an alternative to health kits.- The best looking inventory in Stalker.- While there are only 3 hub worlds, labs and underground bunkers are still here.- Multiple endings and factions to side with.- The mutant Ai for dogs and other beasts like chimera are amazing, as they attack one another, eat their prey, and can be seen dragging their prey to their respective packs. Chimeras also hunt at night and can be easily killed by taking advantage of their sleep cycles.- Stealth is still here and is a option.- The more your discover and wander, the game rewards you with treasures, gear, or even memorable moments thanks to its unscripted Ai.- Gunplay in CoP feels the most polished with weapons having bullet drop, varied recoil depending on the weapon, and enemies have the same properties as the player (higher the difficulty, higher the damage, which also goes for the enemies.) Cons:- Weak main quest which can be finished really quickly.- The engine has taken a hit as vegetation now grow before your very eyes.- The game does have some bugs.- Emission storms define certain buildings as safe spots, not just any building which might be a bit fustration for newcomers.- Save system is still weak so be ready to smack that F5 key.- Cutscenes are a bit akward with characters having rigid movement.- 3 Main Hub worlds.- While factions exist, it still feels somewhat shallow as it simply determines what type of weapons merchants sell and how others talk to you.- Ai can be spotty at times. Friendlies will shoot you on accident if your in their line of fire BUT will continue shooting. On higher difficulties it almost feels like the Ai has some ridiculous aim and an amazing throwing arm for grenades.- Certain features may turn off players such as weapon jam being random (keep your items repaired) and how artifacts are hunted.- Money runs everything, you can no longer travel between hubs on your own but must pay a guide. Weapon repairs are also done with money only.Stalker CoP is some of the few rpgs thay I sank lots of time into. It manages to be fun after many playthroughs since the game rewards you for exploring areas which might lead you to a new quests, underground labs with locked doors which only increase your curiosity, and the many secrets the game has in store. It's also the only Stalker that seems 100% playable in vanilla as it has so many features that are well polished compared to Soc or Clear Sky. However, this game is not for the weak willed, it will push you and place you in uncomfortable situations which can be memorable or just fustration for some players. Tread lightly, there is no tutorial and no hand holding.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2016
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Call of Pripyat is a game that I can describe as "unpredictable" - it is, in the eyes of many, a foreign competitor to Fallout, and they do share a similar concept, but are actually more separate than people think.Now when I say "unpredictable", I mean with Fallout "encounters" in the various maps, NPC ambushes aren't that surprising or unique, and very rarely does the story give some sort of interesting twist or spin. S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Call of Pripyat, on the other hand, is borderline terrifying at times due to the genuinely frightening creatures of the Zone and the rather cinematic radiation emissions that pop up periodically. Call of Pripyat's world is a rather dangerous one, with every sort of nightmarish abomination ranging from packs of furless, feral dogs to invisible humanoid monsters called "Bloodsuckers", which move and strike VERY quickly and unpredictably. And unlike Fallout's "nightmare fuel" monsters, which are positioned in sewers and caves, the Zone's monsters can be out in the central area, just kind of waiting for you.In terms of a story, I'm going to assume that this is some sort of sequel or something (I'm waiting for all of those dedicated fanboy S.T.A.L.K.E.R. nerds to dislike just because I'm not a leet fan pro like yourselves, and that I actually have a girlfriend and real options in my life), since it doesn't really have a proper opening or background check, and I'm sure if I bought the other games it'd probably make a lot more sense to me, so if you're buying this game in the hopes of a story, I don't think that's a good selling point because it doesn't really give you a complete story.All in all, S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Call of Pripyat is really cool, and if you're up for an alternative to Fallout that kind of takes itself a little bit more seriously, this game is worth your while.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2016
												        So I have heard many good things about this game( and look at the reviews!). Good graphics, great gameplay, fun mechanics, et cetera. Basically the whole kit and kaboodle of a good game. I buy it and open it up, eager to immerse myself in this rich, irradiated, open world with so much to offer. Right out of the gate I load it up and go through the beginning intro to start my game on "Rookie" difficulty and discover a big problem. It's running on 1024x768 resolution and laggy as all get out. Running at 3 FPS. I turned everything down as low as I was willing and it ran smooth but it looked like somehting that I would create with a few days at home with nothing but time spent on creating this game. My hopes were all smashed, but I gave it a try anyway. The first Stalkers I encounter I shoot at because, well, they look like enemies. Immediately I drop from a comfortable (comfortable like a rock mattress) FPS rate of 18 to 5 as they shoot back. I die and try again, this time avoiding everyone. I get reasonably far and then the emissions start. I tried 5 more times and got ambushed by mutants and stalkers alike. I finally gave up on it deciding that the only way I can run it is to have it on 800somex600some resolution, I wouldn't play it. I had high hopes and I do believe this is a great game. I just can't enjoy it. I recommend this to anyone that reads my review. My word of advice: Don't buy this game if you don't have a PC able to run it well. You won't enjoy it and you will just end up sorely disappointed and frustrated. Thank you for taking time to read this.

content:
Posted: March 14
												The game did manage to keep me interested to play through the end--but only barely.  I got to one of the ending, most of NPCs died, but I really didn't care enough about replaying any parts.  Here are a few reasons:- At one location, enemies spawn 30 feet away from you, and literally drop from the sky and start shooting.  - "Protect an NPC" mission where a single enemy can 1-shot-kill the person you're trying to protect--whereas you, and the enemies, require at least 10 direct hits to be affected.- Some missions cannot be activated (game freezes).- Waiting for blowouts means you leave the game running for 5 minutes and walk around.  Good for ergonomics, but bad for immersion.- Most of the characters are not relatable.  I didn't care about Freedom-Duty factions, they were too generic.There were some nice enemies and some scary areas, but the game just didn't have the same charm as S.T.A.L.K.E.R. #1, so I cannot recommend it.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
												I felt like my last review was a bit harsh, so I'm putting up another one after playing the game for a few straight hours.CoP has given me mixed feelings. It's honestly a GOOD game, but gets severely butchered by awful performance. The atmosphere, the lighting, the mods, the horror and survival elements are done well enough to keep me playing for awhile, that's until the stuttering gets worse and worse to the point where it becomes a huge chore to continue, which really sucks because I could play this game forever without the technical flaws. STALKER gives me feelings that I don't get in other games. I'm saddened to leave it behind. I strongly feel that STALKER needs a reboot. I would play the föck out of a new STALKER game running on a beefier engine, like the 4A engine! The extra polish would be well-deserved. I'm deeply sorry to give thumbs down, but CoP goes against what makes a game a game - Stability. Without a stable framerate, how do you apply/develop skills or even stay immersed? Such a shame. Good effort, but better luck next time, future devs. I'm out of here, stalker.Additional info (in case you haven't said "F U!!!" already):I finished the story once on sheeti pc hardware (dafuq was wrong with me?). I now run a Core i5-4460, GTX 970 SSC, 8GB RAM, 120GB SSD and a G-Sync monitor, and can't finished the damn thing. Yes, I've tried many fixes online, including the 'Complete' mod. Nothing works. Come on, bring a STALKER game that's playable!! Don't waste great potential.

I'm not one for story or anything in my games but after a short 2 minute slide show you're just dumped into an ugly barren wasteland filled with nothing but the WORST hit detection, a mess of a UI and just disgusting gameplay in general. number of helpful: 2 of 32 people (6%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												This game is awful.So once I start up the game it actually works (something quite rare for a lot of games on steam!). So far I'm happy. Then I've got to sit through a whole minute of stupid AMD advertisements. Once I get to the main menu, In an effort to try to learn the mechanics of the game before I went into singleplayer, I clicked multiplayer. Of course I've got to go make an account with my email. However, since it didn't have password requirements, email verification, and I didn't have to exit the game to create it, i'll let it pass. Then, what showed up for me were 10 different servers, all with over 120 ping, 8 of which being completely empty, and the other 2 having 1 person each. So this game is dead. Not a good sign. Then I went to singleplayer.  I've got to sit through a 10 minute cutscene, I'm not able to skip it as far as I know. About half of it was explaining the events of Chernobyl, something most people do know about, especially in a game about the place...Then the rest of it is kind of reasonable. They introduce the stalkers, a group of people who live in Chernobyl so they can sell artifacts from the location. Okay, sounds kind of interesting. At the end of the cutscene they kind of just plop you into a random location with 5 objectives: ALL OF THEM saying "investigate the crash site". That's all. I'm also given some weapons and an infinite number of screws that I have no idea the purpose of. I also see a small yellow arrow on my minimap. So I decided to follow it. About 20 yards from actually being right in front of some NPCS, they abruptly show up on my screen. I shot them, thinking they were hostiles. Then I was able to loot them, but I already had all of the stuff they had. Not very rewarding. So I restarted and tried to go interact with them. I had to jump in front of them to notice me, then they say "Hey man, put the weapon away." Okay. I try to, but there's no actual way to do that unless you want to take out your binoculars or those pile of screws. That's all. They don't shoot me. They don't even do anything if I don't put the weapon away. Boring.So then I go back to following the arrow.  After 10 minutes of walking through a whole lot of nothing interesting and repetitive terrain, I get bored and randomly shoot in the air. Then this invisible creature shows up. I shoot him so many times and he doesn't die. I eventually get him but I couldn't interact with his corpse. Couldn't even loot it. No rewards for wasting all of my ammo. Back to following the arrow. so I get to the location, and the objective marker on my minimap is on one of those hills in video games that you aren't able to climb up because its too steep. I continously walk around the hill trying to find a way up, I even try to glitch myself up because you are able to in certain games. Then I come across a giant hole in the ground (probably the crash site, but not according to the minimap). It's got some weird things circling around it. I walk to the center and flames start going around. I get out of the hole and then go back in because there was nothing else to do and I hadn't figured out exactly what the hole's purpose was. Then I realize im at 1 bar of hp and I die. That's when I realized this game is garbage. How does it have overwhelmingly positive reviews?I get it. I didn't even give this game an hour. But most of what I played was cutscene, and the rest was a walking simulator  with no rewards or obvious purpose to interacting with the environment or characters. I saw some ruined buildings over and over again, empty. Here I am, requesting a refund.TLDR: garbage walking simulator

												I got this game because it was suggested to me and it looked like a fun title to add to my collection. It seemed up my alley, too. Post-apocalyptic, FPS, RPG elements. It is very...different. I don't know quite how to describe it. It was just not what I was expecting or hoping for. It seems like it would be a massive time sink. The game gives very little direction and just drops you into a situation. The dialogue system feels very dated. I won't lie, I played for about half an hour. I felt nothing. No emotion, no real goal, no reason to keep going in the face of adversity. There is a whole world here, which is great. I just know nothing about it and the game doesn't really seem to give a damn if I do. For ♥♥♥♥'s sake, I understand Dark Souls more than I understand this.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
												Some Russians tried to make a Fallout 3 clone in Garry's Mod?Graphics:They run as bad as they look.  The map(s) are small, un-detailed, and functionally empty.  Comparing the quarry in this game, to the one(s) in Fallout 4, is laughable.  On top of being low quality, with zero style and bad performance, the graphics are also buggy, with shadows glitching around on max settings.Gameplay:Terrible core/FPS mechanics, guns aren't satisfying, extremely limited stamina, you can jump about 2 inches high.  The open world is even worse, small and empty, there are fields of nothing, followed by empty buildings.  There is practically no loot, and no reason to explore.  Choices you make in-game have no effect on anything, only to be relayed as text cards during the end-credits.  The game is also severely buggy, I don't think a single quest played out correctly, and at several points, the tracker for the main quest even disappeared.  "This item is too damaged to be sold"Story:*Find out why some helicopters crashed*  "They crashed because of some information that should have been blatantly obvious, except it goes against in-game mechanics, so doesn't make any sense"  *fly away into the sunset*.  The first 3/4s of this relatively short game are boring and pointless, doing simple fetch quests on nonsensically separated maps.  The last act is slightly more interesting, but only a few quests long, and still not above average.  Voice acting is sparse, most of the time just giant walls of text, with simplified Fallout 3 style responses.  Stick with Fallout 3, its the same price, came out around the same time, and 10x better than this game in every category.

												Geeze, I feel bad for even doing this, and considering its the first time I have ever considered doing it in the history of having a Steam account....its really that bad.Asking a Russian or fellow eastern-european to write game dialogue is about as pointless and clunky as asking a gay frenchman to beat someone to death with his bare hands....its just...embarrassing.What stumps me is the Stalker 2 that I played back in the day...blew my mind!It is as if they simplified their engine to support a rolling wide open wasteland, which is not that big to begin with, spent a week on creating rhetorical dialogue, expanded the anomaly mechanics, and figured it would sit in pole position or next to the likes of Fallout or Skyrim! I'm sad GSC dropped the ball on this - I was looking for atmosphere, an immersive expanse and lots of loot to tinker with. Although the palette set some of the scene...the lack of interactivity, and opportunity, was a major killer for me. Failing this I felt like I was being chased by a tireless puppy for the first 2 hours (which I killed many times over, and I like puppies). This game just doesn't have it in my book. Sorry, but game over man - because I get more Stalker feel out of Metro: Last Light

content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												If you like the plot like me you might spend a few hours in this game. I specially liked that your choises may impact your missions and there's basically no "wrong" answer, only another way of doing things. But i think It's mostly a game for already fans. I'd suggest you rather buy Fallout. It have all the good things that Stalker Cop have but they fixed the bad things.. Like stupid AI/NPC's, repetetive conversations, clumsy inventory, movement and weapons. Not much customization or variety of loot, actually not much loot at all. Youy may want to read on the wiki's or check out a video before playing to learn the basics. The game will not tell you what certain status icons mean, how weapons work, that your choises impact the story and for some reason red pointer on the compass is south.. If they added some random loot spawns and let the player play a bit more with the economy i might have been able to look over it's many flaws.

number of helpful: 13 of 88 people (15%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												I seriously tried to get immersed in this world...I really did.  I played Shadow of Chernobyl many years ago and found it enjoyable with the immersive music and semi difficult gameplay.  Call of Prypiat (COP) is almost the exact opposite.  From the get go you are thrown into the extremely small map in search of your 5 objectives, crashed helicopters.  The music is there, the scariness is there...but the game just lacks something that its predecessors had.  I can't quite place it, but the game feels rushed.  I know its european but they can make some really great games.  First off, you get way too much ammo initially.  The game is fairly easy on the standard difficulty however, you will die from cheap deaths over and over and over forcing you to quick save like every 5 minutes lest you die and have to load something from an hour ago.  For this game to be enjoyable graphically these days, you pretty much have to download a 3 year old graphic mod that improves lighting and shadows while also improving a few textures here and there.  Edits:  A few things I forgot to mention that are really tedious:Your character gets exhausted after 10 seconds of running!  This leaves you being very slow and open to attack...very annoying.  And finally the engine crashes every so often leaving you reloading a previous save. So again, save often. At least every 5 minutes.For me, I think it's just the size of the map initially that put me off.  Its just a giant circle with your objectives on the outer sides and keeping the quest hub in the very center.  It's pretty stock gameplay design if you ask me and pulls from the immersion.  There are Stalker fan boys on here that have sunk hundreds of hours into this game and the series in a whole and will probably scoff at this review.  I just couldnt get into it.   For 20 bucks I'd say this is definately NOT worth a buy.  Wait for it to go on sale which it does quite often and get it for half off.  Today, there are just better shooters out there like the Metro series which has far superior graphics.  Obviously...the game is 5 years old so the graphics arent going to be stellar.  IMO to enjoy this, download the misery mod to make the game really hard and immersive.  I think also, if there was a skill system in place it would make me feel like i'm progressing. Instead I just get better weapons if I search in caves and such.  Eventually, from what i've read, people get so powerful from farming resources for cash that they have all the best loot in the game and are pretty untouchable...even with the misery mod.  This probably takes time but whats the point after that?  I'd rather have a skill system in place or at least attributes that improve the more I run, fight etc.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												Okay, second review on a game that I have ever written but here it goes. Don't waste your money. The games hit box (or whatever you call it) sucks, you are aiming right at an enemy and missing so they turn and shoot you. The rifles jam like every 10 seconds so don't plan on sneaking up on a group and killing them all because you might get one before your gun jams and you get killed. The weight thing they did sucks, instead of your bag being full you get over loaded and can't move unless you drop stuff and that isn't good when you are being shot at. Enemies just appear before your eyes and you are being shot at (I have a really nice gaming machine so it isn't my puter). On a 1 to 10 I give it a solid 3, which is pretty sucky but it does have a few good things about it and so much potential that never developed.

												Now first off, the game itself is great! Gameplay, story, "open world", etc. all solid in most area. But what really drives me nuts are the constant crashes of the god damn engine. Admitatly, it only happens if you mod your game and I'm talking basic script modding, nothing that would even touch the graphic engine.I have a decent rig (MSI X58A-GD65 MB, Intel i7 950 3.07GHz Quadcore, Corsair 12 GB DDR3 RAM, MSI GTX680 /w 4GB DDR5 VRAM, WD Black HDD), but the game still hangs once in a while when loading an area and that's when the crashes happen.I like ... no I love modding my games and any game that doesn't support this or messes up with doing it, I can not recommend. Fix it and I'll adjust this review.

												There's a random bug that seems to frequently occur where dead bodies are not properly removed by the game when leaving a zone area, which making you unable to return to that zone ever again. (The game will crash to desktop every time when trying to zone back.)This bug can vary from annoying (being unable to finish quests in the area or visit vendors,) to game breaking (Being unable to return to a zone where a primary mission is located. This bug has occurred at various points in 3 out of 4 play throughs of the game, (Usually after arriving in Pripyat.) and can prove extremely frustrating, as such I cannot recommend.

												The STALKER series is easily one of my favorites. With that being said, these are the most poorly made video games to ever be sold. 99% of the forums for them are filled with people who cannot run the game properly, if at all. It is a shame that Steam allows them to be sold. This and SOC USED to run, but now they won't even launch. This is a very common and legitimate problem, yet the STALKER fans get so butthurt about anything negative, no matter how legitimate it is, and they will thumb it down. Stay away from spending money on these games. It hurts to say that because they are such wonderful games.

number of helpful: 13 of 89 people (15%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												Personally I didn't find this anywhere near as good as the first game.The game map has changed from a long corridor of zones with sparse safe areas to a simple 3 zone system where you have to pay for the travel between them. I do however prefer the hub system of having everyone important to the story and trade in one single building.The user interface is a major improvement over the first almost to a point where it's night and day as far as usability is concerned. I wouldn't recommend playing this though, the storyling slightly taints my view on the franchise and as there is no likelihood of a sequel it feels far too open ended.

content:

												After some time spent ingame i couldn't recommend it. Sorry guys but it's full of bugs :( Idea is great, atmosphere is one of the best in games in any genre, graphics are great - especcially after installing "Complete" mod.From my 4 hours spent in game, it took me at least half an ingame time just to start the game. This means starting game and closing it with task manager because "xr3da.exe" (or something simmilar) is not responding.I played "Shadow of Chernobil" and it was great. This game has improved in graphic department, atmosphere but also in bugs as well.I would really like to recommend this game, but not being able to start properly and (probably) finish it because of a bug would be verry dissapointing and annoying.I really hope someone can buy this serial and make it as bug free as possible without losing what it already is.EDIT: after finishing the game, i still wouldn't recommend it. I was surprised by the ending (no spoilers here): after a short shootout, credits rolled, to my surprise. SoC was way better, probably because it was the first one. After all this, i would recommend buying it only in pack with other two S.T.A.L.K.E.R.s and on a discount.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												I really wanted to enjoy this game, but I can't. I just simply can't, the game's perfomance is terrible. It just stutters and freezes, it kills the immersion, which I found to be a real shame because this game is so immersive. I've even tried fixes too, which didn't work and made it worse. Not to mention a complete clean re-install, still stuttering.Specs for those who are wondering:GTX 780 SUPERCLOCKED 6GB (Not overclocked, that's actually the title)i7-2600 3.40GHz16 GB RAMIf you're willing to put up with the stuttering and freezing every couple of seconds, then by all means play the game. You'll enjoy it, but I can't. You can take the greatest gameplay, the greatest story, the greatest graphics, the greatest audio, etc... But if the performance and optimization is bad, then I won't play it. It's as simple as that, I'm sure others will agree with me, but overall I'm probably on my own with that preference. I know most games have bugs, but this is ridiculous.Maybe I'll see if I can do something about the perfomance in the future, doubt anything will help.

												This game is so terrible its not worth or even possible playing for more than an hr. First off the emissions. I can understand the immersion aspect of it. But the fact they have an emission that occurs within 15 min of starting the game with no information about it at all with a real ♥♥♥♥♥♥ introduction and the game just puts your character in the middle of no where with no info on what to do at all except with a few quests that are named the exact same thing is just terrible way to start the game. After researching the game you'll find out where to take cover. Supposedly they're approved places to take cover. You barely have enough time to find a good place. And if you go into a cave. You can kiss your♥♥♥♥♥good buy. Which brings me to my next point in why this game is so bad. The enemies will not die. The guns have absolutely no range. If you get a single time by an enemy whether you got shot or scratched. your armor and weapon will instantly be broke. Meaning your gun will randomly misfire causing you to reload and you have to be point blake for an AR to even hit a damn thing. 170+ bullets into an enemy with well over 50% head shots does not kill one of those creature that jump around. I understand difficulty but the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ballistics and armor mechanics is game breaking. This is all said with the complete user bug fix mod. DO  NOT waste a penny on this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥game.
